It did not elaborate.\n\nThe event has raised $700,000 to $1 million annually to expand programs and purchase equipment for the hospital's Florida facility. It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the last eight years.\n\nMore than 1,100 doctors, nurses, medical students and other Ohio residents signed a public letter of concern over the choice of venue.", It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the last eight years.\n\nMore than 1,100 doctors, nurses, medical students and other Ohio residents signed a public letter of concern over the choice of venue.", It didn't elaborate.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the clinic said.\n\nSpokeswoman Eileen Sheil had said last week that the event was not political and that donors and executives discussed it and agreed Mar-a-Lago met the organization's needs.\n\nThe fundraiser has raised $700,000 to $1 million annually to expand programs and purchase equipment for the hospital's Florida facility. It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the last eight years.\n\nBut, citing Trump's positions, more than 1,100 doctors, nurses, medical students and other Ohio residents signed a public letter of concern over the choice of venue.\n\nThe letter said the hospital's support for the Trump Organization was unacceptable \"because it symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare and cut billions of dollars in research funding from the National Institutes of Health budget.\"\n\nOne doctor who signed said Trump's approach to medicine defies the hospital's core principles for diversity, integrity, research and facts.\n\nThe American Red Cross faced similar pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the worldwide humanitarian relief organization was offering aid to those affected by Trump's moratorium on the U.S. refugee program.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:11:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": It said the event was not political.\n\nCuyahoga County's largest employer said Thursday it made the decision to pull the event after \"careful consideration\" of various issues and released this statement:\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018. It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the last eight years.\n\nMore than 1,100 doctors, nurses, medical students and other Ohio residents signed a public letter of concern over the choice of venue.", {"id": "9735043", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 2, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 370, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Facilities", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Facilities", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 506, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Research", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Research", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710999821", "source": {"id": "2989", "title": "The Detroit News", "uri": "detroitnews.com"}, "url": "http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/politics/2017/08/17/trump-resort-cleveland-clinic/104683310/", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nColumbus, Ohio -- A leading U.S. hospital pulled its annual fundraiser from Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort on Thursday, reversing course after initially resisting pressure from health professionals and others over the president's support for repealing the Affordable Care Act and cutting federal budget dollars to medical research.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic said in a statement that it decided not to hold the event there after \"careful consideration\" of a number of issues. It didn't elaborate.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the clinic said.\n\nSpokeswoman Eileen Sheil had said last week that the event was not political and that donors and executives discussed it and agreed Mar-a-Lago met the organization's needs.\n\nThe fundraiser has raised $700,000 to $1 million annually to expand programs and purchase equipment for the hospital's Florida facility. It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the last eight years.\n\nBut, citing Trump's positions, more than 1,100 doctors, nurses, medical students and other Ohio residents signed a public letter of concern over the choice of venue.\n\nThe letter said the hospital's support for the Trump Organization was unacceptable \"because it symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare and cut billions of dollars in research funding from the National Institutes of Health budget.\"\n\nOne doctor who signed said Trump's approach to medicine defies the hospital's core principles for diversity, integrity, research and facts.\n\nThe American Red Cross faced similar pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the worldwide humanitarian relief organization was offering aid to those affected by Trump's moratorium on the U.S. refugee program.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "image": null, "timeCrawl": "16:37:00", "isDuplicate": false, "title": "Cleveland Clinic will pull event from Mar-a-Lago resort", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "9730138", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 2, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 370, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Facilities", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Facilities", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 506, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Research", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Research", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710986856", "source": {"id": "1806", "title": "tristateupdate.com", "uri": "tristateupdate.com"}, "url": "http://www.tristateupdate.com/story/36158332/cleveland-clinic-will-pull-event-from-mar-a-lago-resort", "body": "COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP) - A leading U.S. hospital pulled its annual fundraiser from Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort on Thursday, reversing course after initially resisting pressure from health professionals and others over the president's support for repealing the Affordable Care Act and cutting federal budget dollars to medical research.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic said in a statement that it decided not to hold the event there after \"careful consideration\" of a number of issues. It didn't elaborate.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the clinic said.\n\nSpokeswoman Eileen Sheil had said last week that the event was not political and that donors and executives discussed it and agreed Mar-a-Lago met the organization's needs.\n\nThe fundraiser has raised $700,000 to $1 million annually to expand programs and purchase equipment for the hospital's Florida facility. It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the last eight years.\n\nBut, citing Trump's positions, more than 1,100 doctors, nurses, medical students and other Ohio residents signed a public letter of concern over the choice of venue.\n\nThe letter said the hospital's support for the Trump Organization was unacceptable \"because it symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare and cut billions of dollars in research funding from the National Institutes of Health budget.\"\n\nOne doctor who signed said Trump's approach to medicine defies the hospital's core principles for diversity, integrity, research and facts.\n\nThe American Red Cross faced similar pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the worldwide humanitarian relief organization was offering aid to those affected by Trump's moratorium on the U.S. refugee program.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the last eight years.\n\nBut, citing Trump's positions, more than 1,100 doctors, nurses, medical students and other Ohio residents signed a public letter of concern over the choice of venue.\n\nThe letter said the hospital's support for the Trump Organization was unacceptable \"because it symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare and cut billions of dollars in research funding from the National Institutes of Health budget.\"\n\nOne doctor who signed said Trump's approach to medicine defies the hospital's core principles for diversity, integrity, research and facts.\n\nSandy Theis, executive director of the liberal policy group ProgressOhio, one of several organizations behind the letter, said the hospital's decision shows \"the resistance is working.\"\n\n\"I applaud The Cleveland Clinic for cancelling their gala at Mar-a-Lago and letting President Trump know that bigotry and racial violence have no place in America,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe American Red Cross faced similar pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the "http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2017/08/19/532241/Americas-biggest-charities-boycott-Trump", "body": "Major charities cancel events at Trump's Mar-a-Lago club in Florida\n\nSeveral charitable groups have cancelled plans to hold fundraising events at US President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Florida, amid anger over his comments on Charlottesville.\n\nThe American Red Cross, the Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and several other medical organizations have canceled galas at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThe American Red Cross said in a statement that it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters.\"\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018,\" the Cleveland Clinic said in a statement on Thursday, according to the Cleveland Plain Dealer. \"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nThe American Cancer Society also said it would move its 2017 Island of Palm Beach gala from Trump's club, The Washington Post reported on the same day.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the group said in a statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nAccording to The Washington Post, the Salvation Army, the Autism Project of Palm Beach County and Susan G Komen have all also canceled fundraisers.\n\nThe latest developments came after the president's controversial press conference at Trump Tower last week where thousands of white supremacists, KKK members and neo-Nazis descended on Charlottesville for a \"Unite the Right\" rally. The march however turned violent when a man plowed a vehicle into a group of anti-hate demonstrators protesting against the white supremacist rally, killing at least three people and injuring 20 others.\n\nTrump came under fire for initially blaming the violence on \"many sides.\"\n\nNonprofits have not been the only ones abandoning Trump after his comments on Charlottesville.\n\nThree White House business panels were scrapped in the past week after CEOs of some of America's largest companies withdrew their support from Trump.\n\nRead more:\n\nLaurel Baker, the head of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, also started discouraging businesses from hosting events at Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"If you're looking at your mission statement,\" she in an interview with The Washington Post, \"can you honestly say having an event at Mar-a-Lago, given all that has transpired, is the best stewardship of your efforts?\"\n\nShe added, \"The club is a member of the chamber. But right is right.\"\n\nTrump has been criticized both in the country and abroad over his response to the violence in Charlottesville. In the US, many lawmakers, including members of his own party, and business executives have distanced themselves from him. {"id": "9957414", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 17, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 261, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Web Design and Development", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Web_Design_and_Development", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 298, "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711607413", "source": {"id": "18317", "title": "newsnet5", "uri": "news5cleveland.com"}, "url": "http://www.news5cleveland.com/news/national/charities-including-red-cross-salvation-army-cancel-events-connected-to-trump", "body": "Some of the biggest-named charities in America are walking away from President Trump.\n\nThe American Red Cross, The Salvation Army and Susan G. Komen foundation all said Friday they're canceling events at Trump's Palm Beach property Mar-a-Lago. That comes after three organizations made similar announcements on Thursday.\n\nThe cancellations follow the spectacular implosion of Trump's business councils this week over the president's insistence that counter-protesters shared the blame for violence at a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe collapse of the councils was an extraordinary rebuke to a president who prides himself on being business-friendly. High-profile CEOs like JPMorgan Chase' Jamie Dimon have publicly slammed Trump's reaction to Charlottesville.\n\nNow, Trump's words appear to be hurting his own business.\n\n\"The American Red Cross has decided we cannot host our annual fundraising event at Mar-a-Lago, as it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the organization said in a statement.\n\nThe Red Cross said it \"provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nAccording to the Palm Beach Daily News social events calendar, The Red Cross was slated to host its International Red Cross Ball at the resort on Feb. 3, 2018.\n\nThe Salvation Army also pulled its Holiday Snow Ball off the venue's events list.\n\n\"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago,\" spokesperson Kurt Watkins said.\n\nOn Thursday, the Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society and an organization that supports disaster relief said they were abandoning plans for fundraisers at the private club.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the Cleveland Clinic said in a statement. It did not give a reason for its cancellation -- the first time in eight years it will not hold the event at Mar-a-Lago. The announcement was reported earlier Thursday by the Cleveland Plain Dealer.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the hospital group's CEO, was among the executives on one of Trump's business councils.\n\nA few hours after the Cleveland Clinic's announcement, the American Cancer Society pulled out.\n\nThe nonprofit said in a statement that it had planned to host its 2018 gala at Mar-a-Lago \"based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements.\" But the organization said \"it has become increasingly clear\" that hosting its fundraiser on Trump-owned property presents a \"challenge\" to its values.\n\nThe American Cancer Society, which has hosted its annual event at Mar-a-Lago for at least the past decade -- has not selected another venue. The decision was reported earlier by the Palm Beach Post.\n\nMar-a-Lago declined to comment. The Trump Organization did not immediately respond to a message.\n\nTrump retained an ownership interest in his business when he took office, which means he has a personal stake in Mar-a-Lago's success. As president, he has raised the club's profile by making repeated visits there.\n\nThe health organization last hosted its gala in Trump's Palm Beach club in February of this year. It coincided with a visit from Trump, who was in Florida the same weekend to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom, a group that supports Israel's national ambulance, blood-services and disaster-relief organization, confirmed that it, too, has decided to move its annual gala to another location.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago,\" spokesperson Erik Levis said in a statement.\n\nThe event was scheduled to take place at Mar-a-Lago on Feb. 25, 2018.\n\nTwo organizations that have announced plans to hold events at Mar-a-Lago in the coming months confirmed they'll go ahead with their plans.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said it would still host its annual black-tie dinner dance at the club on January 6, 2018, citing its deposit and the size of the venue.\n\nThe Kravis Center for the Performing Arts confirmed it will host a wine auction at the club on Feb. 1.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T18:43:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 1494, "textStart": 1482, "date": "2018-02-03", "amb": false}, It didn't elaborate.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the clinic said.\n\nSpokeswoman Eileen Sheil had said last week that the event was not political and that donors and executives discussed it and agreed Mar-a-Lago met the organization's needs.\n\nThe fundraiser has raised $700,000 to $1 million annually to expand programs and purchase equipment for the hospital's Florida facility. It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the last eight years.\n\nBut, citing Trump's positions, more than 1,100 doctors, nurses, medical students and other Ohio residents signed a public letter of concern over the choice of venue.\n\nThe letter said the hospital's support for the Trump Organization was unacceptable \"because it symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare and cut billions of dollars in research funding from the National Institutes of Health budget.\"\n\nOne doctor who signed said Trump's approach to medicine defies the hospital's core principles for diversity, integrity, research and facts.\n\nThe American Red Cross faced similar pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the worldwide humanitarian relief organization was offering aid to those affected by Trump's moratorium on the U.S. refugee program.\n\nSubscribe", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:10:00Z", "extractedDates": {"id": "9954540", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 17, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 261, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Web Design and Development", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Web_Design_and_Development", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 298, "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711599092", "source": {"id": "537", "title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/18/now-charities-are-dumping-trump-too/", "body": "Some of the biggest-named charities in America are walking away from President Trump.\n\nThe American Red Cross, The Salvation Army and Susan G. Komen foundation all said Friday they're canceling events at Trump's Palm Beach property Mar-a-Lago. That comes after three organizations made similar announcements on Thursday.\n\nThe cancellations follow the spectacular implosion of Trump's business councils this week over the president's insistence that counter-protesters shared the blame for violence at a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe collapse of the councils was an extraordinary rebuke to a president who prides himself on being business-friendly. High-profile CEOs like JPMorgan Chase' Jamie Dimon have publicly slammed Trump's reaction to Charlottesville.\n\nNow, Trump's words appear to be hurting his own business.\n\n\"The American Red Cross has decided we cannot host our annual fundraising event at Mar-a-Lago, as it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the organization said in a statement.\n\nThe Red Cross said it \"provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nAccording to the Palm Beach Daily News social events calendar, The Red Cross was slated to host its International Red Cross Ball at the resort on Feb. 3, 2018.\n\nThe Salvation Army also pulled its Holiday Snow Ball off the venue's events list.\n\n\"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago,\" spokesperson Kurt Watkins said.\n\nOn Thursday, the Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society and an organization that supports disaster relief said they were abandoning plans for fundraisers at the private club.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the Cleveland Clinic said in a statement. It did not give a reason for its cancellation -- the first time in eight years it will not hold the event at Mar-a-Lago. The announcement was reported earlier Thursday by the Cleveland Plain Dealer.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the hospital group's CEO, was among the executives on one of Trump's business councils.\n\nA few hours after the Cleveland Clinic's announcement, the American Cancer Society pulled out.\n\nThe nonprofit said in a statement that it had planned to host its 2018 gala at Mar-a-Lago \"based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements.\" But the organization said \"it has become increasingly clear\" that hosting its fundraiser on Trump-owned property presents a \"challenge\" to its values.\n\nThe American Cancer Society, which has hosted its annual event at Mar-a-Lago for at least the past decade -- has not selected another venue. The decision was reported earlier by the Palm Beach Post.\n\nMar-a-Lago declined to comment. The Trump Organization did not immediately respond to a message.\n\nTrump retained an ownership interest in his business when he took office, which means he has a personal stake in Mar-a-Lago's success. As president, he has raised the club's profile by making repeated visits there.\n\nThe health organization last hosted its gala in Trump's Palm Beach club in February of this year. It coincided with a visit from Trump, who was in Florida the same weekend to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom, a group that supports Israel's national ambulance, blood-services and disaster-relief organization, confirmed that it, too, has decided to move its annual gala to another location.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago,\" spokesperson Erik Levis said in a statement.\n\nThe event was scheduled to take place at Mar-a-Lago on Feb. 25, 2018.\n\nTwo organizations that have announced plans to hold events at Mar-a-Lago in the coming months confirmed they'll go ahead with their plans.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said it would still host its annual black-tie dinner dance at the club on January 6, 2018, citing its deposit and the size of the venue.\n\nThe Kravis Center for the Performing Arts confirmed it will host a wine auction at the club on Feb. 1.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T18:23:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 1494, "textStart": 1482, "date": "2018-02-03", "amb": false}, {"id": "9950045", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 17, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 96, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Instruments", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 261, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Web Design and Development", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Web_Design_and_Development", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 298, "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711587040", "source": {"id": "537", "title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/18/five-organizations-cancel-fundraisers-at-trumps-mar-a-lago/", "body": "First, top CEOs abandoned President Trump. Now, major organizations are canceling plans to hold events at the president's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society and an organization that supports disaster relief said Thursday they were abandoning plans for fundraisers at the private club. On Friday, the American Red Cross and Salvation Army said they too planned to take their business elsewhere.\n\nThe cancellations follow the spectacular implosion of Trump's business councils this week over the president's insistence that counter-protesters shared the blame for violence at a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe collapse of the councils was an extraordinary rebuke to a president who prides himself on being business-friendly. High-profile CEOs like JPMorgan Chase's Jamie Dimon have publicly slammed Trump's reaction to Charlottesville.\n\nNow, Trump's words appear to be hurting his own business.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the Cleveland Clinic said in a statement. It did not give a reason for its cancellation -- the first time in eight years it will not hold the event at Mar-a-Lago. The announcement was reported earlier Thursday by the Cleveland Plain Dealer.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the hospital group's CEO, was among the executives on one of Trump's business councils.\n\nA few hours after the Cleveland Clinic's announcement, the American Cancer Society pulled out.\n\nThe nonprofit said in a statement that it had planned to host its 2018 gala at Mar-a-Lago \"based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements.\" But the organization said \"it has become increasingly clear\" that hosting its fundraiser on Trump-owned property presents a \"challenge\" to its values.\n\nThe American Cancer Society, which has hosted its annual event at Mar-a-Lago for at least the past decade -- has not selected another venue. The decision was reported earlier by the Palm Beach Post.\n\nMar-a-Lago declined to comment. The Trump Organization did not immediately respond to a message.\n\nTrump retained an ownership interest in his business when he took office, which means he has a personal stake in Mar-a-Lago's success. As president, he has raised the club's profile by making repeated visits there.\n\nThe health organization last hosted its gala in Trump's Palm Beach club in February of this year. It coincided with a visit from Trump, who was in Florida the same weekend to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom, a group that supports Israel's national ambulance, blood-services and disaster-relief organization, confirmed that it, too, has decided to move its annual gala to another location.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago,\" spokesperson Erik Levis said in a statement.\n\nThe event was scheduled to take place at Mar-a-Lago on Feb. 25, 2018.\n\nThe Mar-a-Lago event calendar grew emptier still on Friday.\n\n\"The American Red Cross has decided we cannot host our annual fundraising event at Mar-a-Lago, as it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the organization said in a statement. \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nAccording to the Palm Beach Daily News social events calendar, The Red Cross was slated to host its \"International Red Cross Ball at the resort on Feb. 3, 2018.\n\nSalvation Army also pulled its Holiday Snow Ball off the venue's events list.\n\n\"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago,\" spokesperson Kurt Watkins said.\n\nCNNMoney has reached out to the other organizations that have announced plans to hold events at Mar-a-Lago in the coming months, and two confirmed they'll go ahead with their plans.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said it would still host its annual black-tie dinner dance at the club on January 6, 2018, citing its deposit and the size of the venue.\n\nThe Kravis Center for the Performing Arts confirmed it will host a wine auction at the club on Feb. 1.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T17:54:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 3036, "textStart": 3023, "date": "2018-02-25", "amb": {"id": "9979962", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 3, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical Specialties", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical_Specialties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 239, "label": "dmoz/Business/Biotechnology and Pharmaceuticals/Pharmaceuticals", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Biotechnology_and_Pharmaceuticals/Pharmaceuticals", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 333, "label": "dmoz/Society/Activism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Activism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711669681", "source": {"id": "228", "title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/cleveland-clinic-american-cancer-society-215800407.html", "body": "UPDATE: Aug. 18 -- Seven groups have now said they won't host future events at Mar-A-Lago, including the Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen, The Washington Post reported Friday.\n\nPreviously:\n\nTwo major nonprofit organizations are pulling the plug on their plans to host upcoming events at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club amid backlash over his controversial response to the deadly clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, a nonprofit medical center, announced its decision to cancel hosting its annual charity gala at the Palm Beach, Florida, resort in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018,\" the statement said. \"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nThe annual event, which typically raises around $1 million and is attended by roughly 500 people, had been scheduled to take place on Feb. 24, 2018, and would have marked eight years in a row at the location.\n\nProceeds from the fundraiser benefit Cleveland Clinic Florida, a hospital in Weston, according to Eileen Sheil, executive director of communications at Cleveland Clinic.\n\nSheil told HuffPost there were \"a variety of reasons\" the clinic decided to drop Mar-a-Lago, but wouldn't elaborate much further.\n\n\"I think the community really was asking us to not have it there,\" Sheil said, adding that the decision was made Thursday morning.\n\nThe clinic is currently looking into other locations to host the gala.\n\nHours after Cleveland Clinic announced their plans to scrap their planned event, the American Cancer Society followed suit.\n\nThe nationwide health organization confirmed it is seeking a new venue to host its Island of Palm Beach gala on Feb. 22, 2018, in a statement to HuffPost. The organization has hosted the event at Mar-a-Lago since 2007.\n\n\"When we chose to hold our 2018 event and related dinner at Mar-a-Lago, we selected the venue based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements,\" the statement said.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the statement continued. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nThe American Cancer Society and Cleveland Clinic are just the latest organizations to distance themselves from Trump following nearly a week of withering criticism over his response to a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville that left one dead and dozens injured.\n\nTrump initially blamed \"many sides\" for hatred and bigotry on Saturday, but eventually specifically condemned white supremacist groups after facing harsh criticism. But the president walked back some of his strong language on Tuesday by defending those who participated in the white nationalist rally and accusing counterprotesters -- whom he referred to as the \"alt-left\" -- of also acting violently.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the chief executive of Cleveland Clinic was a member of the Strategic and Policy Forum, one of Trump's two business advisory councils that disbanded this week in the wake of Trump's explosive comments.\n\nOn Monday, Kenneth Fraizer, CEO of Merck & Co., stepped down from Trump's American Manufacturing Council. One by one, top business executives including, Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank and Intel CEO Brian Krzanich, followed in Fraizer's footsteps. As members of Trump's Strategic and Policy Forum began to resign from the group on Wednesday, Trump announced that he was \"ending both\" councils to alleviate \"pressure\" on its members.\n\nLaurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, told the Palm Beach Post that organizations should stop holding charity events at the Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"If you have a conscience, you're really condoning bad behavior by continuing to be there,\" Baker said. \"Many say it's the dollars (raised at the events) that count. Yes. But the integrity of any organization rests on their sound decisions and stewardship.\"\n\nTrump Organization representatives did not immediately respond to HuffPost's multiple requests for comment. A receptionist for Mar-a-Lago said she was told to direct phone calls to the White House. A White House spokeswoman declined to comment on the canceled events.\n\nThis article originally appeared on HuffPost.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T21:46:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 15, {"id": "9899074", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1154, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Events", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Events", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711455863", "source": {"id": "4014", "title": "The Hollywood Reporter", "uri": "hollywoodreporter.com"}, "url": "http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/charities-cancel-mar-a-lago-events-trump-backlash-1030765", "body": "The Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society and the American Friends of Magen David Adom have all changed venues.\n\nPresident Donald Trump's comments about the white nationalist rally last weekend are hurting not just his political standing, but his pocketbook.\n\nThree charities announced Thursday that they were canceling fundraisers at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort, a sign the president's business is starting to suffer backlash from his comments Tuesday about the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic said in a statement that it decided not to hold its annual event at his Palm Beach resort after \"careful consideration\" of a number of issues. It didn't elaborate, but the Ohio-based hospital was already under pressure to shift venues.\n\nDoctors, nurses and medical students of the hospital had signed a public letter earlier this year objecting to Mar-a-Lago given President Trump's plans to cut funding of medical research and other policies.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic has held its annual fundraiser at the resort for eight years.\n\nA few hours after the hospital pulled out, the American Cancer Society said it also planned to shift the venue of its annual fundraiser, called the 2018 Island of Palm Beach gala.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" spokeswoman Miriam Falco said in statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nFalco declined to elaborate.\n\nLate Thursday, the American Friends of Magen David Adom announced it had decided not to hold its 2018 fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago. The group, which raises money for an ambulance service in Israel, has been holding its annual gala at the resort since 2012.\n\nIts spokesman, Erik Levis, gave no reason but said the decision came after \"considerable deliberation.\" His statement noted the organization is \"apolitical.\"\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment. The managing director of Trump's properties in Florida, Bernd Lembcke, did not respond to a phone call seeking comment, either.\n\nThe president has drawn widespread and bipartisan criticism for his comments at a Trump Tower news conference where he insisted that \"both sides\" were to blame for violence at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville where a counterprotester was killed. The president dissolved two business councils after members who are CEOs began quitting.\n\nCleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove was a member of one of those panels designed to advise the president on the economy and jobs.\n\nThe gilded and glittering Mar-a-Lago has been a favorite spot for holding charity events and a money maker for the Trump Organization. Dubbed the Winter White House, it is one of the few places in the area that can hold a large crowd. Its 20,000 square-foot ballroom has massive archways and columns decorated in gold leaf.\n\nPalm Beach town records showed that 21 charities held events at Mar-a-Lago between last November and April, during the active social season.\n\nBut the resort has also become the site of protest by groups who oppose the president's policies and statements.\n\nThe American Red Cross faced pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the worldwide humanitarian relief organization was offering aid to those affected by Trump's moratorium on the U.S. refugee program.\n\nThe organization did not immediately respond to questions about whether it plans to hold its fundraiser next year at the resort.\n\nSome charities contacted by the Associated Press said they had no plans to change venues.\n\nThe Kravis Center said it plans to keep its annual wine auction at the Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"The event has been held there for a number of years, and the folks supporting it want to continue to have it there,\" spokesman Gary Schweikhart said.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said in a statement that it plans to keep its annual ball at Mar-a-Lago because it is not a political event and no other venues in town can accommodate 700 guests.\n\nThe event raised $700,000 this year, according to town records, with the proceeds used to buy equipment for the Palm Beach Police Department, help its officers and families when they are in need, and provide scholarships for officers' children. The foundation declined further comment.\n\nLaurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, said in an email that \"each organization should examine their mission statements to ensure that any fundraising efforts are not compromising their efforts.\"\n\nShe said she is not implying that charities should shun Trump.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:45:00Z", "extractedDates": It did not give a reason. The announcement was reported earlier Thursday by the Cleveland Plain Dealer. Mar-a-Lago declined comment.\n\nThe hospital group is based in Cleveland, but it has a health center in South Florida. Proceeds from previous Mar-a-Lago galas balls have helped pay for medical equipment, nursing education and wheelchairs, according to the organization's website.\n\nA spokeswoman said the event raises about $1 million each year on average. She said the Cleveland Clinic has not yet decided on a date or new location for the 2018 gala. The 2017 gala was in February.\n\nThe clinic had received criticism for hosting the annual event at Mar-a-Lago. Earlier this year, protesters organized outside the Cleveland center to pressure the hospital to cancel the event, according to local media reports.\n\nAnd in July, nearly 1,700 people -- including doctors and medical students -- signed an open letter asking the clinic to hold the fundraiser somewhere else.\n\nHolding the fundraiser there \"symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare and cut billions of dollars in research funding from the National Institutes of Health budget,\" read the letter, which was posted on Medium.\n\nTM & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. {"id": "9759768", "categories": [{"id": 2, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 370, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Facilities", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Facilities", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711065062", "source": {"id": "537", "title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/17/cleveland-clinic-cancels-fundraiser-at-trump-resort/", "body": "The Cleveland Clinic is abandoning plans to hold a gala fundraiser next year at President Trump's Mar-a-Lago club in Florida.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the hospital group's CEO, was among the executives on the White House business councils that imploded this week after Trump blamed both sides for the violence at a white nationalist rally in Virginia.\n\nIt will be the first time in eight years that the Cleveland Clinic has not held the fundraiser at the Trump resort.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the hospital group said in a statement. It did not give a reason. The announcement was reported earlier Thursday by the Cleveland Plain Dealer. Mar-a-Lago declined comment.\n\nThe hospital group is based in Cleveland, but it has a health center in South Florida. Proceeds from previous Mar-a-Lago galas balls have helped pay for medical equipment, nursing education and wheelchairs, according to the organization's website.\n\nA spokeswoman said the event raises about $1 million each year on average. She said the Cleveland Clinic has not yet decided on a date or new location for the 2018 gala. The 2017 gala was in February.\n\nThe clinic had received criticism for hosting the annual event at Mar-a-Lago. Earlier this year, protesters organized outside the Cleveland center to pressure the hospital to cancel the event, according to local media reports.\n\nAnd in July, nearly 1,700 people -- including doctors and medical students -- signed an open letter asking the clinic to hold the fundraiser somewhere else.\n\nHolding the fundraiser there \"symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare and cut billions of dollars in research funding from the National Institutes of Health budget,\" read the letter, which was posted on Medium.", {"id": "9888879", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1154, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Events", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Events", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711429176", "source": {"id": "2795", "title": "NewsMax", "uri": "newsmax.com"}, "url": "http://www.newsmax.com/US/trump-mar-a-lago-charity-events/2017/08/18/id/808350/", "body": "President Donald Trump's comments about the white nationalist rally last weekend are hurting not just his political standing, but his pocketbook.\n\nThree charities announced Thursday that they were canceling fundraisers at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort, a sign the president's business is starting to suffer backlash from his comments Tuesday about the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic said in a statement that it decided not to hold its annual event at his Palm Beach resort after \"careful consideration\" of a number of issues. It didn't elaborate, but the Ohio-based hospital was already under pressure to shift venues.\n\nDoctors, nurses and medical students of the hospital had signed a public letter earlier this year objecting to Mar-a-Lago given President Trump's plans to cut funding of medical research and other policies.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic has held its annual fundraiser at the resort for eight years.\n\nA few hours after the hospital pulled out, the American Cancer Society said it also planned to shift the venue of its annual fundraiser, called the 2018 Island of Palm Beach gala.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" spokeswoman Miriam Falco said in statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nFalco declined to elaborate.\n\nLate Thursday, the American Friends of Magen David Adom announced it had decided not to hold its 2018 fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago. The group, which raises money for an ambulance service in Israel, has been holding its annual gala at the resort since 2012.\n\nIts spokesman, Erik Levis, gave no reason but said the decision came after \"considerable deliberation.\" His statement noted the organization is \"apolitical.\"\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment. The managing director of Trump's properties in Florida, Bernd Lembcke, did not respond to a phone call seeking comment, either.\n\nThe president has drawn widespread and bipartisan criticism for his comments at a Trump Tower news conference where he insisted that \"both sides\" were to blame for violence at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville where a counterprotester was killed. The president dissolved two business councils after members who are CEOs began quitting.\n\nCleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove was a member of one of those panels designed to advise the president on the economy and jobs.\n\nThe gilded and glittering Mar-a-Lago has been a favorite spot for holding charity events and a money maker for the Trump Organization. Dubbed the Winter White House, it is one of the few places in the area that can hold a large crowd. Its 20,000 square-foot ballroom has massive archways and columns decorated in gold leaf.\n\nPalm Beach town records showed that 21 charities held events at Mar-a-Lago between last November and April, during the active social season.\n\nBut the resort has also become the site of protest by groups who oppose the president's policies and statements.\n\nThe American Red Cross faced pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the worldwide humanitarian relief organization was offering aid to those affected by Trump's moratorium on the U.S. refugee program.\n\nThe organization did not immediately respond to questions about whether it plans to hold its fundraiser next year at the resort.\n\nSome charities contacted by The Associated Press said they had no plans to change venues.\n\nThe Kravis Center said it plans to keep its annual wine auction at the Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"The event has been held there for a number of years, and the folks supporting it want to continue to have it there,\" spokesman Gary Schweikhart said.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said in a statement that it plans to keep its annual ball at Mar-a-Lago because it is not a political event and no other venues in town can accommodate 700 guests.\n\nThe event raised $700,000 this year, according to town records, with the proceeds used to buy equipment for the Palm Beach Police Department, help its officers and families when they are in need, and provide scholarships for officers' children. The foundation declined further comment.\n\nLaurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, said in an email that \"each organization should examine their mission statements to ensure that any fundraising efforts are not compromising their efforts.\"\n\nShe said she is not implying that charities should shun Trump.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:10:00Z", "extractedDates": Now, major organizations are canceling plans to hold events at the president's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society and an organization that supports disaster relief said Thursday they were abandoning plans for fundraisers at the private club.\n\nThe cancellations follow the spectacular implosion of Trump's business councils this week over the president's that counter-protesters shared the blame for violence at a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe collapse of the councils was an extraordinary rebuke to a president who prides himself on being business-friendly. High-profile CEOs like JPMorgan Chase's Jamie Dimon have publicly slammed Trump's reaction to Charlottesville.\n\nNow, Trump's words appear to be hurting his own business.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the Cleveland Clinic said in a statement. It did not give a reason for its cancellation -- the first time in eight years it will not hold the event at Mar-a-Lago. The announcement was reported earlier Thursday by the Cleveland Plain Dealer.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the hospital group's CEO, was among the executives on one of Trump's business councils.\n\nA few hours after the Cleveland Clinic's announcement, the American Cancer Society pulled out.\n\nThe nonprofit said in a statement that it had planned to host its 2018 gala at Mar-a-Lago \"based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements.\" But the organization said \"it has become increasingly clear\" that hosting its fundraiser on Trump-owned property presents a \"challenge\" to its values.\n\nThe American Cancer Society, which has hosted the annual event at Mar-a-Lago for at least the past decade -- has not selected another venue. The decision was reported earlier by the Palm Beach Post.\n\nMar-a-Lago declined to comment. The Trump Organization did not immediately respond to a message.\n\nTrump retained an ownership interest in his business when he took office, which means he has a personal stake in Mar-a-Lago's success. As president, he has raised the club's profile by making repeated visits there.\n\nThe health organization last hosted its gala in Trump's Palm Beach club in February of this year. It coincided with a visit from Trump, who was in Florida the same weekend to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom, a group that supports Israel's national ambulance, blood-services and disaster-relief organization, confirmed that it, too, has decided to move its annual gala to another location.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago,\" spokesperson Erik Levis said in a statement.\n\nThe event was scheduled to take place at Mar-a-Lago on Feb. 25, 2018.\n\nOn Thursday, CNNMoney reached out to all the organizations that have announced plans to hold events at Mar-a-Lago in the coming months.\n\nOnly one other organization, Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, responded to CNNMoney's inquiries. {"id": "9991588", "categories": [{"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711702902", "source": {"id": "1799", "title": "wyso.org", "uri": "wyso.org"}, "url": "http://wyso.org/post/charities-pull-fundraisers-planned-trumps-mar-lago", "body": "On Friday, three well-known charities -- the American Red Cross, the Salvation Army and Susan G. Komen -- announced they are canceling plans for fundraising events at President Trump's Palm Beach country club, Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThe three joined a growing list of nonprofits that have severed ties with the exclusive, Trump-owned resort. Others include the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society.\n\nThe cancellations come in the wake of Trump's controversial comments made earlier this week when he said that \"both sides were to blame\" for last weekend's deadly violence involving white supremacists in Charlottesville, Va.\n\nTrump has been under heavy criticism all week for his remarks, which prompted many corporate leaders to bail out of White House advisory boards. So many CEOs resigned that the president responded by disbanding three committees -- one focused on shaping business strategy, another on boosting manufacturing and third on improving infrastructure.\n\nAfter the CEOs started refusing to work with the president, pressure increased on charities to give up their annual trips to Mar-a-Lago for galas.\n\nFor example, Cleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove had served on one of the disbanded business councils. And a day after that dismantling happened, the hospital announced that \"after careful consideration,\" Cleveland Clinic would not hold its 2018 event at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nEarlier this year, despite a petition drive by doctors and medical students, the hospital had refused to cancel its fundraiser there. When medical students and other groups renewed the push recently, Cleveland Clinic remained firm, saying Mar-a-Lago met its needs.\n\nNow, it does not.\n\nThe American Red Cross said in its statement that it must provide \"assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions.\"\n\nThe charity's connection with the president's club \"has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" it said.\n\nThe Salvation Army issued a similar statement, saying its event at Mar-a-Lago helped raise money for disaster victims and the homeless. \"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event,\" the group says, \"we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\nSusan G. Komen, a charity that invests in breast cancer research, confirmed it is also withdrawing from Mar-a-Lago and is seeking a new venue for its fundraising event.\n\nThe rash of high-profile cancellations has created something of a scramble in Palm Beach as charities look for other suitable venues. The Palm Beach Post says other nearby hotels and the Palm Beach County Convention Center are hearing from interested groups.\n\nFor Trump, the cancellations will mean a significant loss of income, unless the staff at Mar-a-Lago finds new customers who want to book a 20,000-square-foot ballroom embellished with 24-karat gold leafing, modeled, as Trump told Florida Design magazine, after {"id": "9979104", "categories": [{"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711667790", "source": {"id": "2496", "title": "Talking Points Memo", "uri": "talkingpointsmemo.com"}, "url": "http://talkingpointsmemo.com/dc/charities-ditch-mar-a-lago-charlottesville", "body": "First, CEOs abandoned President Donald Trump by quitting White House advisory councils. Now, charities have begun to ditch Trump's business by canceling fundraisers planned at his Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach, Florida.\n\nIn the wake of Trump's failure to fully denounce white nationalists following the violence in Charlottesville, six charities have cancelled events planned for Mar-a-Lago next year.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, a hospital network, pulled its 2018 fundraising gala from Trump's Palm Beach club early Thursday afternoon. The clinic did not share its reasoning behind canceling plans to hold the event at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThen the American Cancer Society announced Thursday afternoon that it would no longer hold its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in February. The charity did not mention Trump by name, but noted its commitment to diversity.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" American Cancer Society spokeswoman Miriam Falco said in statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nLater Thursday, American Friends of Magen David Adom, a group that supports medical first responders in Israel, announced that it would no longer hold its annual fundraiser at Mar-A-Lago in 2018. The group, which held its fundraiser at Trump's club last year, did not offer specific reasoning for pulling the event from the Trump family venue.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago,\" the group said in a statement.\n\nFour charities announced plans to move their venues from Mar-A-Lago on Friday, including several major national foundations.\n\nThe American Red Cross, which was scheduled to hold an event in February of next year, announced that it pulled the event from Mar-A-Lago \"as it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters.\"\n\n\"We believe this action will allow us to continue to put the focus on our lifesaving mission and the people we serve. The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle,\" the organization said in a statement.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which was set to hold a fundraiser at Trump's Palm Beach club in December, said Friday that the venue had become a distraction.\n\n\"The Salvation Army relies heavily on fundraising events like The Holiday Snow Ball in Palm Beach to further our mission of helping those in need through a range of social services including food for the hungry, relief for disaster victims, clothing and shelter for the homeless, and opportunities for the underprivileged,\" the group said in a statement. \"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\nThe Susan G. Komen Foundation, a charity that fundraises for breast cancer research, told the Washington Post that they would change the venue for its event planned for January 2018, but did not offer a specific reasoning for doing so. The Autism Project of Palm Beach County also told the Washington Post on Friday that they would no longer hold a planned event at the club.\n\nCharities ditching Trump's businesses is the latest bit of fallout from his comments pandering to white nationalists in the wake of the deadly Charlottesville attack. Trump on Wednesday dissolved two White House advisory boards as the CEOs on the councils began to object to Trump's comments and leave the panels.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T16:39:00Z", {"id": "10023178", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 2, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 3, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical Specialties", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical_Specialties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711803616", "source": {"id": "1269", "title": "RTV6", "uri": "theindychannel.com"}, "url": "http://www.theindychannel.com/news/national/cleveland-clinic-american-cancer-society-pull-events-from-trump-resort", "body": "The Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society are abandoning plans to hold fundraisers at President Trump's Mar-a-Lago club in Florida.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the Cleveland Clinic's CEO, was among the executives on the White House business councils that imploded this week after Trump blamed both sides for the violence at a white nationalist rally in Virginia.\n\nIt will be the first time in eight years that the Cleveland Clinic has not held the fundraiser at the Trump resort.\n\n\"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years,\" the hospital group said in a statement. It did not give a reason. The announcement was reported earlier Thursday by the Cleveland Plain Dealer.\n\nA few hours after the Cleveland Clinic's announcement, the American Cancer Society followed suit.\n\nThe nonprofit said in a statement that it had planned to host its 2018 gala at Mar-a-Lago \"based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements.\" But the organization said \"it has become increasingly clear\" that hosting its fundraiser on Trump-owned property presents a \"challenge\" to its values.\n\nThe nonprofit -- which has hosted the annual event at Mar-a-Lago for at least the past decade -- has not yet selected another venue. The decision was reported earlier by the Palm Beach Post.\n\nMar-a-Lago declined comment. The Trump Organization did not immediately respond to a message.\n\nThe health organization last hosted its gala in Trump's Palm Beach club in February of this year.\n\nThat event coincided with a visit from Trump, who was in Florida the same weekend to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.\n\nIt's not clear whether Trump attended any portion of the American Cancer Society's event, but he is known to pop in on fundraisers. In fact, Trump served as a co-chair for the American Cancer Society's annual event in 2014, the organization said.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic is a hospital group based in Cleveland, but it has a health center in South Florida. Proceeds from previous Mar-a-Lago galas have helped pay for medical equipment, nursing education and wheelchairs, according to the organization's website.\n\nA spokeswoman said the event raises about $1 million each year on average. She said the Cleveland Clinic has not yet decided on a date or new location for the 2018 gala. The 2017 gala was in February.\n\nThe clinic had received criticism for hosting the annual event at Mar-a-Lago. Earlier this year, protesters organized outside the Cleveland center to pressure the hospital to cancel the event, according to local media reports.\n\nAnd in July, nearly 1,700 people -- including doctors and medical students -- signed an open letter asking the clinic to hold the fundraiser somewhere else.\n\nHolding the fundraiser there \"symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare and cut billions of dollars in research funding from the National Institutes of Health budget,\" read the letter, which was posted on Medium.", {"id": "9836886", "categories": [{"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711295409", "source": {"id": "380", "title": "The Times of Israel", "uri": "timesofisrael.com"}, "url": "http://www.timesofisrael.com/american-friends-of-mda-moves-fundraiser-from-trumps-mar-a-lago/", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Florida -- A group raising money for Israeli emergency medical service Magen David Adom joined two other charities Thursday in shunning Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort, amid simmering anger over the US president's statements in the wake of a white supremacist rally in Virginia.\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom announced Thursday night it had decided not to hold its 2018 fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago, after the Cleveland Clinic and American Cancer Society also said they were canceling fundraisers at the glitzy Florida resort.\n\nThe group. which raises money for the MDA ambulance service in Israel, has been holding its annual gala at the resort since 2012.\n\nSome 600 people attended the Palm Beach Celebration of Life gala on February 26, 2017, where the group raised $1.3 million, according to the Palm Beach Post.\n\nIts spokesman, Erik Levis, gave no reason but said the decision came after \"considerable deliberation.\"\n\nHis statement noted the organization is \"apolitical.\"\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment. The managing director of Trump's properties in Florida, Bernd Lembcke, did not respond to a phone call seeking comment, either.\n\nThe president has drawn widespread and bipartisan criticism for his comments at a Trump Tower news conference where he insisted that \"both sides\" were to blame for violence at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville where a counterprotester was killed. The president dissolved two business councils after members who are CEOs began quitting.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic said in a statement that it decided not to hold its annual event at his Palm Beach resort after \"careful consideration\" of a number of issues. It didn't elaborate, but the Ohio-based hospital was already under pressure to shift venues.\n\nDoctors, nurses and medical students of the hospital had signed a public letter earlier this year objecting to Mar-a-Lago given President Trump's plans to cut funding of medical research and other policies.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic has held its annual fundraiser at the resort for eight years.\n\nCleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove was a member of one of those panels designed to advise the president on the economy and jobs.\n\nA few hours after the hospital pulled out, the American Cancer Society said it also planned to shift the venue of its annual fundraiser, called the 2018 Island of Palm Beach gala.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" spokeswoman Miriam Falco said in statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nFalco declined to elaborate.\n\nPresident-elect Donald Trump waves to members of the media after a meeting with admirals and generals from the Pentagon at Mar-a-Lago, in Palm Beach, Fla., Wednesday, Dec. 21, 2016. (AP/Andrew Harnik)\n\nThe gilded and glittering Mar-a-Lago has been a favorite spot for holding charity events and a money maker for the Trump Organization. Dubbed the Winter White House, it is one of the few places in the area that can hold a large crowd. Its 20,000 square-foot ballroom has massive archways and columns decorated in gold leaf.\n\nPalm Beach town records showed that 21 charities held events at Mar-a-Lago between last November and April, during the active social season.\n\nBut the resort has also become the site of protest by groups who oppose the president's policies and statements.\n\nThe American Red Cross faced pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the worldwide humanitarian relief organization was offering aid to those affected by Trump's moratorium on the US refugee program.\n\nThe organization did not immediately respond to questions about whether it plans to hold its fundraiser next year at the resort.\n\nSome charities contacted by The Associated Press said they had no plans to change venues.\n\nThe Kravis Center said it plans to keep its annual wine auction at the Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"The event has been held there for a number of years, and the folks supporting it want to continue to have it there,\" spokesman Gary Schweikhart said.\n\nThis March 11, 2016, file photo shows the Mar-A-Lago Club, owned by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, in Palm Beach, Florida. (AP Photo/Lynne Sladky, File)\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said in a statement that it plans to keep its annual ball at Mar-a-Lago because it is not a political event and no other venues in town can accommodate 700 guests.\n\nThe event raised $700,000 this year, according to town records, with the proceeds used to buy equipment for the Palm Beach Police Department, help its officers and families when they are in need, and provide scholarships for officers' children. The foundation declined further comment.\n\nLaurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, said in an email that \"each organization should examine their mission statements to ensure that any fundraising efforts are not compromising their efforts.\"\n\nShe said she is not implying that charities should shun Trump.\n\nTimes of Israel staff contributed to this report.", {"id": "9989530", "categories": [{"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711697086", "source": {"id": "3701", "title": "publicradiotulsa.org", "uri": "publicradiotulsa.org"}, "url": "http://publicradiotulsa.org/post/charities-pull-fundraisers-planned-trumps-mar-lago", "body": "On Friday, three well-known charities -- the American Red Cross, the Salvation Army and Susan G. Komen -- announced they are canceling plans for fundraising events at President Trump's Palm Beach country club, Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThe three joined a growing list of nonprofits that have severed ties with the exclusive, Trump-owned resort. Others include the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society.\n\nThe cancellations come in the wake of Trump's controversial comments made earlier this week when he said that \"both sides were to blame\" for last weekend's deadly violence involving white supremacists in Charlottesville, Va.\n\nTrump has been under heavy criticism all week for his remarks, which prompted many corporate leaders to bail out of White House advisory boards. So many CEOs resigned that the president responded by disbanding three committees -- one focused on shaping business strategy, another on boosting manufacturing and third on improving infrastructure.\n\nAfter the CEOs started refusing to work with the president, pressure increased on charities to give up their annual trips to Mar-a-Lago for galas.\n\nFor example, Cleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove had served on one of the disbanded business councils. And a day after that dismantling happened, the hospital announced that \"after careful consideration,\" Cleveland Clinic would not hold its 2018 event at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nEarlier this year, despite a petition drive by doctors and medical students, the hospital had refused to cancel its fundraiser there. When medical students and other groups renewed the push recently, Cleveland Clinic remained firm, saying Mar-a-Lago is located in the heart of one of the nation's most affluent communities and met its needs.\n\nNow, it does not.\n\nThe American Red Cross said in its statement that it must provide \"assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions.\"\n\nThe charity's connection with the president's club \"has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" it said.\n\nThe Salvation Army issued a similar statement, saying its event at Mar-a-Lago helped raise money for disaster victims and the homeless. \"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event,\" the group says, \"we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\nSusan G. Komen, a charity that invests in breast cancer research, confirmed it is also withdrawing from Mar-a-Lago and is seeking a new venue for its fundraising event.\n\nThe rash of high-profile cancellations has created something of a scramble in Palm Beach as charities look for other suitable venues. The Palm Beach Post says other nearby hotels and the Palm Beach County Convention Center are hearing from interested groups.\n\nFor Trump, the cancellations will mean a significant loss of income, unless the staff at Mar-a-Lago finds new customers who want to book a 20,000-square-foot ballroom embellished with 24-karat gold leafing, modeled, as Trump told Florida Design magazine, after Versailles.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T23:22:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3369442", "time": "23:22:00", "lang":
