{"id": "9788939", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 3, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical Specialties", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical_Specialties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 239, "label": "dmoz/Business/Biotechnology and Pharmaceuticals/Pharmaceuticals", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Biotechnology_and_Pharmaceuticals/Pharmaceuticals", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711147715", "source": {"id": "402", "title": "The Huffington Post", "uri": "huffingtonpost.com"}, "url": "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/american-cancer-cleveland-clinic-mar-a-lago_us_5995dd24e4b01f6e801ce093", "body": "The two organizations are the latest to distance themselves from the president following backlash over his response to the Charlottesville violence.\n\nTwo major nonprofit organizations are pulling the plug on their plans to host upcoming events at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club amid backlash over his controversial response to the deadly clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, a nonprofit medical center, announced its decision to cancel hosting its annual charity gala at the Palm Beach, Florida, resort in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018,\" the statement said. \"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nThe annual event, which typically raises around $1 million and is attended by roughly 500 people, had been scheduled to take place on Feb. 24, 2018 and would have marked eight years in a row at the location.\n\nProceeds from the fundraiser benefit Cleveland Clinic Florida, a hospital in Weston, according to Eileen Sheil, executive director of communications at Cleveland Clinic.\n\nSheil told HuffPost there were \"a variety of reasons\" the clinic decided to drop Mar-a-Lago, but wouldn't elaborate much further.\n\n\"I think the community really was asking us to not have it there,\" Sheil said, adding that the decision was made Thursday morning.\n\nThe clinic is currently looking into other locations to host the gala.\n\nHours after Cleveland Clinic announced their plans to scrap their planned event, the American Cancer Society followed suit.\n\nThe nationwide health organization confirmed it is seeking a new venue to host its Island of Palm Beach gala on Feb. 22, 2018 in a statement to HuffPost. The organization has hosted the event at Mar-a-Lago since 2007.\n\n\"When we chose to hold our 2018 event and related dinner at Mar-a-Lago, we selected the venue based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements,\" the statement said.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the statement continued. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nThe American Cancer Society and Cleveland Clinic are just the latest organizations to distance themselves from Trump following nearly a week of withering criticism over his response to a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville that left one dead and dozens injured.\n\nTrump initially blamed \"many sides\" for hatred and bigotry on Saturday, but eventually specifically condemned white supremacist groups after facing harsh criticism. But the president walked back some of his strong language on Tuesday by defending those who participated in the white nationalist rally and accusing counterprotesters -- whom he referred to as the \"alt-left\" -- of also acting violently.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the chief executive of Cleveland Clinic was a member of the Strategic and Policy Forum, one of Trump's two business advisory councils that disbanded this week in the wake of Trump's explosive comments.\n\nOn Monday, Kenneth Fraizer, CEO of Merck & Co., stepped down from Trump's American Manufacturing Council. One by one, top business executives including, Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank and Intel CEO Brian Krzanich, followed in Fraizer's footsteps. As members of Trump's Strategic and Policy Forum began to resign from the group on Wednesday, Trump announced that he was \"ending both\" councils to alleviate \"pressure\" on its members.\n\nLaurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, told the Palm Beach Post that organizations should stop holding charity events at the Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"If you have a conscience, you're really condoning bad behavior by continuing to be there,\" Baker said. \"Many say it's the dollars (raised at the events) that count. Yes. But the integrity of any organization rests on their sound decisions and stewardship.\"\n\nTrump Organization representatives did not immediately respond to HuffPost's multiple requests for comment. A receptionist for Mar-a-Lago said she was told to direct phone calls to the White House. A White House spokeswoman declined to comment on the cancelled events.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:40:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 929, "textStart": 916, "date": "2018-02-24", "amb": false}, {"id": "9806576", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 2, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 3, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical Specialties", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical_Specialties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 370, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Facilities", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Facilities", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711201770", "source": {"id": "726", "title": "SunSentinel", "uri": "sun-sentinel.com"}, "url": "http://www.sun-sentinel.com/opinion/fl-op-editorial-cleveland-clinic-trump-20170816-story.html", "body": "The prestigious Cleveland Clinic did the right thing Thursday by dropping plans to hold its annual fundraising ball at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club.\n\nThe question is, why did it take so long?\n\nA hospital whose guiding principal is \"putting the patient's needs first\" shouldn't be putting money in the pocket of a president trying to repeal the Affordable Care Act, cut funding for medical research and block certain foreign doctors from training here.\n\nDespite the president pushing to repeal Obamacare, even without a replacement, the Cleveland Clinic had been sticking with plans to hold its glitzy fundraiser at Trump's Palm Beach estate.\n\nYet staying at Mar-a-Lago would have signaled support for Trump's efforts to end a program that helps millions of people get health care, while also enriching his business.\n\nA coalition of doctors, nurses, medical students and others had petitioned the Ohio-based hospital system - which boasts a network of South Florida facilities from Weston to Palm Beach Gardens - to pick a different venue.\n\nThe Breakers, the Flagler Museum and the Beach Club all host A-list Palm Beach soirees. According to the Palm Beach Daily News, the Bascom Palmer Eye Institute and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute had already moved their upcoming fundraisers to other Palm Beach venues after facing controversy for using Mar-a-Lago in the past.\n\nBut for months, the Cleveland Clinic said it was sticking with Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThat changed Thursday, after continued criticism of Trump's response to white supremacist and neo-Nazi demonstrations in Charlottesville, Va. and the violence that followed.\n\nIt's well known that CEO Toby Cosgrove has enjoyed a good relationship with the president. In the early days of his administration, Trump asked Cosgrove to lead the Department of Veterans Affairs. Cosgrove turned him down, though he did take a position on the president's business advisory board. And as several CEOs stepped down from the board in reaction to past Trump controversies -- including the travel ban and the Paris Accord -- Cosgrove opted to stay.\n\nThen this week, criticism of Trump's comments about finding \"many sides\" to blame for the violence in Charlottesville brought more departures, prompting Trump to tweet that he was disbanding the group.\n\nWhy did Cosgrove hang on so long?\n\n\"Dr. Cosgrove believes that it's important to be able to provide input at the highest level of government on health care matters,\" spokeswoman Eileen Sheil last week told The Plain Dealer of Cleveland.\n\nBut how has his \"input\" worked out?\n\nTrump continues to push for undoing the Affordable Care Act, even without a replacement. If Trump succeeds, 18 million people could lose health care coverage in the first year, according to the Congressional Budget Office.\n\nTrump wants to cut the budget for the National Institutes of Health by almost $6 billion -- money that funds the kind of medical research that's made the clinic famous.\n\nAnd Trump's first attempt at a travel ban -- targeting seven predominantly Muslim countries -- temporarily blocked a Cleveland Clinic doctor of Sudanese descent from coming home from a trip to Saudi Arabia.\n\nLast year, Cleveland Clinic staff similarly raised objections to the gala at Mar-a-Lago, but the clinic said the contract was already signed, it was too late.\n\nFor eight years, the clinic has held its fundraising galas at Mar-a-Lago, raising between $700,000 and $1 million each year. The money helps pay for equipment and expanded programs at its Florida facilities, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe fundraiser, scheduled for Feb. 25, focuses on cardiology equipment and services \"to bring world-class cardiology care to our community,\" its website says. Now it's looking for a new location.\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018,\" the hospital system said in a statement released Thursday, the Plain Dealer reported. \"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nAll along, the Cleveland Clinic argued its party location was about fundraising success, not making a political statement.\n\nBut Mar-a-Lago is a political venue because of its ties to Trump.\n\nBy either choosing to do business there or choosing to go somewhere else, the Cleveland Clinic couldn't avoid making a political statement.\n\nLeaving Mar-a-Lago could end up costing the clinic donations from Trump supporters, just as sticking with Mar-a-Lago could have scared away other potential donors.You've got to believe hospital leaders took that equation into account.\n\nBut keeping its party at Mar-a-Lago could have left this renowned medical institution paying a bigger long-term price with lost employees, patients and community support.\n\nCosgrove is retiring after 13 years of leading Cleveland Clinic. His work includes expanding the hospital's reach in other countries, reducing the number of employees to cut costs and ushering in an economic rebound last year - which was the hospital's best financial year ever, according to the Plain Dealer. It's good that he didn't mar his legacy by sticking too close to Trump.\n\nMoving the party away from Mar-a-Lago was the right call for the Cleveland Clinic, even if it came too late.\n\nEditorials are the opinion of the Sun Sentinel Editorial Board and written by one of its members or a designee. The Editorial Board consists of Editorial Page Editor Rosemary O'Hara, Andy Reid, Elana Simms, Gary Stein and Editor-in-Chief Howard Saltz.\n\nEditorials are the opinion of the Sun Sentinel Editorial Board and written by one of its members or a designee. The Editorial Board consists of Editorial Page Editor Rosemary O'Hara, Elana Simms, Gary Stein, Andy Reid and Editor-in-Chief Howard Saltz.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:17:00Z", "extractedDates": {"id": "9748394", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 2, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 3, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical Specialties", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical_Specialties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711034183", "source": {"id": "104", "title": "Washington Post", "uri": "washingtonpost.com"}, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/cleveland-clinic-cancels-plans-for-gala-at-president-trumps-mar-a-lago/2017/08/17/a412f596-8369-11e7-b359-15a3617c767b_story.html", "body": "The Cleveland Clinic has abruptly canceled its plans to host a charity gala at President Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club next year, marking one of the Palm Beach club's biggest defections since Trump's inauguration.\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018,\" the medical center said in a statement Thursday. \"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nCompany spokeswoman Eileen Sheil told The Post on Thursday that \"there were a variety of factors\" behind the cancellation, but she added, \"We're not elaborating.\"\n\nTrump Organization officials did not immediately respond.\n\nThough the company had faced increasing pressure to call off its Mar-a-Lago event, the company had still intended to host its ninth gala there as recently as last week, Sheil told The Post then. She said the event was not political and had raised roughly $1 million a year toward buying medical equipment.\n\n\"Our donors really enjoy that venue,\" Sheil said last week. \"They've had it there eight years in a row, long before the election.\"\n\n[The banquet business was booming at Mar-a-Lago. Then Trump became president.]\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic's chief executive, Toby Cosgrove, was among the business leaders on the president's Manufacturing Council who did not resign before the group disbanded on Wednesday.\n\nExecutives said they were concerned by Trump's comments Tuesday equating the actions of white supremacists and neo-Nazis with protesters during a violent weekend in Charlottesville. Shortly after the group decided to dissolve, Trump said on Twitter that he would end the council \"rather than putting pressure on the busi\u00adness\u00adpeo\u00adple.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic is only the latest medical group to swear off an event at the president's club. The Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society in New York and Bascom Palmer Eye Institute in Miami have all announced in recent months that they would choose other venues.\n\nIt's unclear how much the Cleveland Clinic's move could cost Mar-a-Lago. Similar-sized events brought in fees of between $100,000 and $275,000.\n\nThe 2017-2018 season looks like it will be the slowest period for Mar-a-Lago events in at least a decade, a Washington Post analysis found.\n\n[At Mar-a-Lago, the star power of the presidency helps charities -- and Trump -- make more money]\n\nThe hospital system has faced growing pressure for months to end its relationship with the president's private club. More than 1,600 people, including doctors and health professionals, signed a letter to the company last month, urging it to cancel the Mar-a-Lago booking, saying the event \"symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic was ranked the nation's second-best hospital this month by U.S. News & World Report, which gave top honors to its urology, cardiology and heart surgery units.\n\nNearly 550 people visited the hospital's February fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago, where the theme was \"Reflections of Versailles.\"\n\nDavid Fahrenthold contributed to this report.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:57:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "details": {"gpCnt": {"id": "9798043", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1154, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Events", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Events", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711173970", "source": {"id": "963", "title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted.ap.org"}, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_TRUMP_RESORTS_CHARITIES?SITE=COCOL&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- President Donald Trump's comments about the white nationalist rally last weekend are hurting not just his political standing, but his pocketbook.\n\nThree charities announced Thursday that they were canceling fundraisers at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort, a sign the president's business is starting to suffer backlash from his comments Tuesday about the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic said in a statement that it decided not to hold its annual event at his Palm Beach resort after \"careful consideration\" of a number of issues. It didn't elaborate, but the Ohio-based hospital was already under pressure to shift venues.\n\nDoctors, nurses and medical students of the hospital had signed a public letter earlier this year objecting to Mar-a-Lago given President Trump's plans to cut funding of medical research and other policies.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic has held its annual fundraiser at the resort for eight years.\n\nA few hours after the hospital pulled out, the American Cancer Society said it also planned to shift the venue of its annual fundraiser, called the 2018 Island of Palm Beach gala.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" spokeswoman Miriam Falco said in statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nFalco declined to elaborate.\n\nLate Thursday, the American Friends of Magen David Adom announced it had decided not to hold its 2018 fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago. The group, which raises money for an ambulance service in Israel, has been holding its annual gala at the resort since 2012.\n\nIts spokesman, Erik Levis, gave no reason but said the decision came after \"considerable deliberation.\" His statement noted the organization is \"apolitical.\"\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment. The managing director of Trump's properties in Florida, Bernd Lembcke, did not respond to a phone call seeking comment, either.\n\nThe president has drawn widespread and bipartisan criticism for his comments at a Trump Tower news conference where he insisted that \"both sides\" were to blame for violence at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville where a counterprotester was killed. The president dissolved two business councils after members who are CEOs began quitting.\n\nCleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove was a member of one of those panels designed to advise the president on the economy and jobs.\n\nThe gilded and glittering Mar-a-Lago has been a favorite spot for holding charity events and a money maker for the Trump Organization. Dubbed the Winter White House, it is one of the few places in the area that can hold a large crowd. Its 20,000 square-foot ballroom has massive archways and columns decorated in gold leaf.\n\nPalm Beach town records showed that 21 charities held events at Mar-a-Lago between last November and April, during the active social season.\n\nBut the resort has also become the site of protest by groups who oppose the president's policies and statements.\n\nThe American Red Cross faced pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the worldwide humanitarian relief organization was offering aid to those affected by Trump's moratorium on the U.S. refugee program.\n\nThe organization did not immediately respond to questions about whether it plans to hold its fundraiser next year at the resort.\n\nSome charities contacted by The Associated Press said they had no plans to change venues.\n\nThe Kravis Center said it plans to keep its annual wine auction at the Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"The event has been held there for a number of years, and the folks supporting it want to continue to have it there,\" spokesman Gary Schweikhart said.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said in a statement that it plans to keep its annual ball at Mar-a-Lago because it is not a political event and no other venues in town can accommodate 700 guests.\n\nThe event raised $700,000 this year, according to town records, with the proceeds used to buy equipment for the Palm Beach Police Department, help its officers and families when they are in need, and provide scholarships for officers' children. The foundation declined further comment.\n\nLaurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, said in an email that \"each organization should examine their mission statements to ensure that any fundraising efforts are not compromising their efforts.\"\n\nShe said she is not implying that charities should shun Trump.\n\n---\n\nCondon reported from New York and Smyth from {"id": "9967930", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 298, "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711635391", "source": {"id": "2072", "title": "NOLA.com", "uri": "nola.com"}, "url": "http://www.nola.com/national_politics/2017/08/red_cross_salvation_army_other.html", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- The American Red Cross and the Salvation Army became the latest charitable organizations Friday to abandon plans for events at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort.\n\nThey're among several philanthropic groups canceling plans at the resort as pressure mounts from business leaders over the president's comments about violence in Charlottesville, Va.\n\nA spokeswoman for the Salvation Army told the Sun Sentinel on Friday that it will not host its Holiday Snow Ball in Palm Beach event at Mar-a-Lago, citing a shifting national conversation. The Salvation Army relies \"heavily on fundraising events\" like the ball as part of helping those in need, the group said in a statement.\n\n\"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\nThe American Red Cross also nixed plans to host an annual fundraising event at the resort calling it a \"source of controversy and pain\" for volunteers, employees and staff.\n\n\"We believe this action will allow us to continue to put the focus on our lifesaving mission and the people we serve,\" according to a statement. \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nDonald Trump has owned Mar-a-Lago, the Palm Beach estate built by cereal heiress Marjorie Merriweather Post, since the 1980s. Trump turned it into a private club and is using it as his Weekend White House.\n\nOn Thursday, three large funding organizations -- the American Cancer Society, Cleveland Clinic and American Friends of Magen David Adom -- pulled their events.\n\nThe American Cancer Society's event, held at Trump's Palm Beach estate for 11 years, nets about $450,000 for the organization, according to the American Cancer Society's local office.\n\nThe organization has started looking for another site for the fundraiser. It was held at Mar-a-Lago because of costs, venue requirements and other factors, according to the statement.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic didn't give a reason for its decision. Before changing course, Cleveland Clinic spokeswoman Eileen Sheil had said last week that the hospital system's event was not political. Donors and executives had discussed it and agreed Mar-a-Lago met the organization's needs, she said.\n\nThe fundraiser has raised $700,000 to $1 million annually to expand programs and purchase equipment for the hospital system's Florida facility. It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the past eight years.\n\nTwo other organizations said Friday that their events would proceed as scheduled.\n\nA spokesman for The Kravis Center for the Performing Arts said that as of Thursday afternoon, officials had not changed their minds. \"The event has been held there for a number of years, and the people who are regulars at the event want to keep it there,\" said Gary Schweikhart, spokesman for the Kravis Center.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said it, too, will stay the course. \"The ball typically attracts 700 people, and it's the only venue in Palm Beach that will accommodate a crowd of that size,\" according to a statement issued from the foundation, which supports Palm Beach Police Department employees.", "dateTime": Carlos Barria/Reuters\n\nThree charities have pulled their fundraising events from President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Florida, in the wake of his response to a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville Virginia.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, American Cancer Society, and American Friends of Magen David Adom all said they wouldn't hold their 2018 galas at the resort. The organization had held their annual events at Mar-a-Lago for a number of years.\n\nThe decisions to pull out of Mar-a-Lago come after a week of turbulent comments from the president regarding the white-supremacist protests that took place in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations,\" the American Cancer Society said in a statement.\n\nThe organizations join a growing group of organizations and business leaders who have distanced themselves from the president after the events in Charlottesville. On Wednesday, the president said he would disband his two business councils, after a number of members of his manufacturing council started to drop out and his strategy and policy council had plans to dissolve the group.\n\nSome groups that have hosted their fundraising galas at Mar-a-Lago in the past, including the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, had already decided not to return to the resort before this week. Washington Post reporter David Fahrenthold reports that other major charities, including the American Red Cross and Susan G. The organization had held their annual events at Mar-a-Lago for a number of years.\n\nThe decisions to pull out of Mar-a-Lago come after a week of turbulent comments from the president regarding the white-supremacist protests that took place in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nRELATED: A look at Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations,\" the American Cancer Society said in a statement.\n\nThe organizations join a growing group of organizations and business leaders who have distanced themselves from the president after the events in Charlottesville. On Wednesday, the president said he would disband his two business councils, after a number of members of his manufacturing council started to drop out and his strategy and policy council had plans to dissolve the group.\n\nSome groups that have hosted their fundraising galas at Mar-a-Lago in the past, including the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, had already decided not to return to the resort before this week. Washington Post reporter David Fahrenthold reports that other major charities, including the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen have said in the past that they still have plans to hold their events at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThe events can yield $100,000 to $275,000 for the resort, the Post has reported.\n\nNOW WATCH: 'I'm used {"id": "9806623", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711201765", "source": {"id": "7580", "title": "NECN", "uri": "necn.com"}, "url": "http://www.necn.com/news/national-international/Cleveland-Clinic-Will-Pull-Event-From-Mar-a-Lago-Resort-440946753.html", "body": "Receive the latest national-international updates in your inbox\n\nPresident Donald Trump's comments about the white nationalist rally last weekend are hurting not just his political standing, but his pocketbook.\n\nThree charities announced Thursday that they were canceling fundraisers at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort, a sign the president's business is starting to suffer backlash from his comments Tuesday about the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic said in a statement that it decided not to hold its annual event at his Palm Beach resort after \"careful consideration\" of a number of issues. It didn't elaborate, but the Ohio-based hospital was already under pressure to shift venues.\n\nDoctors, nurses and medical students of the hospital had signed a public letter earlier this year objecting to Mar-a-Lago given President Trump's plans to cut funding of medical research and other policies.\n\nFatalities Confirmed After Van Hits People in Barcelona\n\nA white van jumped the sidewalk in Barcelona's Las Ramblas district on Aug. 17, 2017. Police say 13 people have been killed and more than 100 injured in this terrorist attack. The area is one of the city's top tourist destinations.\n\n(Published 5 hours ago)\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic has held its annual fundraiser at the resort for eight years.\n\nA few hours after the hospital pulled out, the American Cancer Society said it also planned to shift the venue of its annual fundraiser, called the 2018 Island of Palm Beach gala.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" spokeswoman Miriam Falco said in statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nDevelopingSpanish Police Kill 4 Terror Suspects South of Barcelona\n\nFalco declined to elaborate.\n\nLate Thursday, the American Friends of Magen David Adom announced it had decided not to hold its 2018 fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago. The group, which raises money for an ambulance service in Israel, has been holding its annual gala at the resort since 2012.\n\nIts spokesman, Erik Levis, gave no reason but said the decision came after \"considerable deliberation.\" His statement noted the organization is \"apolitical.\"\n\nPhotos: Deadly Barcelona Van Terror AttackJosep Lago/AFP/Getty Images\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment. The managing director of Trump's properties in Florida, Bernd Lembcke, did not respond to a phone call seeking comment, either.\n\nThe president has drawn widespread and bipartisan criticism for his comments at a Trump Tower news conference where he insisted that \"both sides\" were to blame for violence at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville where a counterprotester was killed. The president dissolved two business councils after members who are CEOs began quitting.\n\nCleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove was a member of one of those panels designed to advise the president on the economy and jobs.\n\nAnti-Hate Groups Seize on Virginia as Teachable Moment\n\nThe gilded and glittering Mar-a-Lago has been a favorite spot for holding charity events and a money maker for the Trump Organization. Dubbed the Winter White House, it is one of the few places in the area that can hold a large crowd. Its 20,000 square-foot ballroom has massive archways and columns decorated in gold leaf.\n\nPalm Beach town records showed that 21 charities held events at Mar-a-Lago between last November and April, during the active social season.\n\nBut the resort has also become the site of protest by groups who oppose the president's policies and statements.\n\nDems, GOP Condemn Trump for 'Both Sides' Blame Game\n\nLawmakers and business leaders from both sides of the aisle are criticizing President Donald Trump's comments blaming \"both sides\" for the violence that erupted in Charlottesville, Virginia, over the weekend, with three dead and dozens more injured. This, as hundreds gathered to mourn at the University of Virginia Wednesday night.\n\n(Published Thursday, Aug. 17, 2017)\n\nThe American Red Cross faced pushback in January, when demonstrators rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the worldwide humanitarian relief organization was offering aid to those affected by Trump's moratorium on the U.S. refugee program.\n\nThe organization did not immediately respond to questions about whether it plans to hold its fundraiser next year at the resort.\n\nSome charities contacted by The Associated Press said they had no plans to change venues.\n\nConfederate Monuments Removed or Vandalized Across US\n\nThe Kravis Center said it plans to keep its annual wine auction at the Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"The event has been held there for a number of years, and the folks supporting it want to continue to have it there,\" spokesman Gary Schweikhart said.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said in a statement that it plans to keep its annual ball at Mar-a-Lago because it is not a political event and no other venues in town can accommodate 700 guests.\n\nTrump Says 'Fixing the Inner Cities' Is a Priority\n\nPresident Donald J. Trump told reporters on Tuesday that \"fixing the inner cities\" is a priority for his administration.\n\n(Published Wednesday, Aug. 16, 2017)\n\nThe event raised $700,000 this year, according to town records, with the proceeds used to buy equipment for the Palm Beach Police Department, help its officers and families when they are in need, and provide scholarships for officers' children. The foundation declined further comment.\n\nLaurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, said in an email that \"each organization should examine their mission statements to ensure that any fundraising efforts are not compromising their efforts.\"\n\nShe said she is not implying that charities should shun Trump.\n\nVideo'The Moment I Hoped Would Never Come': Oakland Nurse Trump's response to the white supremacist violence and murder in Charlottesville this past weekend on Thursday cost him an estimated $200,000 to $550,000 as two national non-profits canceled plans to hold fundraisers at his Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach.\n\nThe American Cancer Society and the Cleveland Clinic on Thursday announced the cancellations, making clear they are tied to Trump's comments on white supremacism, according to The Washington Post.\n\n\"The cancellations will hit one of the biggest moneymakers for what Trump calls the 'winter White House,' where similar-sized events have often earned the club between $100,000 and $275,000 a piece,\" the Post reports.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the American Cancer Society said, according to Politico. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic issued a more terse statement.\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018,\" the medical group said in a statement. \"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nIn June the Post reported \"seven nonprofit organizations -- all repeat customers of the president's club -- have announced their decisions to avoid Mar-a-Lago next winter during the social season, when Palm Beach life revolves around lavish parties for charity.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:17:00Z", It did not give a reason for its cancellation. The announcement was reported earlier Thursday by the Cleveland Plain Dealer.\n\nA few hours after the Cleveland Clinic's announcement, the American Cancer Society followed suit.\n\nThe nonprofit said in a statement that it had planned to host its 2018 gala at Mar-a-Lago \"based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements.\" But the organization said \"it has become increasingly clear\" that hosting its fundraiser on Trump-owned property presents a \"challenge\" to its values.\n\nThe American Cancer Society -- which has hosted the annual event at Mar-a-Lago for at least the past decade -- has not yet selected another venue. The decision was reported earlier by the Palm Beach Post.\n\nMar-a-Lago declined comment. The Trump Organization did not immediately respond to a message.\n\nThe health organization last hosted its gala in Trump's Palm Beach club in February of this year.\n\nThat event coincided with a visit from Trump, who was in Florida the same weekend to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.\n\nIt's not clear whether Trump attended any portion of the American Cancer Society's event, but he is known to pop in on fundraisers. In fact, Trump served as a co-chair for the American Cancer Society's annual event in 2014, the organization said.\n\nOn Thursday, CNNMoney reached out to all the organizations that have announced plans to hold events at Mar-a-Lago in the coming months. The American Friends of Magen David Adom, a group that supports Israel's national ambulance, blood-services, and disaster-relief organization, confirmed it too has decided to move its annual gala to another location.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago,\" spokesperson Erik Levis said in a statement.\n\nThe event was scheduled to take place at Mar-a-Lago on February 25, 2018.\n\nOnly one other organization, Kravis Center for the Performing Arts, responded to CNNMoney's inquiries.\n\nThat group confirmed it will host a wine auction at the club on February 1.\n\n- An earlier version of this story misidentified the location of the American {"id": "9967457", "categories": [{"id": 253, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Christianity", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Christianity", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711634212", "source": {"id": "162", "title": "Beaumont Enterprise", "uri": "beaumontenterprise.com"}, "url": "http://www.beaumontenterprise.com/technology/businessinsider/article/3-charities-just-dropped-Trump-s-Mar-a-Lago-for-11942370.php", "body": "Four charities have pulled their fundraising events from President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Florida, in the wake of his response to a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, American Cancer Society, and American Friends of Magen David Adom all said they wouldn't hold their 2018 galas at the resort on Thursday. The organizations had held their annual events at Mar-a-Lago for a number of years.\n\nOn Friday, the American Red Cross and the Salvation Army said they would not host its event at Mar-a-Lago either. The Red Cross said in a statement that \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters.\"\n\nThe decisions to pull out of Mar-a-Lago come after a week of turbulent comments from the president regarding the white-supremacist protests that took place in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations,\" the American Cancer Society said in a statement.\n\nThe Salvation Army said its decision to no longer have its Holiday Snow Ball at the Mar-A-Lago was because the location was shifting the subject away from the organization's mission.\n\n\"The Salvation Army relies heavily on fundraising events like The Holiday Snow Ball in Palm Beach to further our mission of helping those in need through a range of social services including food for the hungry, relief for disaster victims, clothing and shelter for the homeless, and opportunities for the underprivileged. Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\nThe organizations join a growing group of organizations and business leaders who have distanced themselves from the president after the events in Charlottesville. On Wednesday, the president said he would disband his two business councils, after a number of members of his manufacturing council started to drop out and his strategy and policy council had plans to dissolve the group.\n\nSome groups that have hosted their fundraising galas at Mar-a-Lago in the past, including the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, had already decided not to return to the resort before this week. Washington Post reporter David Fahrenthold reports that other major charities, including Susan G. Komen and the Salvation Army, have said in the past that they still have plans to hold their events at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThe events can yield $100,000 to $275,000 for the resort, the Post has reported.\n\nJoin the conversation about this story \"\n\nNOW WATCH: A drone captured shocking footage of inequality in Mexico City and South Africa\n\nSee Also:", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T20:01:00Z", "http://globalnews.ca/news/3680190/charities-are-cancelling-fundraising-events-at-mar-a-lago-following-trumps-charlottesville-comments/", "body": "Three fundraising giants -- the American Cancer Society, the Cleveland Clinic and the American Friends of Magen David Adom -- announced Thursday that they would cancel gala events scheduled to take place at U.S. President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort later this year and in 2018.\n\nThe move signals a negative response to Trump's recent remarks on the violence at last weekend's Charlottesville, Va., protests.\n\nWATCH BELOW: President Donald Trump comments on Charlottesville protests\n\nDonald Trump doubles down on his original comments on Charlottesville 05:21 Donald Trump doubles down on his original comments on Charlottesville 17:09 Donald Trump full news conference on Charlottesville response 01:30 Fallout escalating for Donald Trump over Charlottesville response 00:34 Theresa May says Donald Trump must condemn dangerous right-wing groups 01:18 Donald Trump returns to New York amid controversy over Charlottesville response\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the American Cancer Society said in a statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nStory continues below\n\nAlthough neither the American Friends of Magen David Adom (a group that raises funds for an ambulance service in Isreal) nor the Cleveland Clinic gave explicit reasons for cancelling their events, the latter charity had been receiving mounting pressure from the medical community not to hold any fundraising events at the luxury Palm Springs resort.\n\nEarlier this year, 1,700 nurses, physicians and medical students signed an open letter demanding the Cleveland Clinic move their February 2016 event from Mar-a-Lago. It deemed the resort \"unacceptable because it symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare and cut billions of dollars in research funding from the National Institutes of Health budget.\"\n\nDespite the outcry, the fundraising event was still held at Mar-a-Lago on Feb. 25. The recent decision to move their 2018 event from the resort was declared a win.\n\nREAD MORE: SNL Weekend Update: Tina Fey goes on cake-fueled rant, founding fathers address Trump comments\n\n\"Our campaign declared victory, but the fight for health justice continues on many fronts, and we will work to confront them together,\" the letter stated.\n\nIn recent months, a number of other charitable groups who held annual events at Mar-a-Lago have stated that they will find alternate venues for upcoming fundraisers, citing security issues and political differences as reasons. They include the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society in New York, and the Bascom Palmer Eye Institute in Miami.\n\nLaurel Baker, head of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, called Mar-a-Lago a \"morally reprehensible\" business on Thursday, according to the Washington Post, and advised charities to review their mission statements.\n\n\"Can you honestly say having an event at Mar-a-Lago, given all that has transpired, is the best stewardship of your efforts?\"\n\nDespite this recent spate of charities who have pulled their events from the resort, some who were contacted by the Associated Press, said they will still hold future fundraising events there.\n\nKravis Centre spokesperson Gary Schweikhart said \"the folks supporting\" the performing arts centre's annual wine auction want to have it there. And the Palm Beach Police Foundation said it will hold its annual ball at Mar-a-Lago. It's not clear where the event is moving.\n\nOn the Preservation Foundation's official Facebook and Twitter accounts, a statement read, \"given the current environment surrounding Mar-a-Lago, we have made the decision to move our annual dinner dance.\"\n\nUPDATED: Here's a list of who's leaving Mar-a-Lago\n\nRELATED: Complains aside, charities plan to stick with Mar-a-Lago\n\nNo one at the Foundation could be reached for comment.\n\nLater Saturday, H.O.W. \"Hearing the Ovarian Cancer Whisper,\" published a statement on their Facebook page that read, \"After careful consideration H.O.W. \"Hearing the Ovarian Cancer Whisper\" has changed its venue for our annual \"Time is of the Essence Luncheon\" from Mar A Lago with a return to our roots at the historically beautiful Flagler Museum.\n\n\"For us, this event is about raising money for research, educational programs, and financial assistance for women undergoing treatment. We are committed to our mission therefore, this is not a political statement made by H.O.W.\"\n\nThe move by the two organizations Saturday brings to 10 the number of nonprofits pulling an event from Mar-a-Lago since the president's controversial news conference Tuesday at Trump Tower on the deadly violence in Charlottesville, Va., last week.\n\nOn Friday, five additional philanthropic organizations -- Susan G. Komen, the International Red Cross, The Salvation Army, Austin Association of Palm Beach County and Big Dog Ranch -- moved events from Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, American Cancer Society and the American Friends of Magen David Adom, an organization supporting Israel disaster relief programs have also changed venues for their events.\n\nThe Raymond F. Kravis Center was scheduled to hold board meetings this weekend to discuss possibly moving The Palm Beach Wine Auction from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"We have received concerns about this event being at Mar-a-Lago,\" Judy Spelling, the center's CEO, said in an email to The Palm Beach Post. \"We have a process to address such issues and we are currently engaged in that process. {"id": "10085046", "categories": [{"id": 399, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Golf/Tournaments and Events", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Golf/Tournaments_and_Events", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1145, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Event Planning and Production", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Event_Planning_and_Production", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711971411", "source": {"id": "1784", "title": "NYMag", "uri": "nymag.com"}, "url": "http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/08/charities-are-pulling-their-events-from-trumps-mar-a-lago.html", "body": "Continuing a trend of mass exodus from the orbit -- or perceived orbit -- of President Trump in the aftermath of the violence in Charlottesville, eight charities have decided to move their fundraising events from Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Florida over the past few days. The Palm Beach Post reports that on Friday, Susan B. Komen, The Salvation Army, International Red Cross, Autism Association of Palm Beach County, and Big Dog Ranch Rescue all announced they wouldn't hold their planned events at the club this coming winter, joining the Cleveland Clinic, American Cancer Society, and American Friends of Magen David Adom (which supports disaster relief in Israel), who all cancelled their Mar-a-Lago events on Thursday. As with most of the CEOs who quickly backed away from Trump this week, it seems that the president's unhinged Tuesday press conference was what set events in motion.\n\nSpeaking to reporters at that now-infamous event, the combative president doubled down on his previous assertion that white supremacists were not the only people at fault for the violence that erupted at a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville last Saturday -- violence which resulted in the death of 32-year-old Heather Heyer and injuries to dozens of others.\n\nThe Palm Beach Daily News adds that a total of 16 charities who held events at Mar-a-Lago over the past year have now bailed on the club in recent months or days. Only five charities, including three local Palm Beach organizations, have committed to still holding their events at Mar-a-Lago. Another four charities with events planned at the club either haven't decided what to do, or haven't yet responded to media inquiries. The executive director of the Palm Peach Chamber of Commerce, Laurel Baker, is urging charitable organizations trying to stick with Mar-a-Lago to reconsider, warning them that deep-pocket donors \"have a conscience.\"\n\nThere have also been calls on social media to boycott charities that were still planning events at the property, which has likely added to the pressure.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations,\" the American Cancer Society explained when announcing that it was moving the two upcoming events it had originally planned to hold at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nAt least some of the organizations appeared to have relationships with members of the Trump family. President Trump has repeatedly been the chairman of the International Red Cross' ball, which has been held at Mar-a-Lago since before Trump bought the estate. And Lara Trump, the president's daughter-in-law, was a co-chair of the annual Mar-a-Lago event hosted by Big Dog Ranch Rescue.\n\nOn Saturday, the Washington Post's David Fahrenthold, who has tracked the Trump Organization's relationships with charities more than anyone, pointed out that while the Trump hotel in Washington, D.C. has been doing well, his other more distant properties are clearly suffering under the weight of Trump's controversial presidency. That includes not only an event drop-off at Mar-a-Lago -- which now appears to be losing support from the Palm Beach elite who Trump covets -- but also at the Trump SOHO hotel in Manhattan, as well as at the Trump golf courses in the Bronx and Los Angeles. According to Fahrenthold, the trend \"shows how vulnerable Trump's business is to backlash, because it needs big-ticket customers to want to put Trump's name on their own special events.\"\n\nSpeaking of special events, the president and first lady also announced on Saturday that they will not attend this year's Kennedy Center Honors in D.C. in the wake of three of this year's five honorees vowing to boycott the traditional White House reception that accompanies the celebration. The president and first lady traditionally attend the December event, but Donald and Melania Trump are staying away this year \"to allow the honorees to celebrate without any political distraction,\" according to White House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders.\n\nThis post has been updated to include David Fahrenthold's analysis.", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T16:46:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": At the protest, a man with Nazi sympathies drove a car into counter-protesters, wounding 19 people and killing 32-year-old Heather Heyer.\n\nThe protesters were in Charlottesville to demonstrate their removal of a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee. Counter-protesters reportedly were carrying clubs, a move Trump pointed to as an example of how there was \"blame on both sides.\"\n\nEileen Sheil, a spokeswoman for the Cleveland Clinic, would not say whether those comments influenced the hospital's decision, saying only that they \"considered a number of factors.\" The Cleveland Clinic is considered one of the country's best hospitals, with locations in Florida, Virginia, and Ohio.\n\nIt already had been under pressure to move its event by healthcare providers who oppose Trump's aim to repeal and replace portions of Obamacare and other groups who protest his budget proposal to cut research funding from the National Institutes of Health. An open letter signed by nearly 1,700 doctors, medical students and patients says that holding such a fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago is \"unacceptable,\" saying it \"symbolically and financially supports a politician\" with those goals.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic said last week, before the violence in Charlottesville, that it would not change its fundraiser. Sheil said it had been scheduled for Feb. 24, 2018, and a new location and date hasn't been selected.\n\nDavid Fahrenthold, a journalist for the Washington Post who has reported on the club's dealings, said on Twitter that these types of events typically cost between $100,000 and $275,000.\n\nLoss for @realDonaldTrump's club: $100K-$275K in fees, based on similar -sized events. https://t.co/xBnlzUh12U -- David Fahrenthold (@Fahrenthold) August 17, 2017\n\nDr. Toby Cosgrove, CEO of the Cleveland Clinic, was part of the White House's Strategy & Policy Forum, a group that Trump said he would dissolve \"rather than putting pressure\" on business leaders as various CEOs began exiting another one of his councils, focused on manufacturing. {"id": "9979103", "categories": [{"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711667783", "source": {"id": "283", "title": "Miami Herald", "uri": "miamiherald.com"}, "url": "http://www.miamiherald.com/entertainment/ent-columns-blogs/jose-lambiet/article168016157.html", "body": "In April, Mar-a-Lago, the president's private club in Palm Beach, was the hottest place to be in South Florida. Heads of states came to dine with The Donald while well-heeled members milled about and up to 500 tuxedoed charity fundraiser guests gawked.\n\nLess than four months later, Mar-a-Lago is suddenly a dirty word -- courtesy of Trump's inability to pick a side in the deadly Charlottesville protests.\n\nAnd when it reopens in November, the beachfront club could end up downright cavernous as more than half a dozen major non-profits notified Mar-a-Lago they'd hold winter galas planned for the club's gilded grand ballroom somewhere else.\n\nIt started Thursday when Cleveland Clinic, a research hospital with a site in West Palm Beach, announced it would change venues for its $1 million fundraiser in February, possibly to a nearby hotel.\n\nThe research hospital had held the event at Mar-a-Lago for the past eight years.\n\nRelated link: Undercooled meat. Dangerous fish. Health inspectors ding Trump's Mar-a-Lago kitchen\n\nShortly after the announcement, the American Cancer Society turned its back on Trump's \"Winter White House,\" canceling not just one but two events.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" read the Society's statement regarding re-booking of the 2018 sponsor dinner and 60th anniversary gala. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nAnd Friday morning, the Salvation Army walked as well, joining the American Red Cross, Susan G. Komen and the Autism Association of Palm Beach County.\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom, a group supporting Israel's ambulance and disaster relief programs, also pulled its event from the club, a shindig that last year drew 600 attendees who paid $650 each to get in.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago,\" the group announced.\n\nCharity galas traditionally have been a major stream of revenue for Mar-a-Lago.\n\nIn the past, the ballroom was used for nonprofit fundraisers two to three times a week from November through April. Mar-a-Lago rented out the ballroom but also provided the four- to five-course meals and drinks.\n\nGuests in evening wear paid between $500 to $1,000 to attend.\n\nAs of now, some nonprofits are staying the course, including West Palm Beach's Kravis Center For The Performing Arts, Big Dog Ranch Rescue (Trump daughter-in-law Lara Trump is the event's chairwoman) and Leaders in Furthering Education, National Enquirer heiress Lois Pope's Dec. 2 shindig.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T17:39:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 2716, "textStart": 2710, "date": "-12-02", "amb": false}], "sim": {"id": "9806180", "categories": [{"id": 93, "label": "dmoz/Science/Biology/Flora and Fauna", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Biology/Flora_and_Fauna", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711200718", "source": {"id": "1040", "title": "WJAX", "uri": "actionnewsjax.com"}, "url": "http://www.actionnewsjax.com/news/trending-now/third-organization-joins-charities-leaving-maralago/594472182", "body": "PALM BEACH, Fla. - Three major philanthropic organizations said Thursday they are pulling their events from President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club, with one already in discussions to move its 2018 fundraiser to another A-list oceanfront setting.\n\n>> Read more trending news\n\nThursday afternoon, the Cleveland Clinic and American Cancer Society announced they were leaving the president's Palm Beach estate.\n\nLate Thursday, the American Friends of Magen David Adom, an organization supporting Israel disaster relief programs, told The Palm Beach Post it is canceling a planned fund-raising gala at Mar-a-Lago, set for Sunday, Feb. 25.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago,\" the brief statement said. Magen David Adom is Israel's ambulance, blood services and disaster-relief organization.\n\nLast season's gala, held Feb. 26, featured more than 600 attendees who paid $650 per ticket.\n\nAlso Thursday, a prominent business leader in Palm Beach urged other charitable organizations sticking with Mar-a-Lago to reconsider their commitment to the president's club. Laurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, told those groups and their deep-pocket donors to \"have a conscience\" and seek another venue for their events.\n\nThe decisions by the American Cancer Society, Cleveland Clinic and the AFMDA were three of the latest examples of pushback to Trump in the days since the president's off-the-cuff, combative and controversial news conference on Tuesday at Trump Tower, where he renewed his statements that \"both sides\" were at fault in the deadly violence in Charlottesville, Virginia, sparked by marches by neo-Nazis and white supremacists last weekend.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the American Cancer Society said in announcing it would move two 2018 events, a dinner for sponsors and its 60th anniversary gala, from the president's Palm Beach estate. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nThat announcement followed a decision by Cleveland Clinic, a leading research hospital in the United States with a location in West Palm Beach, to move its event, possibly to the Eau Palm Beach Resort and Spa.\n\nNick Gold, the public relations director of the oceanfront Eau Palm Beach , said it is working with the hospital in hopes of hosting next year's event.\n\n\"Their first call was to us,\" Gold said. \"We are talking to them. ... We certainly want to work with The Cleveland Clinic.\"\n\nThe American Cancer Society said it has not settled on a new location and is evaluating venue options. No further information was available about whether AFMDA would try to hold an event elsewhere in Palm Beach County during the season.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic's move follows previous assertions its event would go on at Trump's Palm Beach estate as planned, despite protests and letters of concern from some who demanded the venue be changed.\n\nThe hospital has hosted the fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago for the past eight years, according to The Associated Press, raising anywhere from $700,000 to $1 million a year.\n\nA representative for the Kravis Center in West Palm Beach said the nonprofit has no plans to move its fundraising event -- The Palm Beach Wine Auction -- which is scheduled to be held at Mar-a-Lago on Feb. 1. Tickets to the auction are $1,000 a person.\n\nThe Big Dog Ranch Rescue in Loxahatchee Groves also still plans to have one of its major fundraisers at Mar-a-Lago. The \"Wine, Women and Shoes\" event is scheduled for March 10, said Robin Friedman, Big Dog Ranch's director of development.\n\n\"Most of our supporters know that we do what we do for our dogs, and that just happens to be the best venue,\" Friedman said of Mar-a-Lago. \"In fact, it's one of the only venues where we can do an event of our size in the daytime.\"\n\nThe president's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, is co-chairing the Big Dog Ranch Mar-a-Lago event with Georgina Bloomberg, daughter of billionaire Michael Bloomberg.\n\nThe animal-rescue group is expecting 600 attendees -- up from 450 last year. The group raised $1.1 million at its Mar-a-Lago event last year, and Friedman said \"we are definitely expecting more\" for 2018.\n\nNonetheless, Palm Beach County event venues have made clear they would be receptive to discussing opportunities with charities considering a move.\n\nThe Eau, located on a 7-acre site with ocean views and lush tropical gardens in Manalapan, underwent a major transformation in 2013 -- dropping the Ritz-Carlton name and rebranding itself as a beachfront getaway for out-of-town guests and locals looking for a beachfront retreat. The property consistently ranks among the best resorts in the state. This spring, Chinese President Xi Jinping stayed at the resort during his two-day summit with Trump at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nGold said the resort can accommodate as many as 500 guests for a seated dinner. In addition to the Cleveland Clinic, the Eau has received inquiries from other charities looking to move events away from Mar-a-Lago, Gold said.\n\n\"We do see a lot of charities that are checking spaces to see what can be done,\" Gold said.\n\nDave Anderson, the general manager of the Palm Beach County Convention Center in West Palm Beach, said the venue is also hearing from groups who may be interested in moving events previously held at Mar-a-Lago. The convention center can host groups of roughly 1,000 people.\n\n\"We have a beautiful ballroom,\" Anderson said. \"We have a fantastic chef. ... It is a great venue for social events. The only thing I can't provide is an ocean at my doorstep.\"\n\nOne leader in Palm Beach's business community urged the charitable groups to consider a change of venue.\n\nThe Palm Beach Chamber's Baker minced no words Thursday about whether charities should abandon Mar-a-Lago this season.\n\n\"If you have a conscience, you're really condoning bad behavior by continuing to be there,\" Baker said. \"Many say it's the dollars (raised at the events) that count. Yes. But the integrity of any or organization rests on their sound decisions and stewardship.\"\n\nShe added: \"Personally, I do not feel that supporting him, directly or indirectly, speaks well of any organization.\"\n\nBaker's comments are the strongest yet from Palm Beach County's business community in the wake of Trump's conflicting and, to many, polarizing statements made in the aftermath of the weekend violence.\n\nLast Friday night, neo-Nazis and white supremacists marched through the northwestern Virginia town that is home to Thomas Jefferson's Monticello. On Saturday, a suspected white supremacist rammed a car into a crowd of counter-protesters, killing one and injuring 19.\n\nIn response, Trump first blamed Saturday's violence \"on many sides,\" but zeroed in on specific criticism of the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazis two days later after a backlash to his initial statement.\n\nHowever, Trump doubled down on his first set of comments during Tuesday's volatile news conference -- and then tweeted support for Confederate monuments on Thursday.\n\nNo one from the Palm Beach County business community had spoken out publicly -- until Baker.\n\nBaker also expressed no patience for charities that will try to keep a low profile during this turbulent period.\n\n\"I hope that people will not maintain their neutrality,\" she said. \"This is the best time ever for people to show their backbone.\"\n\nBaker encouraged all charities to re-examine their core purpose for guidance about how to react to Trump's comments.\n\nIn particular, she called out charities that advocate for social justice, the disabled, the poor and the sick.\n\n\"Look at your mission statement,\" Baker said. \"Are you living up to it?\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic's departure from Mar-a-Lago was no surprise after CEO Toby Cosgrove distanced himself from Trump following Tuesday's comments. Cosgrove was one of a number of CEOs who stepped down from two White House business councils.\n\nTrump later said he was disbanding that council and another after a rash of defections by other business industry leaders, including the CEOs of 3M, Campbell Soup Co. and United Technologies.\n\n\"Rather than putting pressure on the businesspeople of the Manufacturing Council & Strategy & Policy Forum, I am ending both,\" the president tweeted. \"Thank you all!\"\n\nBut the pressure for the Cleveland Clinic to move its event from Mar-a-Lago started this past spring, with petitions and backlash against the Ohio-based hospital and the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute as each planned lavish galas on the Palm Beach resort's grounds during the first months of Trump's presidency.", {"id": "9959474", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 17, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 298, "label": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Ethnicity", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711613120", "source": {"id": "971", "title": "Los Angeles Times", "uri": "latimes.com"}, "url": "http://www.latimes.com/nation/fl-reg-charities-reconsider-mar-a-lago-events-20170818-story.html", "body": "The American Red Cross and the Salvation Army became the latest charitable organizations Friday to abandon plans for events at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort.\n\nThey're among several philanthropic groups canceling plans at the resort as pressure mounts from business leaders over the president's comments about violence in Charlottesville.\n\nA spokeswoman for the Salvation Army told the Sun Sentinel on Friday that it will not host its Holiday Snow Ball in Palm Beach event at Mar-a-Lago, citing a shifting national conversation. The Salvation Army relies \"heavily on fundraising events\" like the ball as part of helping those in need, the group said in a statement.\n\n\"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\nThe American Red Cross also nixed plans to host an annual fundraising event at the resort calling it a \"source of controversy and pain\" for volunteers, employees and staff.\n\n\"We believe this action will allow us to continue to put the focus on our lifesaving mission and the people we serve,\" according to a statement. \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nThe organization offers many social services, including food for the hungry, relief for disaster victims, clothing and shelter to the homeless and opportunities for the underprivileged.\n\nOn Thursday, three large funding organizations -- the American Cancer Society, Cleveland Clinic and American Friends of Magen David Adom -- pulled their events.\n\nThe American Cancer Society's event, held at Trump's Palm Beach estate for 11 years, nets about $450,000 for the organization, according to the American Cancer Society's local office.\n\nThe organization has started looking for an another site for the fundraiser. It was held at Mar-a-Lago because of costs, venue requirements and other factors, according to the statement.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic didn't give a reason for its decision. Before changing course, Cleveland Clinic spokeswoman Eileen Sheil had said last week that the hospital system's event was not political. Donors and executives had discussed it and agreed Mar-a-Lago met the organization's needs, she said.\n\nThe fundraiser has raised $700,000 to $1 million annually to expand programs and purchase equipment for the hospital system's Florida facility. It has been held at Mar-a-Lago the past eight years.\n\nTwo other organizations said Friday that their events will proceed as scheduled.\n\nA spokesman for The Kravis Center for the Performing Arts said that as of Thursday afternoon, officials had not changed their minds. \"The event has been held there for a number of years, and the people who are regulars at the event want to keep it there,\" said Gary Schweikhart, spokesman for the Kravis Center.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said it, too, will stay the course. \"The ball typically attracts 700 people, and it's the only venue in Palm Beach that will accommodate a crowd of that size,\" according to a statement issued from the foundation, which supports Palm Beach Police Department employees.\n\nThis is a developing story. Check for updates.\n\nStaff writer Skyler Swisher and staff researcher Barbara Hijek contributed to this report.\n\nRvanvelzer@sun-sentinel.com, 561-243-6544, or on Twitter the latest nonprofits to pull an event from the Mar-a-Lago Club, the Palm Beach winter home of President Donald Trump.\n\nThe Preservation Foundation, which celebrates and protects the architectural and cultural heritage of Palm Beach, planned to host a dance in March at the club, which has long been an oasis for charities and their patrons during Palm Beach's winter charity season.\n\nOn the Preservation Foundation's official Facebook and Twitter accounts, a statement read, \"Given the current environment surrounding Mar-a-Lago, we have made the decision to move our annual dinner dance.\"\n\nThe event will be at a private residence on March 9, Preservation Foundation Executive Director Amanda Skier said.\n\nLater Saturday, H.O.W. \"Hearing the Ovarian Cancer Whisper,\" published a statement on its Facebook page that read, \"After careful consideration H.O.W., 'Hearing the Ovarian Cancer Whisper,' has changed its venue for our annual 'Time is of the Essence Luncheon' from Mar-a-Lago with a return to our roots at the historically beautiful Flagler Museum.\n\n\"For us, this event is about raising money for research, educational programs, and financial assistance for women undergoing treatment. We are committed to our mission therefore, this is not a political statement made by H.O.W.\"\n\nUPDATED: Here's a list of who's leaving Mar-a-Lago\n\nThe move by the two organizations Saturday brings to 10 the number of nonprofits pulling an event from Mar-a-Lago since the president's controversial news conference Tuesday at Trump Tower on the deadly violence in Charlottesville, Va., last week.\n\nOn Friday, five additional philanthropic organizations -- Susan G. Komen, the International Red Cross, the Salvation Army, Autism Association of Palm Beach County and Big Dog Ranch -- moved events from Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, American Cancer Society and the American Friends of Magen David Adom, an organization supporting Israel disaster relief programs, also have changed venues for their events.\n\nThe Raymond F. Kravis Center board is planning next week to discuss possibly moving the Palm Beach Wine Auction from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"We have received concerns about this event being at Mar-a-Lago,\" Judith Mitchell, the Kravis CEO, said in an email to The Palm Beach Post. \"We have a process to address such issues and we are currently engaged in that process. Komen and the Autism Association of Palm Beach County. \"In fact, it's one of the only venues where we can do an event of our size in the daytime\".\n\nThe new announcements bring the total number of groups that have canceled events at Mar-a-Lago to seven.\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and anti-semitic and racist views being spewed by neo-Nazis and white supremacists are repugnant and repulsive - and they are antithetical to everything that this country, and I personally stand for\", LIFE President Lois Pope said in a statement.\n\nThe proceeds of the Lady in Red Gala are slated to go to \"an array of initiatives benefiting military families and military dogs\", according to the charity's website.\n\nThe charitable groups joined three other large event cancellations Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club. Mar-a-Lago rented out the ballroom but also provided the four- to five-course meals and drinks.\n\nStackla Emerges as a Go-To Firm for Charities Seeking Viral Impact: The social-media-marketing company, which made its name developing user-generated content into online promotions for major corporations, launched a new division, Stackla for Good, to handle its growing portfolio of hashtag-heavy cause campaigns for groups such as Greenpeace, ONE, and the World Wildlife Fund, Fast Company writes. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations\", the American Cancer Society said in a statement.\n\nThe American Cancer Society, which has hosted its annual event at Mar-a-Lago for at least the past decade - has not selected another venue. The club, which has sought dozens of H-2B visas for foreign employees because it argued that it can't find Americans to do the work, was absent last week at a job fair in West Palm Beach.\n\nTrump retained an ownership interest in his business when he took office, which means he has a personal stake in Mar-a-Lago's success.\n\nThe event was scheduled to take place at Mar-a-Lago on February 25, 2018.\n\nThe gilded and glittering Mar-a-Lago has been a favorite spot for holding charity events and a money maker for the Trump Organization.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation said it, too, will
