"http://www.opposingviews.com/i/health/cleveland-clinic-pulls-event-mar-lago-resort", "body": "The Cleveland Clinic, a nonprofit medical research and care center, announced on August 17 that they pulled out of a planned fundraiser at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago club and resort, making them the third charity to do so that day after his response to violence in Charlottesville, Virginia, drew criticism from Democrats and Republicans alike.\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018,\" the Cleveland Clinic said in a statement on August 17, according to Politico. \"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nThe Associated Press notes that this is the first time in eight years that the Ohio organization will host its annual event elsewhere.\n\nCleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove was on one of Trump's two business councils that the president dissolved after a number of members quit in light of the Charlottesville aftermath.\n\nThe hospital did not elaborate on their reasoning for changing venues, although a number of those associated with the clinic, including doctors, nurses and medical students, signed a letter urging the organization to sever ties with Trump in light of some of his policies that include medical research budget cuts.\n\nIn 2017, other organizations have moved their events away from the club that Trump visits regularly, many of them citing the heightened security that held up guests and even made many late, notes The Washington Post.\n\n\"We allow for a cocktail hour -- an hour and a half, really [during a silent auction fundraiser],\" said Peter Brock, chairman for the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, which has hosted a fundraiser at the Mar-a-Lago for eight years, according to The Post. \"And we want people to have time to have a couple of glasses of wine, obviously, and try to raise the bids. ... People didn't have the appropriate amount of time.\"\n\nTheir next fundraiser will be at a neighboring resort.\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society followed suit, announcing on August 17 that their 2018 fundraisers will not be at Trump's Florida resort, notes AP.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" American Cancer Society spokeswoman Miriam Falco said in statement, according to AP. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nThe three charities made the announcements following what some called Trump's reluctance to speak out against white supremacists in Charlottesville.\n\n\"We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides, on many sides,\" Trump said in a short statement following the protests, according to CNN. \"It has been going on for a long time in our country -- not Donald Trump, not Barack Obama. be held at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club, amid backlash over Trump's comments on the violence in Charlottesville, Va., this week.\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018,\" the Cleveland Clinic said in a statement on Thursday, according to the Cleveland Plain Dealer. \"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nOn the same day, the American Cancer Society said it would move its 2017 Island of Palm Beach gala from Trump's club, the Washington Post reported.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the group said in a statement to the Post. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nCleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove was part of Trump's strategic and policy forum, which disbanded this week in the wake of the President's remarks defending people who were linked to white supremacist groups and saying \"both sides\" deserved blame for the recent violence in {"id": "9979117", "categories": [{"id": 150, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/On the Web", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/On_the_Web", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711667808", "source": {"id": "5836", "title": "mypalmbeachpost.com", "uri": "mypalmbeachpost.com"}, "url": "http://www.mypalmbeachpost.com/business/update-five-more-charities-pull-out-mar-lago-events/kmSbC6rQkcaxNhagItqfjL/", "body": "By Jennifer Sorentrue and Alexandra Clough - Palm Beach Post Staff Writer\n\nFive more philanthropic organizations said Friday they have pulled their fundraising events from President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club following an intense social media push calling on people to boycott charities who use the venue.\n\nA ninth charity, Palm Beach philanthropist Lois Pope's Lady in Red gala for education initiatives, may depart as well. Pope, a self-described Trump loyalist, issued a statement Friday saying she had recommended to the organization's board of directors that they seek a new location.\n\nClick here to see which charities are in, which are out of Mar-a-Lago for this season\n\nA total of eight groups have now pulled their events Mar-a-Lago since the president's off-the-cuff, combative and controversial news conference on Tuesday at Trump Tower.\n\nOn Friday, Susan G. Komen, the world's largest nonprofit in the fight against breast cancer, the International Red Cross, The Salvation Army, Autism Association of Palm Beach County, and Big Dog Ranch Rescue in Loxahatchee Groves, announced they would not hold their events at Trump's Palm Beach club during the winter fundraising season.\n\nThose announcements came a day after the Cleveland Clinic, American Cancer Society and the American Friends of Magen David Adom, an organization supporting Israel disaster relief programs, said they would seek alternative venues. The Cleveland Clinic plans to hold its Feb. 23 ball at The Breakers in Palm Beach.\n\nThe International Red Cross announcement, in particular, marks the end of an era. Mar-a-Lago's original owner, Marjorie Merriweather Post, hosted the IRC's first ball there and Trump has been a frequent chairman of the event. And Big Dog Rescue, which counts Trump's daughter-in-law Lara Trump as a gala co-chair, decided Friday to move its fundraiser only a after it reiterated its intention to stick with Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThe decisions coincided with a firestorm of criticism on social media. Many Twitter users called on people to boycott the charities, pointing to Trump's controversial statements on the deadly violence in Charlottesville, Va., last weekend, including that \"both sides\" were at fault in the confrontations between neo-Nazis, white supremacists and counter protesters.\n\nA third organization joins charities leaving Mar-a-Lago\n\nTrump's statements that there were also \"some very fine people\" on both sides was especially stinging when juxtaposed against the anti-Semitic chants of \"Blood and soil\" and \"Jews will not replace us\" by marching, torch-carrying neo-Nazis and others on Aug. 11.\n\nPope issued a sharply worded statement to that effect on Friday.\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by neo-Nazis and white supremacists are repugnant and repulsive - and they are antithetical to everything that this country stands for. And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations,\" Pope said in a prepared statement. \"I want my children, grandchildren and great grandson to know that standing up to hatred and discrimination in all forms is both a personal responsibility and the right thing to do. Therefore, I am recommending to my board that we move this year's gala from the Mar-A-Lago Club.\"\n\nIn a statement Friday, Laurie Simmons, who heads Big Dog Ranch Rescue, said the group now plans to hold its annual luncheon at its new Loxahatchee Groves shelter.\n\n\"In the interest of being better able to focus on our core mission of helping animals and saving dogs, we have decided to hold our next annual luncheon at our new facility in Loxahatchee Groves,\" Simmons said. \"Holding the event at our facility will also give our donors a first-hand look at our world-class dog rescue operation.\"\n\nIronically, the platform of choice to pressure the organizations became social media, including Twitter, which Trump himself uses on a daily basis to reach out to supporters and castigate opponents.\n\nOn Twitter, some critics used the hashtag #DropMarALago in their calls to charities to abandon the club, which has long been an oasis for charities and their patrons during Palm Beach's winter charity season.\n\nOthers said they would no longer donate to the Salvation Army and vowed to stop shopping at its thrift stores if the non-profit didn't change venues.\n\n\"Do the right thing,\" one person wrote to The Salvation Army on Twitter. \"Stand against hatred & bigotry, Nazis and KKK. Don't continue to host your events at Mar-A-Lago.\"\n\n\"Please do the right thing and cancel your Mar-a-largo (sic) event,\" another Twitter user said. \"If not @goodwill gets my business from now on.\"\n\nOne local charity will keep event at Mar-a-Lago, with Lara Trump as co-chair\n\nSeveral of those taking aim Susan G. Komen used the hashtag #RacistForTheCure, a reference to Komen's annual Race For The Cure events, to put pressure on the group to change venues.\n\n\"Have the breast cancer grifters over at @SusanGKomen cancelled their gala at Mar-A- Lago yet? #RacistForTheCure,\" one tweet read.\n\nLocal non-profits, including the Palm Beach Zoo and the Kravis Center in West Palm Beach, were also targeted on Twitter for plans to hold events at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nPB chamber head to charities: 'Have conscience' about Mar-a-Lago\n\n\"@KravisCenter If you're not against the #nazis, you're WITH the Nazis, Move #MaraLago event,\" one person wrote.\n\nThe linkage of Trump's Mar-a-Lago and Nazism are a particularly sharp rebuke of the performing arts center decision to hold it's event at the president's club.\n\nThe Kravis center's roots go back to the Palm Beach Country Club, created by Jewish residents of Palm Beach who were excluded from other private clubs.\n\nIn a 2014 interview with the Palm Beach Post, Kravis backer Alexander W. Dreyfoos, Jr. recalled why club members decided to donate to the performing arts center in honor of Raymond F. Kravis, an Oklahoma oil man and Palm Beach Country Club member.\n\nEvery year, club members would go around asking other members to donate to their causes. And every year, Kravis would contribute generously, Dreyfoos said.\n\n\"But Kravis never had his own cause,\" Dreyfoos said.\n\nSo when the time came to name the center, \"they named it for him,\" Dreyfoos said. \"They wanted to reciprocate.\"\n\nSome Twitter users pointed to Friday's mass resignation of the President's Committee On the Arts and Humanities in their calls for the Kravis Center to move its fundraiser. The arts board's membership cited Trump's remarks about the violence in Charlottesville, Va. for their departure.\n\n\"Hey @KravisCenter follow the lead of fellow arts leaders today!,\" one tweet read. \"Find a new place for your gala!\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:39:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 1470, "textStart": 1463, "date": "-02-23", "amb": false}, {"textEnd": 2612, "textStart": {"id": "9789904", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 2, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711150480", "source": {"id": "8208", "title": "Central Maine", "uri": "centralmaine.com"}, "url": "http://www.centralmaine.com/2017/08/17/the-american-cancer-society-cleveland-clinic-cancel-plans-for-galas-at-mar-a-lago/", "body": "The head of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which the resort is a member, urges other charities to follow suit.\n\nTwo leading charities said they were pulling their business from President Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach on Thursday amid blowback over Trump's comments on Charlottesville's bloody unrest.\n\nThe head of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which Mar-a-Lago is a member, also called the president's business \"morally reprehensible\" on Thursday and said she expected more charities to defect.\n\n\"The glitter, the shine has gone from the club,\" said Laurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, \"and I can't help but think there will be more fallout from it.\"\n\nThe rapid rejections of one of the president's signature businesses revealed a key vulnerability for Trump, who has been fiercely criticized this week for equating the actions of white supremacists and neo-Nazis with protesters during a violent weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nA number of other groups - including the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society in New York and Bascom Palmer Eye Institute in Miami - have all announced in recent months that they would choose other venues.\n\nThe White House referred questions to the Trump Organization, which did not immediately respond.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, one of the nation's top-ranked medical centers, abruptly canceled its plans Thursday to host a fundraising gala at Mar-a-Lago in the coming year. Company spokeswoman Eileen Sheil told The Post on Thursday that \"there were a variety of factors\" behind the cancellation, but she added, \"We're not elaborating.\"\n\nShortly after, the American Cancer Society, another long-time charity customer of the club, said it would pull its own event and explore \"other opportunities and potential venues.\"\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the group said in a statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nBoth health-related groups faced growing pressure to rethink their support of the president's business amid numerous controversies. But the cancellations don't come without risk: The Cleveland Clinic said it had raised about $1 million a year for medical equipment over the last eight years at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nMar-a-Lago's 2017-2018 season now looks like it will be the slowest period for charity events in at least a decade, according to a Washington Post analysis of upcoming events. It's unclear how much the cancellations could cost the club, though similar-sized events brought in fees of between $100,000 and $275,000.\n\nTrump's comments also appear to have helped turn the Palm Beach business community against one of its most opulent venues.\n\nBaker, head of the Palm Beach chamber, spoke vigorously against Mar-a-Lago on Thursday, saying that her directive to nearby charities was, \"If you're looking at your mission statement, can you honestly say having an event at Mar-a-Lago, given all that has transpired, is the best stewardship of your efforts?\"\n\n\"The club is a member of the chamber. But right is right,\" she added in an interview with The Post. \"My mantra this week is from Dante: 'The darkest places in hell are reserved for those who maintain their neutrality in times of moral crisis.' Especially for nonprofits. Especially for groups who help people who can't help themselves.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic's cancellation was an abrupt change, and the hospital system had still intended to host its ninth gala there as recently as last week. The move followed weeks of public turmoil, including a letter signed by 1,600 health professionals and others last month that said the Mar-a-Lago booking \"symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic's chief executive, Toby Cosgrove, was among the business leaders on the president's Strategic and Policy Forum that agreed to disband on Wednesday. As members of the group resigned, Trump said on Twitter that he would end the forum and a separate American Manufacturing Council \"rather than putting pressure on the businesspeople.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic was ranked the nation's second-best hospital this month by U.S. News & World Report, which gave top honors to its urology, cardiology and heart surgery units.\n\nNearly 550 people visited the hospital's February fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago, where the theme was \"Reflections of Versailles.\"\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? Our daily headlines email is delivered to your inbox each morning. Sign up by entering your email address below. {"id": "9840207", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1154, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Events", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Events", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711304096", "source": {"id": "246", "title": "International Business Times", "uri": "ibtimes.com"}, "url": "http://www.ibtimes.com/charlottesville-comments-blowback-trumps-business-take-direct-hit-cancelled-events-2579958", "body": "President Donald Trump's remarks on violence in Charlottesville where he insisted that \"both sides\" were to blame for the incident not just drew criticism from all quarters, but also ended up hurting his business. Three fundraising giants decided Thursday to withdraw their previously planned fundraising galas at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort, according to multiple reports.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society, and the American Friends of Magen David Adom (AFMDA) are the philanthropic organizations that decided to pull events from the president's mansion. The cancellations -- that may cut down the revenue for the private club -- can be viewed as a direct blowback to Trump's business.\n\nThe mansion has been a venue for such gala events in the past and has earned revenues between $100,000 and $275,000 each from such events, Chicago Tribune reported. The president calls the club \"Winter White House.\"\n\nThe mansion that has lavish interiors and can hold a large crowd. Each guest suite is \"exquisitely appointed in keeping with the original character of this lavish estate while assuring the luxury of modern day world-class amenities,\" according to its official website.\n\nAround 21 charities held events at the mansion between November and April during the active social season, ABC News reported citing Palm Beach town records.\n\nThe American Cancer Society is one of the high-dollar clients at the Mar-a-Lago club since 2009. It cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in a statement, as reported by various media publications, on its decision to pull out its fundraising gala from the club.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, one of the nation's leading medical centers, also took a U-turn from its decision of holding its winter event in the club. Earlier, it had said it planned to continue business at the club, reports said.\n\nAFMDA, which is Israel's national ambulance, blood-services, and disaster-relief organization, also said, it decided not to hold its 2018 gala at Mar-a-Lago \"after considerable deliberation\". The charity had a big event last season at the club with about 600 people attending it, reports said.\n\nApart from being a host to some of the biggest gala events, the club has also become the site of protests by groups who are against Trump's policies and statements. For instance, in January, the American Red Cross faced criticism when protesters rallied outside its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago as the charity organization was helping those affected by Trump's U.S. refugee program, ABC News reported.\n\nHowever, the organization did not respond to questions about whether it will have its fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago next year as well or not.\n\nMeanwhile, some other charities said they do not plan to cancel its events at the club such as the Kravis Center who would continue to have its annual wine auction at the Mar-a-Lago, a report said.\n\n\"The event has been held there for a number of years, and the folks supporting it want to continue to have it there,\" spokesman Gary Schweikhart said.\n\nThe Palm Beach Police Foundation also said that it would have its annual ball at the president's mansion because it is not a political event and that no other venue would accommodate as many as 700 guests.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:12:00Z", [Doug Mills | New York Times]\n\nThe Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen on Friday joined a growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, deepening the financial impact to President Donald Trump's private business amid furor over his comments on Charlottesville.\n\nThe major exits now mean seven of the club's biggest event customers have abandoned it this week, likely costing the Trump business hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost revenue or more.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast-cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nPREVIOUS COVERAGE:Trump retreats to Mar-a-lago over and over but at what cost?\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need - regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions - and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nThe charitable groups joined three other large event cancellations Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is no longer planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post Friday.\n\nPREVIOUS COVERAGE: Greetings from Mar-a-lago, Donald Trump's presidential paradise\n\nThe move from the local group, which has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008, suggests that pressure on the club is growing even among groups with deep roots in Palm Beach.\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe cancellations hit at one of the private Florida club's top moneymakers: The club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past during Palm Beach's glitzy social seasons.\n\nBut they also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters were similarly at blame during a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T21:11:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "dateCrawl": {"id": "10129747", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 505, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 823, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service Clubs", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service_Clubs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1302, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712108106", "source": {"id": "138", "title": "The Denver Post", "uri": "denverpost.com"}, "url": "http://www.denverpost.com/2017/08/19/trump-mar-a-lago-club-loses-charity-event/", "body": "Another Palm Beach, Florida, charity announced Saturday that it was canceling plans to hold a gala at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club - the ninth to cancel a big-ticket charity event at the club this week.\n\nThe Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach, a charity focused on the ritzy island's architectural landmarks, had planned to hold a dinner dance at Mar-a-Lago next March. The foundation was a new customer for Trump's club, and a potentially lucrative one: It spent $244,000 on rent and food on a previous gala at another site, according to tax filings.\n\nBut on Saturday, the foundation said it would find another venue.\n\n\"Given the current environment surrounding Mar-a-Lago, we have made the decision to move our annual dinner dance,\" Amanda Skier, the foundation's executive director, said in a written statement. She did not say which new venue the foundation would use.\n\nThat decision meant that Trump's club had lost nine of the 16 galas or dinner events that it had been scheduled to host during next winter's social \"season\" in Palm Beach. At least two other groups have also canceled charity luncheons there this week.\n\nThose losses could reduce the club's revenue by hundreds of thousands of dollars by each event, and deny President Trump his dual role as president and host to the island's partying elite. If he returns to the club for weekends next winter, the president could often find its grand ballrooms quiet and empty.\n\nThese cancellations all followed the president's remarks on the march of neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups in Charlottesville, Virginia, in which the president said the protesters, who gathered under the pretense of wanting to preserve a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee, included some \"fine people.\"\n\nOn Friday, the Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen joined the growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the club.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need - regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions - and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nTrump's club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past.\n\nBut the cancellations also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe Trump Organization has not responded to requests for comment.\n\nThe charitable groups join three other large event cancellations from Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nSome of the club's most notable local boosters, with long fundraising histories and deep Palm Beach roots, were also in outright rebellion Friday against the club. Lois Pope, a Mar-a-Lago member and philanthropist who heads the Lois Pope Life Foundation and Leaders In Furthering Education, said she had told her foundation's board to move its well-known December gala from the club.\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive,\" Pope wrote in a statement. \"And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\"\n\nOne of the cancellations cut close to home for the Trumps. Big Dog Ranch Rescue said Friday it would no longer hold an upcoming event at the club and would instead move it to the group's facility nearby. Trump's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, was scheduled to co-chair the event.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is not planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post on Friday. The local group has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008.\n\nThe Ryan Licht Sang Bipolar Foundation on Friday also announced it had canceled its annual medical briefing luncheon at the club and will move it to another venue.\n\n\"We stand with the community,\" the foundation's co-founder, Dusty Sang, told The Post Friday. \"I think people are standing up for what they believe.\"\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters equally shared the blame for a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T20:58:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-20", We believe this action will allow us to continue to put the focus on our lifesaving mission and the people we serve. The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nThe Salvation Army\n\n\"The Salvation Army relies heavily on fundraising events like The Holiday Snow Ball in Palm Beach to further our mission of helping those in need through a range of social services including food for the hungry, relief for disaster victims, clothing and shelter for the homeless, and opportunities for the underprivileged. Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\nThe American Cancer Society\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\n\n\"With our volunteer leaders, we are exploring other opportunities and potential venues. The generous support of community volunteers and donors are critical to our life-saving mission. Only by coming together will we solve our society's most difficult challenges, including reducing the pain and suffering from cancer.\"\n\nCleveland Clinic\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018. We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nLeaders in Furthering Education (LIFE)\n\nThe organization's president, Lois Pope, is urging the board to abandon Mar-a-Lago for a gala in December. Pope said:\n\n\"America was founded on the principles of life, liberty and justice for all. In the 241 years since, millions of Americans of all religions, races, creeds, color, gender and sexual orientation have died -- and millions more have been disabled -- fighting to protect these values and freedoms.\n\n\"Now, however, our great nation is under siege by those who seek to undermine and obliterate these principles. Indeed, the hatred, vitriol and Anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by Neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive -- and they are antithetical to everything that this country, and I personally stand for. And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\n\n\"Therefore, I am recommending to my board that we move this year's 24th Annual Lady in Red Gala on December 2 -- the proceeds of which benefit those very millions of men and women of all persuasions who have fought with courage and sacrifice in defense of America's ideals -- from the Mar-A-Lago Club.\n\n\"I want my children, grandchildren and great grandson to know that standing up to hatred and discrimination in all forms is both a personal responsibility and the right thing to do.\"\n\n-CNNMoney's Jackie Wattles contributed to this report.", "dateTime": {"id": "9994914", "categories": [{"id": 263, "label": "dmoz/Business/News and Media", "uri": "dmoz/Business/News_and_Media", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 267, "label": "dmoz/Business/Small Business", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Small_Business", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 499, "label": "dmoz/Business/E-Commerce", "uri": "dmoz/Business/E-Commerce", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711714075", "source": {"id": "537", "title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/18/palm-beach-chamber-leader-to-charities-rethink-your-business-with-trump/", "body": "A leader of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which President Trump's Florida resort Mar-a-Lago is a member, wants all charities to do a moral gut check before doing business at the club.\n\n\"Look at your mission statement, and [evaluate] if you still defend Trump...see if this is really the direction you want to go,\" said Laurel Baker, who's been on the executive committee of the chamber of commerce for 17 years.\n\nHer remarks come as the social calendar at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort has been losing some big-ticket events in the backlash against President Trump's response to violent white supremacist rallies in Virginia. Charities and other organizations have started backing out of plans to host events at the Trump-owned property in Palm Beach, Florida.\n\nA chamber of commerce works to promote its members' interests, but Baker says that it's her duty to take a stand when she feels the values of her community are under attack.\n\n\"We're looking for integrity, we're looking for honesty,\" she said.\n\nBaker made similar comments to the Palm Beach Post and then to the Washington Post on Thursday.\n\nSpeaking with CNNMoney on Friday, Baker said the bulk of the reaction she received has been \"very positive.\"\n\nMar-a-Lago declined to comment on Baker's statements. It referred questions to the Trump Organization, which did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nShe said she recognizes her comments run counter to some people's line of thinking: That business and politics don't mix. Baker contends the two \"just can't be separated\" -- particularly in light of this week's events.\n\nAnd some of the biggest names in the private sector haven't shied away from politics either.\n\nProminent business leaders began fleeing from Trump's business advisory councils this week in protest to his response to the white supremacist rally. Trump disbanded two councils amid the outflux.\n\nThough Trump no longer has day-to-day involvement in Mar-a-Lago, which is controlled by the Trump Organization, his sons continue to operate the family business. And, as ethics experts have pointed out, the president stands to eventually reap the benefits of any profits made by those properties.\n\nBased on Trump's latest financial disclosure form from June, Mar-a-Lago has done well for him in the past. In that document, Trump reported $37.2 million in income from Mar-a-Lago between January 2016 and April 2017.\n\nTrump has also made Mar-a-Lago into something of a second office. Since his January inauguration, Trump has spent more than 20 days at the resort and hosted world leaders there, referring to it as the \"winter White House.\"\n\nBaker said she's prepared for criticism.\n\n\"I'm just a gray-haired grandmother,\" she said. \"There's very little fear left in my life.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T00:31:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 2395, "textStart": {"id": "9794460", "categories": [{"id": 3, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical Specialties", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical_Specialties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711163080", "source": {"id": "2955", "title": "Washington Examiner", "uri": "washingtonexaminer.com"}, "url": "http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/cancer-society-moves-2018-gala-from-mar-a-lago/article/2631894", "body": "The American Cancer Society has canceled a gala at President Trump's Mar-a-Lago, joining the Cleveland Clinic, which announced plans Thursday to cancel an annual fundraiser at the Palm Beach, Fla., resort.\n\nThe decision to cancel the Island of Palm Beach gala comes a few days after President Trump said that some of the people that attended a neo-nazi and white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va., last weekend were \"very fine people\" and that \"both sides\" were to blame for the violence. The cancer society refused to comment on whether the cancellation was caused by Trump's statements.\n\n\"When we chose to hold our 2018 event and related dinner at Mar-a-Lago, we selected the venue based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements,\" the cancer society said. \"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nThe society's Palm Beach branch held an event called \"Rock Palm Beach\" at Mar-a-Lago in February.\n\nIt had held events at Mar-a-Lago for the past decade.\n\nThe cancer society is the latest group to pull out of a planned event at the resort. The Cleveland Clinic announced Thursday that it would not host its annual fundraiser gala at the club next year.\n\nOther businesses have been scaling back in the wake of Trump's explosive comments about the Charlottesville violence. Helen Heyer, a 32-year-old counter protester, was killed and 19 people were injured when a man with Nazi sympathies drove his car into a throng of protesters.\n\nTrump's remarks led to a litany of {"id": "10103634", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 505, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 823, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service Clubs", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service_Clubs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1302, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712025663", "source": {"id": "104", "title": "Washington Post", "uri": "washingtonpost.com"}, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/trumps-mar-a-lago-club-loses-its-ninth-big-charity-event-this-week/2017/08/19/8bc21aa2-8513-11e7-ab27-1a21a8e006ab_story.html", "body": "Another Palm Beach charity announced Saturday that it was canceling plans to hold a gala at President Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club -- the ninth to cancel a big-ticket charity event at the club this week.\n\nThe Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach, a charity focused on the ritzy island's architectural landmarks, had planned to hold a dinner dance at Mar-a-Lago next March. The foundation was a new customer for Trump's club, and a potentially lucrative one: It spent $244,000 on rent and food on a previous gala at another site, according to tax filings.\n\nBut on Saturday, the foundation said it would find another venue.\n\n\"Given the current environment surrounding Mar-a-Lago, we have made the decision to move our annual dinner dance,\" Amanda Skier, the foundation's executive director, said in a written statement. She did not say which new venue the foundation would use.\n\nThat decision meant that Trump's club had lost nine of the 16 galas or dinner events that it had been scheduled to host during next winter's social \"season\" in Palm Beach. At least two other groups have also canceled charity luncheons there this week.\n\nThose losses could reduce the club's revenue by hundreds of thousands of dollars by each event, and deny President Trump his dual role as president and host to the island's partying elite. If he returns to the club for weekends next winter, the president could often find its grand ballrooms quiet and empty.\n\nThese cancellations all followed the president's remarks on the march of neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups in Charlottesville, in which the president said their side had included some \"fine people.\"\n\nOn Friday, the Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen joined the growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the club.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast-cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need -- regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions -- and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\n[Three fundraising giants cancel plans for galas at Mar-a-Lago]\n\nTrump's club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past.\n\nBut the cancellations also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe Trump Organization has not responded to requests for comment.\n\nThe charitable groups join three other large event cancellations from Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nSome of the club's most notable local boosters, with long fundraising histories and deep Palm Beach roots, were also in outright rebellion Friday against the club. Lois Pope, a Mar-a-Lago member and philanthropist who heads the Lois Pope Life Foundation and Leaders In Furthering Education, said she had told her foundation's board to move its well-known December gala from the club.\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive,\" Pope wrote in a statement. \"And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\"\n\nOne of the cancellations cut close to home for the Trumps. Big Dog Ranch Rescue said Friday it would no longer hold an upcoming event at the club and would instead move it to the group's facility nearby. Trump's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, was scheduled to co-chair the event.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is not planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post Friday. The local group has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008.\n\nThe Ryan Licht Sang Bipolar Foundation on Friday also announced it had canceled its annual medical briefing luncheon at the club and will move it to another venue.\n\n\"We stand with the community,\" the foundation's co-founder, Dusty Sang, told The Post Friday. \"I think people are standing up for what they believe.\"\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters equally shared the blame for a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T20:12:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", Most of the organizations leaving Mar-a-Lago cite increased security around the club, not politics, as the biggest factor in their decision.\n\nTrump still visits the club regularly after all, so security is tight.\n\nBut that also means it takes longer to get in.\n\nThe Leukemia & Lymphoma Society decided to move its 2018 charity gala for this very reason.\n\nThe nonprofit had held its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago for eight years.\n\nBut the charity said with the tightened security some people only got into the event's silent auction with just 20 minutes left to bid.\n\nSEE MORE: Homeland Security Now Has To Give Up Trump's Mar-A-Lago Visitor Logs But for some nonprofits, Trump's politics may play a role. In January and again in July , a total of nearly 3,500 people signed open letters to the Cleveland Clinic asking it to reconsider its choice of venue for fundraising.\n\nThat most recent letter said hosting the event there supported a politician who was working to \"decrease access to health care\" and cut billions in health care research funding.\n\nOther charities seem to just want to stay out of the president's general sphere of influence.\n\nLast year, the Susan G.\n\nKomen Foundation decided to move its annual fundraising party not because of Trump's politics, but to avoid \"controversies unrelated to our mission.\" Things haven't been all bad for the club since Trump's presidential bid. A report filed in June shows that the club made over $37 million in 2016 and early 2017.\n\nThat's more than double the club's 2015 filings of $15.6 million.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:51:00Z", {"id": "10122770", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 505, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 823, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service Clubs", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service_Clubs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1302, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712086400", "source": {"id": "10395", "title": "HeraldNet.com", "uri": "heraldnet.com"}, "url": "http://www.heraldnet.com/news/trumps-mar-a-lago-club-loses-its-ninth-big-charity-event/", "body": "Another Palm Beach, Florida, charity announced Saturday that it was canceling plans to hold a gala at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club -- the ninth to cancel a big-ticket charity event at the club this week.\n\nThe Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach, a charity focused on the ritzy island's architectural landmarks, had planned to hold a dinner dance at Mar-a-Lago next March. The foundation was a new customer for Trump's club, and a potentially lucrative one: It spent $244,000 on rent and food on a previous gala at another site, according to tax filings.\n\nBut Saturday, the foundation said it would find another venue.\n\n\"Given the current environment surrounding Mar-a-Lago, we have made the decision to move our annual dinner dance,\" said Amanda Skier, the foundation's executive director. She did not say which new venue the foundation would use.\n\nThat decision meant that Trump's club had lost nine of the 16 galas or dinner events that it had been scheduled to host during next winter's social \"season\" in Palm Beach. At least two other groups have also canceled charity luncheons there this week.\n\nThose losses could reduce the club's revenue by hundreds of thousands of dollars by each event, and deny President Trump his dual role as president and host to the island's partying elite. If he returns to the club for weekends next winter, the president could often find its grand ballrooms quiet and empty.\n\nThese cancellations all followed the president's remarks on the march of neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups in Charlottesville, Virginia, in which the president said the protesters, who gathered under the pretense of wanting to preserve a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee, included some \"fine people.\"\n\nOn Friday, the Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen joined the growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the club.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need -- regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions -- and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nTrump's club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past.\n\nBut the cancellations also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe charitable groups join three other large event cancellations from Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nSome of the club's most notable local boosters, with long fundraising histories and deep Palm Beach roots, were also in outright rebellion Friday against the club. Lois Pope, a Mar-a-Lago member and philanthropist who heads the Lois Pope Life Foundation and Leaders In Furthering Education, said she had told her foundation's board to move its well-known December gala from the club.\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive,\" Pope wrote. \"And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\"\n\nOne of the cancellations cut close to home for the Trumps. Big Dog Ranch Rescue said Friday it would no longer hold an upcoming event at the club and would instead move it to the group's facility nearby. Trump's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, was scheduled to co-chair the event.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is not planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto said Friday. The local group has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008.\n\nThe Ryan Licht Sang Bipolar Foundation on Friday also announced it had canceled its annual medical briefing luncheon at the club and will move it to another venue.\n\n\"We stand with the community,\" the foundation's co-founder, Dusty Sang, said Friday. \"I think people are standing up for what they believe.\"\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters equally In one such controversial remark that he made Tuesday, he said both sides were to blame for the outbreak of violence that was reported after white nationalists took to streets against city's decision to remove a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee.\n\nOn Thursday, three philanthropic organizations -- The Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society, and the American Friends of Magen David Adom (AFMDA) -- decided to pull their fundraising events at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, according to multiple reports. The cancellations, which are likely to cut down the revenue for the private club, can be viewed as a direct blowback to Trump's business.\n\nThe mansion has been a venue for such gala events in the past and has earned revenues between $100,000 and $275,000 from such events, Chicago Tribune reported. The president calls the club \"Winter White House.\"\n\nThe mansion with lavish interiors can hold a large crowd of about 700 attendees. Each guest suite is \"exquisitely appointed in keeping with the original character of this lavish estate while assuring the luxury of modern day world-class amenities,\" according to its official website.\n\nAround 21 charities held events at the mansion between November and April during the active social season, ABC News reported citing Palm Beach town records.\n\nThe American Cancer Society has been one of the high-dollar clients at the Mar-a-Lago Club since 2009. Referring to the decision to pull out its fundraising gala from the club, the organization cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in a statement, according to several reports.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, one of the nation's leading medical centers, also decided against holding its winter event in the club. Earlier, it had said it planned to continue the business with the club, reports said.\n\nAFMDA, which is Israel's national ambulance, blood-services, and disaster-relief organization, also said that it had decided not to hold its 2018 gala at Mar-a-Lago \"after considerable deliberation.\" The charity held a huge event at the club last season with about 600 people attending it, reports said.\n\nThe Mar-a-Lago Club has also been a protest venue for the groups that are against Trump's policies and statements. For instance, in January, the American Red Cross faced criticism when protesters rallied outside its annual fundraiser at the club. The charity organization held the event to help people affected by Trump's U.S. refugee program, ABC News reported. fundraisers at the \"Winter White House.\" Kravis Center would hold its annual wine auction at the Mar-a-Lago, a report said. \"The event has been held there for a number of years, and the folks {"id": "9997089", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 263, "label": "dmoz/Business/News and Media", "uri": "dmoz/Business/News_and_Media", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 267, "label": "dmoz/Business/Small Business", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Small_Business", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711720517", "source": {"id": "2128", "title": "erienewsnow.com", "uri": "erienewsnow.com"}, "url": "http://www.erienewsnow.com/story/36170808/palm-beach-chamber-leader-to-charities-rethink-your-business-with-trump", "body": "NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- A leader of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which President Trump's Florida resort Mar-a-Lago is a member, wants all charities to do a moral gut check before doing business at the club.\n\n\"Look at your mission statement, and [evaluate] if you still defend Trump...see if this is really the direction you want to go,\" said Laurel Baker, who's been on the executive committee of the chamber of commerce for 17 years.\n\nHer remarks come as the social calendar at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort has been losing some big-ticket events in the backlash against President Trump's response to violent white supremacist rallies in Virginia. Charities and other organizations have started backing out of plans to host events at the Trump-owned property in Palm Beach, Florida.\n\nA chamber of commerce works to promote its members' interests, but Baker says that it's her duty to take a stand when she feels the values of her community are under attack.\n\n\"We're looking for integrity, we're looking for honesty,\" she said.\n\nBaker made similar comments to the Palm Beach Post and then to the Washington Post on Thursday.\n\nSpeaking with CNNMoney on Friday, Baker said the bulk of the reaction she received has been \"very positive.\"\n\nMar-a-Lago declined to comment on Baker's statements. It referred questions to the Trump Organization, which did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nShe said she recognizes her comments run counter to some people's line of thinking: That business and politics don't mix. Baker contends the two \"just can't be separated\" -- particularly in light of this week's events.\n\nAnd some of the biggest names in the private sector haven't shied away from politics either.\n\nProminent business leaders began fleeing from Trump's business advisory councils this week in protest to his response to the white supremacist rally. Trump disbanded two councils amid the outflux.\n\nThough Trump no longer has day-to-day involvement in Mar-a-Lago, which is controlled by the Trump Organization, his sons continue to operate the family business. And, as ethics experts have pointed out, the president stands to eventually reap the benefits of any profits made by those properties.\n\nBased on Trump's latest financial disclosure form from June, Mar-a-Lago has done well for him in the past. In that document, Trump reported $37.2 million in income from Mar-a-Lago between January 2016 and April 2017.\n\nTrump has also made Mar-a-Lago into something of a second office. Since his January inauguration, Trump has spent more than 20 days at the resort and hosted world leaders there, referring to it as the \"winter White House.\"\n\nBaker said she's prepared for criticism.\n\n\"I'm just a gray-haired grandmother,\" she said. \"There's very little fear left in my life.\"\n\nTM & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. {"id": "9968542", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 17, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 703, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Volunteering", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Volunteering", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 705, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Race-Ethnic-Religious Relations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Race-Ethnic-Religious_Relations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1201, "label": "dmoz/Health/Support Groups", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Support_Groups", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711636964", "source": {"id": "2128", "title": "erienewsnow.com", "uri": "erienewsnow.com"}, "url": "http://www.erienewsnow.com/story/36168995/in-their-words-why-charities-are-walking-away-from-trump", "body": "NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- Prominent charities are canceling events at Mar-a-Lago, President Trump's resort in Florida.\n\nThey follow business leaders who distanced themselves from Trump this week after he insisted that counter-protesters shared blame for the violence at a deadly white supremacist gathering in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nHere's what the charities have to say about the change of plans.\n\nThe American Red Cross\n\n\"The American Red Cross has decided we cannot host our annual fundraising event at Mar-a-Lago, as it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters. We believe this action will allow us to continue to put the focus on our lifesaving mission and the people we serve. The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nThe Salvation Army\n\n\"The Salvation Army relies heavily on fundraising events like The Holiday Snow Ball in Palm Beach to further our mission of helping those in need through a range of social services including food for the hungry, relief for disaster victims, clothing and shelter for the homeless, and opportunities for the underprivileged. Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\nThe American Cancer Society\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\n\n\"With our volunteer leaders, we are exploring other opportunities and potential venues. The generous support of community volunteers and donors are critical to our life-saving mission. Only by coming together will we solve our society's most difficult challenges, including reducing the pain and suffering from cancer.\"\n\nCleveland Clinic\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018. We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nLeaders in Furthering Education (LIFE)\n\nThe organization's president, Lois Pope, is urging the board to abandon Mar-a-Lago for a gala in December. Pope said:\n\n\"America was founded on the principles of life, liberty and justice for all. In the 241 years since, millions of Americans of all religions, races, creeds, color, gender and sexual orientation have died -- and millions more have been disabled -- fighting to protect these values and freedoms.\n\n\"Now, however, our great nation is under siege by those who seek to undermine and obliterate these principles. Indeed, the hatred, vitriol and Anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by Neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive -- and they are antithetical to everything that this country, and I personally stand for. And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\n\n\"Therefore, I am recommending to my board that we move this year's 24th Annual Lady in Red Gala on December 2 -- the proceeds of which benefit those very millions of men and women of all persuasions who have fought with courage and sacrifice in defense of America's ideals -- from the Mar-A-Lago Club.\n\n\"I want my children, grandchildren and great grandson to know that standing up to hatred and discrimination in all forms is both a personal responsibility and the right thing to do.\"\n\n--CNNMoney's Jackie Wattles contributed to this report.\n\nTM & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. Komen Foundation, the American Red Cross and the Salvation Army all confirmed to ABC News that they are no longer going to be holding their fundraising events at Mar-a-Lago this upcoming year.\n\n\"The Salvation Army relies heavily on fundraising events like The Holiday Snow Ball in Palm Beach to further our mission of helping those in need through a range of social services including food for the hungry, relief for disaster victims, clothing and shelter for the homeless, and opportunities for the underprivileged,\" the Salvation Army wrote in a statement, \"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\nYesterday, the American Cancer Society -- which has held events at Mar-a-Lago since 2009 -- along with the Cleveland Clinic, both announced they were pulling fundraising events scheduled at the club for next year.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations,\" the American Cancer Society wrote in a statement.\n\nThese organizations join a growing list of groups that are changing the venues for their fundraising events, many saying they want to avoid being politicized.\n\nThe Dana Farber Cancer Institute and Leaders in Furthering Education (LIFE), have also said they are changing venues for events previously scheduled at Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"America was founded on the principles of life, liberty and justice for all. In the 241 years since, millions of Americans of all religions, races, creeds, color, gender and sexual orientation have died - and millions more have been disabled - fighting to protect these values and freedoms. Now, however, our great nation is under siege by those who seek to undermine and obliterate these principles. Indeed, the hatred, vitriol and Anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by Neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive -- and they are antithetical to everything that this country, and I personally stand for,\" Lois Pope, a philanthropist and veterans advocate who founded LIFE, wrote in a statement provided to ABC News.\n\nOther groups that have pulled events from Mar-a-Lago include the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, American Friends of Magen David Adom and the Bascom Palmer Eye Institute.\n\nThe Leukemia & Lymphoma Society cited the security hassles of hosting an event at Mar-a-Lago as a reason for their switching venues.\n\nPalm Beach Chamber of Commerce executive director Laurel Baker, who has been outspoken on organizations continuing to hold fundraising events at Mar-a-Lago, told ABC News: \"I've been carrying around this quote with me for a while, it's from Dante: 'The darkest places in hell are reserved for those who maintain their neutrality in times of moral crisis.'\"\n\nBaker also told ABC News that she expects more and more organizations will be pulling events in the coming weeks, but that those decisions are best left up to the organizations "dmoz/Business/Employment/Job_Search", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711542040", "source": {"id": "7469", "title": "DiversityInc", "uri": "diversityinc.com"}, "url": "http://www.diversityinc.com/news/major-charities-pull-events-trumps-mar-lago/", "body": "\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" American Cancer Society spokeswoman Miriam Falco said.\n\nThe lure of reaching Palm Beach high society when hosting a fundraiser at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago club has been trumped by the president's response to last weekend's deadly events in Charlottesville, Va., as major charities are now taking their business elsewhere.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic (on the 2017 DiversityInc Top Hospitals and Health Systems list), the American Cancer Society and the American Friends of Magen David Adom are no longer hosting their upcoming 2018 events at Trump's Palm Beach estate.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" American Cancer Society spokeswoman Miriam Falco said. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nTwo 2018 events -- its 60th anniversary gala and a dinner for sponsors -- will not be held at the club.\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom (AFMDA), which raises money for an ambulance service in Israel, has been holding its annual gala at the resort since 2012.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago,\" Erik Levis, spokesman of organization, said in a statement.\n\nAFDA's gala in February 2016 featured more than 600 attendees who paid $650 per ticket, according to The Palm Beach Post.\n\nFor the past eight years, the Cleveland Clinic has hosted its annual event at Mar-a-Lago. Gloria Tavera is a Case Western Reserve University medical student who helped spearhead the petition against using Trump's Palm Beach estate as a venue.\n\nTavera commented to Cleveland.com that the Clinic didn't change venues when immigration and health care were the pressing issues, but \"Charlottesville was the one that broke the camel's back.\"\n\nTrump did an about-face from his scripted comments on Monday denouncing bigotry, racism and anti-Semitism. In remarks to the press on Tuesday, Trump doubled down on his sentiment that the actions of neo-Nazis in Charlottesville were ethically equal to the people protesting neo-Nazis, which he originally implied in his \"many sides\" comment on Saturday.\n\nFormer Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke thanked Trump on Tuesday via Twitter for his \"honesty and courage.\"\n\nThe exit of charities from Mar-a-Lago also follows Wednesday's decision by CEOs of some of the nation's leading corporations to disband Trump's business advisory council.\n\nLaurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, urged other charitable organizations that are not withdrawing from Mar-a-Lago, and their donors, to seek another venue.\n\n\"If you have a conscience, you're really condoning bad behavior by continuing to be there,\" Baker said. \"Many say it's the dollars [raised at the events] that count. Yes. But the integrity of any or organization rests on their sound decisions and stewardship.\n\n\"Personally, I do not feel that supporting him, directly or indirectly, speaks well of any organization.\"\n\nMar-a-Lago Seeks to Hire Foreign Nationals\n\nThe Mar-a-Lago club also represents some of the double standards of the Trump administration. Trump has said that immigrants are taking jobs from native workers.\n\nIn July, during \"Made in America Week,\" BuzzFeed first reported that the club requested 70 visas to hire foreign nationals this fall -- 35 waiters, 20 cooks and 15 housekeepers. Trump's golf club in Jupiter, Fla., asked permission to hire six foreign workers as cooks. If approved, the workers at both Trump-owned locations would fill the jobs between this October and May 2018.\n\nH-2B visa nonimmigrant program permits employers to hire foreign workers to come temporarily to the U.S. and perform temporary nonagricultural services or labor on a one-time, seasonal, peak load or intermittent basis.\n\nApplications for H-2B visa workers are allowed when \"there are not enough U.S. workers who are able, willing, qualified and available to do the temporary work,\" according to the Department of Homeland Security.\n\nSo, last month, the club placed an ad on page C8 of the Palm Beach Post in tiny print stating: \"3 mos recent & verifiable exp in fine dining/country club,\" and \"No tips.\"\n\nThe ad included no phone number or email address. \"Apply by fax,\" it said, and provided a mailing address. The ad only ran twice.\n\nOn the campaign trail, Trump blamed immigrants for the lack of jobs available to nonwhite voters and working-class Americans.\n\nIn July 2015 at a rally in Phoenix, he accused Mexicans of taking jobs.\n\n\"They're taking our jobs,\" he said. \"They're taking our manufacturing jobs. They're taking our money. They're killing us.\"\n\nLast year, The New York Times reported that U.S. residents are less likely to be hired at Mar-a-Lago:\n\n\"Since 2010, nearly 300 United States residents have applied or been referred for jobs as waiters, waitresses, cooks and housekeepers there. But according to federal records, only 17 have been hired.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T16:18:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 3820, "textStart": 3800, "date": "2018-10-", "dateEnd": "2018-05-", {"id": "9806547", "categories": [{"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 792, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Water Sports/Swimming and Diving", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Water_Sports/Swimming_and_Diving", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 823, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service Clubs", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service_Clubs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711201776", "source": {"id": "8940", "title": "Newsy", "uri": "newsy.com"}, "url": "https://www.newsy.com/stories/2-more-nonprofits-moving-fundraisers-from-mar-a-lago/", "body": "Two major nonprofits dropped President Trump's Mar-a-Lago club from their fundraising plans next year.\n\nBoth the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society announced Thursday they wouldn't be holding their annual galas at the club in 2018.\n\nAnd they're not alone in that decision. After Trump announced his run for president in 2015, more events have left Mar-a-Lago than the club has gained.\n\nMost of the organizations leaving Mar-a-Lago cite increased security around the club, not politics, as the biggest factor in their decision. Trump still visits the club regularly after all, so security is tight. But that also means it takes longer to get in.\n\nThe Leukemia & Lymphoma Society decided to move its 2018 charity gala for this very reason. The nonprofit had held its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago for eight years. But the charity said with the tightened security some people only got into the event's silent auction with just 20 minutes left to bid.\n\nBut for some nonprofits, Trump's politics may play a role. In January and again in July, a total of nearly 3,500 people signed open letters to the Cleveland Clinic asking it to reconsider its choice of venue for fundraising.\n\nThat most recent letter said hosting the event there supported a politician who was working to \"decrease access to health care\" and cut billions in health care research funding.\n\nOther charities seem to just want to stay out of the president's general sphere of influence. Last year, the Susan G. Komen Foundation decided to move its annual fundraising party not because of Trump's politics, but to avoid \"controversies unrelated to our mission.\"\n\nThings haven't been all bad for the club since Trump's presidential bid. A report filed in June shows that the club made over $37 million in 2016 and early 2017.
