We believe this action will allow us to continue to put the focus on our lifesaving mission and the people we serve. The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nThe Salvation Army\n\n\"The Salvation Army relies heavily on fundraising events like The Holiday Snow Ball in Palm Beach to further our mission of helping those in need through a range of social services including food for the hungry, relief for disaster victims, clothing and shelter for the homeless, and opportunities for the underprivileged. Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago.\"\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\n\n\"With our volunteer leaders, we are exploring other opportunities and potential venues. The generous support of community volunteers and donors are critical to our life-saving mission. Only by coming together will we solve our society's most difficult challenges, including reducing the pain and suffering from cancer.\"\n\nCleveland Clinic\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018. We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nLeaders in Furthering Education (LIFE)\n\nThe organization's president, Lois Pope, is urging the board to abandon Mar-a-Lago for a gala in December. Pope said:\n\n\"America was founded on the principles of life, liberty and justice for all. In the 241 years since, millions of Americans of all religions, races, creeds, color, gender and sexual orientation have died -- and millions more have been disabled -- fighting to protect these values and freedoms.\n\n\"Now, however, our great nation is under siege by those who seek to undermine and obliterate these principles. Indeed, the hatred, vitriol and Anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by Neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive -- and they are antithetical to everything that this country, and I personally stand for. And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\n\n\"Therefore, I am recommending to my board that we move this year's 24th Annual Lady in Red Gala on December 2 -- the proceeds of which benefit those very millions of men and women of all persuasions who have fought with courage and sacrifice in defense of America's ideals -- from the Mar-A-Lago Club.\n\n\"I want my children, grandchildren and great grandson to know that standing His advisory councils collapsed. Some of his customers said they won't give him their business anymore.\n\nTrump's Treasury secretary got called out by his fellow Yale Class of '85 graduates. His friend Carl Icahn, one of Trump's earliest supporters from Wall Street, said he will no longer serve as a special adviser on regulatory issues.\n\nEven a member of the Palm Beach chamber of commerce, which counts Trump's Mar-a-Lago club as a member, called on charities to consult their mission statements before deciding to do business with Trump.\n\nOh, and the stock market, which has performed well since Trump was elected, did lousy. Investors are afraid.\n\nOf course, the pushback Trump got from business came because of his response to the violent protests in Charlottesville, Virginia last weekend.\n\nIt was that kind of week. It's understandable if you lost track. Here's how it all went down.\n\nMonday, August 14\n\n--8 a.m. ET: Merck CEO Ken Frazier, one of very few black Fortune 500 CEOs, takes the first step. He steps down from President Trump's manufacturing council, saying \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\n--On Tuesday afternoon, Trump gives a news conference inside Trump Tower. He reiterates his earlier position that he believes \"there is blame on both sides\" of last weekend's violence on the University of Virginia campus.\n\n--5:45 p.m.: Richard Trumka, president of the labor group AFL-CIO, and Thea Lee, economist at the AFL-CIO, resign from the manufacturing council.\n\n--Late Wednesday morning, Blackstone CEO Steve Schwarzman, the head of Trump's Strategic and Policy Forum, reportedly held a conference call with the members, who came to a collective decision to dissolve and started drafting a public statement.\n\n--1:14 p.m.: Trump tweets, announcing he was dissolving both the manufacturing council and economic advisory council: \"Rather than putting pressure on the businesspeople of the Manufacturing Council & Strategy & Policy Forum, I am ending both. Thank you all!\"\n\n--1:20 p.m.: United Technologies CEO Greg Hayes puts out a statement, explaining his exit from the manufacturing council.\n\n--1:30 p.m.: Alex Gorsky, CEO of Johnson & Johnson, releases a statement about why he resigned.\n\n--2 p.m.: General Electric's Jeff Immelt issues a statement on his decision to leave the council.\n\n--4:30 p.m.: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg writes a post condemning hate groups but doesn't mention Trump by name.\n\n--Late Wednesday night, Apple CEO Tim Cook sends a letter to employees, rejecting Trump's remarks on Charlottesville.\n\nThursday, August 17\n\n--1:15 p.m.: Cleveland Clinic, a hospital system, backs out of plans to host a fundraiser at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. It doesn't give a reason for the decision.\n\n--4 p.m.: American Cancer Society becomes the second organization to cancel plans for an event at Mar-a-Lago. The charity says using Trump property presented a \"challenge\" to its \"values.\"\n\n--7:30 p.m.: Another organization, American Friends of Magen David Adom, pulls a fundraising event from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--Throughout the day, three top magazines -- Time, The Economist and the New Yorker -- post snapshots of their latest magazine covers. Each lampooned Trump's response to Charlottesville.\n\n--Late Thursday, a scathing letter criticizing Trump written by 21st Century Fox CEO James Murdoch, is made public. He is the son of Trump confidante Rupert Murdoch.\n\n-- Late Thursday, a leader of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which President Trump's Florida resort Mar-a-Lagowants, says all charities should do a moral gut check before doing business at the club.\n\nFriday, August 18\n\n--12:30 p.m.: The American Red Cross cancels plans to hold its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--1 p.m.: The Salvation Army says it won't host its holiday gala at Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--1:30 p.m.: Susan G. Komen, a breast cancer organization, pulls event from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--2 p.m.: The head of Leaders in Furthering Education, another philanthropic group, urges the foundation's board to move its fundraiser from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--3:40 p.m.: Two authors of Letter to Steve Mnuchin, signed by more than 340 members of the '85 Yale Graduating class, appear on CNN to discuss their argument that classmate and Trump's Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin should resign.\n\n-- 4 p.m.: Billionaire Carl Icahn, a longtime friend of Trump, posts a letter announcing he would no longer serve as a special adviser to the president. {"id": "9785114", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 263, "label": "dmoz/Business/News and Media", "uri": "dmoz/Business/News_and_Media", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711136639", "source": {"id": "1378", "title": "Portland Press Herald", "uri": "pressherald.com"}, "url": "http://www.pressherald.com/2017/08/17/the-american-cancer-society-cleveland-clinic-cancel-plans-for-galas-at-mar-a-lago/", "body": "The head of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which the resort is a member, urges other charities to follow suit.\n\nTwo leading charities said they were pulling their business from President Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach on Thursday amid blowback over Trump's comments on Charlottesville's bloody unrest.\n\nThe head of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which Mar-a-Lago is a member, also called the president's business \"morally reprehensible\" on Thursday and said she expected more charities to defect.\n\n\"The glitter, the shine has gone from the club,\" said Laurel Baker, executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, \"and I can't help but think there will be more fallout from it.\"\n\nThe rapid rejections of one of the president's signature businesses revealed a key vulnerability for Trump, who has been fiercely criticized this week for equating the actions of white supremacists and neo-Nazis with protesters during a violent weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nA number of other groups - including the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society in New York and Bascom Palmer Eye Institute in Miami - have all announced in recent months that they would choose other venues.\n\nThe White House referred questions to the Trump Organization, which did not immediately respond.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, one of the nation's top-ranked medical centers, abruptly canceled its plans Thursday to host a fundraising gala at Mar-a-Lago in the coming year. Company spokeswoman Eileen Sheil told The Post on Thursday that \"there were a variety of factors\" behind the cancellation, but she added, \"We're not elaborating.\"\n\nShortly after, the American Cancer Society, another long-time charity customer of the club, said it would pull its own event and explore \"other opportunities and potential venues.\"\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the group said in a statement. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nBoth health-related groups faced growing pressure to rethink their support of the president's business amid numerous controversies. But the cancellations don't come without risk: The Cleveland Clinic said it had raised about $1 million a year for medical equipment over the last eight years at Mar-a-Lago.\n\nMar-a-Lago's 2017-2018 season now looks like it will be the slowest period for charity events in at least a decade, according to a Washington Post analysis of upcoming events. It's unclear how much the cancellations could cost the club, though similar-sized events brought in fees of between $100,000 and $275,000.\n\nTrump's comments also appear to have helped turn the Palm Beach business community against one of its most opulent venues.\n\nBaker, head of the Palm Beach chamber, spoke vigorously against Mar-a-Lago on Thursday, saying that her directive to nearby charities was, \"If you're looking at your mission statement, can you honestly say having an event at Mar-a-Lago, given all that has transpired, is the best stewardship of your efforts?\"\n\n\"The club is a member of the chamber. But right is right,\" she added in an interview with The Post. \"My mantra this week is from Dante: 'The darkest places in hell are reserved for those who maintain their neutrality in times of moral crisis.' Especially for nonprofits. Especially for groups who help people who can't help themselves.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic's cancellation was an abrupt change, and the hospital system had still intended to host its ninth gala there as recently as last week. The move followed weeks of public turmoil, including a letter signed by 1,600 health professionals and others last month that said the Mar-a-Lago booking \"symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to healthcare.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic's chief executive, Toby Cosgrove, was among the business leaders on the president's Strategic and Policy Forum that agreed to disband on Wednesday. As members of the group resigned, Trump said on Twitter that he would end the forum and a separate American Manufacturing Council \"rather than putting pressure on the businesspeople.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic was ranked the nation's second-best hospital this month by U.S. News & World Report, which gave top honors to its urology, cardiology and heart surgery units.\n\nNearly 550 people visited the hospital's February fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago, where the theme was \"Reflections of Versailles.\"\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? {"id": "10003383", "categories": [{"id": 521, "label": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "uri": "dmoz/Computers/Systems/Handhelds", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1089, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Clubs and Venues", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Clubs_and_Venues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711738870", "source": {"id": "133", "title": "Houston Chronicle", "uri": "chron.com"}, "url": "http://www.chron.com/homes/article/More-major-charities-canceling-events-at-Trump-s-11942296.php", "body": "At least three more major charities have canceled events at President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach amid his controversial remarks regarding the violence that erupted at a Charlottesville, Va. protest. Trump said at a press conference that \"both sides\" were to blame at the rally.\n\nThe American Cancer Society announced in a statement Thursday that it would no longer hold its upcoming fundraising gala in Trump's gilded ballroom. In a statement, the ACA said, in part:\n\n\"When we chose to hold our 2018 event and related dinner at Mar-a-Lago, we selected the venue based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements.\n\nOur values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community. It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nThe ACA has not yet chosen a new venue: \"With our volunteer leaders, we are exploring other opportunities and potential venues. The generous support of community volunteers and donors are critical to our life-saving mission. Only by coming together will we solve our society's most difficult challenges, including reducing the pain and suffering from cancer.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, a prominent academic medical center based in Ohio, has also announced that it would no longer have its upcoming fundraiser at the resort but did not elaborate on the decision. However, it was still scheduled to host attendees at Mar-a-Lago as recently as last week, according to the Post.\n\nLater on the same day, a spokesperson for the American Friends of Magen David Adom, an organization that works to raise funds for an ambulance service in Israel, said their annual gala would not be held at Mar-a-Lago this year. The association has held its fundraising formals there since 2012.\n\nTRUMP IN TEXAS: Trump to headline Dallas GOP fundraiser\n\nThe palatial waterfront property, which Trump has referred to as the \"winter White House,\" has been receiving cancellations for upcoming 2017 and 2018 events since earlier this year.\n\nThe Dana-Farber Cancer Institute told the Palm Beach Daily News that it would move its fundraiser to The Breakers, another waterfront resort in Palm Beach, Fla. Members of the organization and its hosting committee claim the decision was not politically motivated.\n\n\"There are a lot of reasons to pick a venue: it's convenient, it feels relevant, there are high-net-worth individuals or potential donors are associated with that particular venue, it accommodates the number of guests that you are going to host, it's beautiful,\" Greg Propper, co-president of social impact agency Propper Daley, told Town & Country magazine, adding that \"the venue should do no harm.\"\n\nUNHEALTHY CODES: Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago kitchen had more than a dozen health code violations\n\nThe Palm Beach Daily News also reports that MorseLife moved its event, scheduled for Dec. 8, to The Breakers. The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society is also moving its Jan. 27, 2018 to The Breakers. Miami-based Bascom Palmer Eye Institute will move one of its events to that same resort, and another to Club Colette, a private Palm Springs supper club.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T20:47:00Z", {"id": "10124333", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 505, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 823, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service Clubs", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service_Clubs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1302, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712091674", "source": {"id": "9061", "title": "Duluth Budgeteer News", "uri": "duluthnewstribune.com"}, "url": "http://www.duluthnewstribune.com/news/4314958-trumps-mar-lago-club-loses-its-ninth-big-charity-event-week", "body": "The Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach, a charity focused on the ritzy island's architectural landmarks, had planned to hold a dinner dance at Mar-a-Lago next March. The foundation was a new customer for Trump's club, and a potentially lucrative one: It spent $244,000 on rent and food on a previous gala at another site, according to tax filings.\n\nBut on Saturday, the foundation said it would find another venue.\n\n\"Given the current environment surrounding Mar-a-Lago, we have made the decision to move our annual dinner dance,\" Amanda Skier, the foundation's executive director, said in a written statement. She did not say which new venue the foundation would use.\n\nThat decision meant that Trump's club had lost nine of the 16 galas or dinner events that it had been scheduled to host during next winter's social \"season\" in Palm Beach. At least two other groups have also canceled charity luncheons there this week.\n\nThose losses could reduce the club's revenue by hundreds of thousands of dollars by each event, and deny President Trump his dual role as president and host to the island's partying elite. If he returns to the club for weekends next winter, the president could often find its grand ballrooms quiet and empty.\n\nThese cancellations all followed the president's remarks on the march of neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups in Charlottesville, Virginia, in which the president said the protesters, who gathered under the pretense of wanting to preserve a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee, included some \"fine people.\"\n\nOn Friday, the Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen joined the growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the club.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need - regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions - and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nTrump's club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past.\n\nBut the cancellations also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe Trump Organization has not responded to requests for comment.\n\nThe charitable groups join three other large event cancellations from Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nSome of the club's most notable local boosters, with long fundraising histories and deep Palm Beach roots, were also in outright rebellion Friday against the club. Lois Pope, a Mar-a-Lago member and philanthropist who heads the Lois Pope Life Foundation and Leaders In Furthering Education, said she had told her foundation's board to move its well-known December gala from the club.\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive,\" Pope wrote in a statement. \"And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\"\n\nOne of the cancellations cut close to home for the Trumps. Big Dog Ranch Rescue said Friday it would no longer hold an upcoming event at the club and would instead move it to the group's facility nearby. Trump's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, was scheduled to co-chair the event.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is not planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post on Friday. The local group has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008.\n\nThe Ryan Licht Sang Bipolar Foundation on Friday also announced it had canceled its annual medical briefing luncheon at the club and will move it to another venue.\n\n\"We stand with the community,\" the foundation's co-founder, Dusty Sang, told The Post Friday. \"I think people are standing up for what they believe.\"\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters equally shared the blame for a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.", "dateTime": "2017-08-20T01:31:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-20", {"id": "10106497", "categories": [{"id": 253, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Christianity", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Christianity", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 258, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Scouting/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Scouting/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712034898", "source": {"id": "537", "title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "uri": "gantdaily.com"}, "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/19/president-trumps-very-bad-week-with-business-a-timeline/", "body": "The businessman president had a really bad week with the business world.\n\nCEOs bolted. His advisory councils collapsed. Some of his customers said they won't give him their business anymore.\n\nTrump's Treasury secretary got called out by his fellow Yale Class of '85 graduates. His friend Carl Icahn, one of Trump's earliest supporters from Wall Street, said he will no longer serve as a special adviser on regulatory issues.\n\nEven a member of the Palm Beach chamber of commerce, which counts Trump's Mar-a-Lago club as a member, called on charities to consult their mission statements before deciding to do business with Trump.\n\nOh, and the stock market, which has performed well since Trump was elected, did lousy. Investors are afraid.\n\nOf course, the pushback Trump got from business came because of his response to the violent protests in Charlottesville, Virginia last weekend.\n\nIt was that kind of week. It's understandable if you lost track. Here's how it all went down.\n\nMonday, August 14\n\n-8 a.m. ET: Merck CEO Ken Frazier, one of very few black Fortune 500 CEOs, takes the first step. He steps down from President Trump's manufacturing council, saying \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\n-8:54 a.m.: Trump tweets that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\n-1 p.m.: The president delivers a speech in which he calls the KKK, neo-Nazis and white supremacists 'repugnant.'\n\n-8:14 p.m.: Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank resigns from the manufacturing council.\n\n-11:37 a.m.: Scott Paul, president of Alliance for American Manufacturing, resigns from the Trump council.\n\n-On Tuesday afternoon, Trump gives a news conference inside Trump Tower. He reiterates his earlier position that he believes \"there is blame on both sides\" of last weekend's violence on the University of Virginia campus.\n\n-5:45 p.m.: Richard Trumka, president of the labor group AFL-CIO, and Thea Lee, economist at the AFL-CIO, resign from the manufacturing council.\n\n-Late Wednesday morning, Blackstone CEO Steve Schwarzman, the head of Trump's Strategic and Policy Forum, reportedly held a conference call with the members, who came to a collective decision to dissolve and started drafting a public statement.\n\n-1:14 p.m.: Trump tweets, announcing he was dissolving both the manufacturing council and economic advisory council: \"Rather than putting pressure on the businesspeople of the Manufacturing Council & Strategy & Policy Forum, I am ending both. Thank you all!\"\n\n-1:20 p.m.: United Technologies CEO Greg Hayes puts out a statement, explaining his exit from the manufacturing council.\n\n-1:30 p.m.: Alex Gorsky, CEO of Johnson & Johnson, releases a statement about why he resigned.\n\n-2 p.m.: General Electric's Jeff Immelt issues a statement on his decision to leave the council.\n\n-4:30 p.m.: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg writes a post condemning hate groups but doesn't mention Trump by name.\n\n-Late Wednesday night, Apple CEO Tim Cook sends a letter to employees, rejecting Trump's remarks on Charlottesville.\n\nThursday, August 17\n\n-1:15 p.m.: Cleveland Clinic, a hospital system, backs out of plans to host a fundraiser at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. It doesn't give a reason for the decision.\n\n-4 p.m.: American Cancer Society becomes the second organization to cancel plans for an event at Mar-a-Lago. The charity says using Trump property presented a \"challenge\" to its \"values.\"\n\n-7:30 p.m.: Another organization, American Friends of Magen David Adom, pulls a fundraising event from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n-Throughout the day, three top magazines -- Time, The Economist and the New Yorker -- post snapshots of their latest magazine covers. Each lampooned Trump's response to Charlottesville.\n\n-Late Thursday, a scathing letter criticizing Trump written by 21st Century Fox CEO James Murdoch, is made public. He is the son of Trump confidante Rupert Murdoch.\n\n-- Late Thursday, a leader of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which President Trump's Florida resort Mar-a-Lagowants, says all charities should do a moral gut check before doing business at the club.\n\nFriday, August 18\n\n-12:30 p.m.: The American Red Cross cancels plans to hold its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago.\n\n-1 p.m.: The Salvation Army says it won't host its holiday gala at Mar-a-Lago.\n\n-1:30 p.m.: Susan G. Komen, a breast cancer organization, pulls event from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n-2 p.m.: The head of Leaders in Furthering Education, another philanthropic group, urges the foundation's board to move its fundraiser from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n-3:40 p.m.: Two authors of Letter to Steve Mnuchin, signed by more than 340 members of the '85 Yale Graduating class, appear on CNN to discuss their argument that classmate and Trump's Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin should resign.\n\n-- 4 p.m.: Billionaire Carl Icahn, a longtime friend of Trump, posts a letter announcing he would no longer serve as a special adviser to the president. He said he wanted to avoid becoming a partisan distraction.\n\n-- CNNMoney's Olivia Chang, Jill Disis, Julia Horowitz and Shen Lu contributed to this report.", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T20:50:00Z", The American Cancer Society, which has held galas at the club since at least 2009, cited its \"values and commitment to diversity,\" The Washington Post reports, while the Cleveland Clinic told the Post \"there were a variety of factors\" behind its decision, adding, \"We're not elaborating.\" Similarly, AFMDA said it canceled its 2018 charity ball -- one of the biggest events at Mar-a-Lago last season -- \"after careful deliberation.\"\n\nThese cancelations, after Trump appeared to defend white supremacists, will certainly affect Mar-a-Lago's bottom line, the Post reports, noting that similar events brought in fees ranging from $100,000 to $275,000 apiece. The executive director of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, Laurel Baker, said she \"can't help but think there will be more fallout\" for Trump's \"morally reprehensible\" club, which is a member of her organization. \"The glitter, the shine has gone from the club,\" she said, adding: \"The club is a member of the chamber. But right is right.\" There are still 13 big-ticket galas scheduled for Mar-a-Lago, notes the Post's David Fahrenthold, but at least seven major charities that typically hold events at Mar-a-Lago decided in recent months to look elsewhere, avoiding the need to cancel their galas. By Friday, seven groups had canceled events.\n\nOther organizations backing out include the Autism Project of Palm Beach County, the Salvation Army, Susan G. Komen, the American Red Cross, and American Friends of Magen David Adom, an Israeli EMS and blood bank provider, according to a tally by The Washington Post's David Fahrenthold.\n\nUPDATED: list of charities holding galas at @realDonaldTrump's Mar-a-Lago next yr. Seven have gone from yes to no. pic.twitter.com/vj5ouSqYWr -- David Fahrenthold (@Fahrenthold)\n\nAugust 18, 2017\n\nThe mass exodus follows a week in which Trump repeatedly declined to condemn white supremacists who descended on Charlottesville, Virginia, and provoked deadly violence there.\n\n\"You have people who are very fine people on both sides,\" Trump said on Tuesday, equating counterprotesters to marchers who carried torches, Confederate and Nazi flags and shouted racist, anti-Semitic and homophobic epithets.\n\n\"The American Red Cross has decided we cannot host our annual fundraising event at Mar-a-Lago, as it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the organization explained in a statement on Friday.\n\n\"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle,\" it concluded.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which hosted a \"Holiday Snow Ball\" at Mar-a-Lago, said it's leaving because the venue distracts from the nonprofit's mission of \"helping those in need.\"\n\n\"Because the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event, we will not host it at Mar-a-Lago,\" the organization explained in a statement.\n\nNumerous business leaders, politicians and artists have already scrambled to disassociate themselves from Trump, and the list of groups bailing on Mar-a-Lago will likely grow.\n\nLeaders In Furthering Education, for instance, is still tentatively holding its Dec. 2 gala at the resort. But on Friday, the group's president, Lois Pope, penned a blistering statement urging the board to find a new venue.\n\n\"Indeed, the hatred, vitriol and Anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by Neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive -- and they are antithetical to everything that this country, and I personally stand for,\" Pope wrote.\n\n\"Anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations,\" she added.", "dateTime": {"id": "10106230", "categories": [{"id": 253, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Christianity", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Christianity", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 258, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Scouting/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Scouting/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712033406", "source": {"id": "2128", "title": "erienewsnow.com", "uri": "erienewsnow.com"}, "url": "http://www.erienewsnow.com/story/36173579/president-trumps-very-bad-week-with-business-a-timeline", "body": "NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- The businessman president had a really bad week with the business world.\n\nCEOs bolted. His advisory councils collapsed. Some of his customers said they won't give him their business anymore.\n\nTrump's Treasury secretary got called out by his fellow Yale Class of '85 graduates. His friend Carl Icahn, one of Trump's earliest supporters from Wall Street, said he will no longer serve as a special adviser on regulatory issues.\n\nEven a member of the Palm Beach chamber of commerce, which counts Trump's Mar-a-Lago club as a member, called on charities to consult their mission statements before deciding to do business with Trump.\n\nOh, and the stock market, which has performed well since Trump was elected, did lousy. Investors are afraid.\n\nOf course, the pushback Trump got from business came because of his response to the violent protests in Charlottesville, Virginia last weekend.\n\nIt was that kind of week. It's understandable if you lost track. Here's how it all went down.\n\nMonday, August 14\n\n--8 a.m. ET: Merck CEO Ken Frazier, one of very few black Fortune 500 CEOs, takes the first step. He steps down from President Trump's manufacturing council, saying \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\n--8:54 a.m.: Trump tweets that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\n--1 p.m.: The president delivers a speech in which he calls the KKK, neo-Nazis and white supremacists 'repugnant.'\n\n--8:14 p.m.: Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank resigns from the manufacturing council.\n\n--11:37 a.m.: Scott Paul, president of Alliance for American Manufacturing, resigns from the Trump council.\n\n--On Tuesday afternoon, Trump gives a news conference inside Trump Tower. He reiterates his earlier position that he believes \"there is blame on both sides\" of last weekend's violence on the University of Virginia campus.\n\n--5:45 p.m.: Richard Trumka, president of the labor group AFL-CIO, and Thea Lee, economist at the AFL-CIO, resign from the manufacturing council.\n\n--Late Wednesday morning, Blackstone CEO Steve Schwarzman, the head of Trump's Strategic and Policy Forum, reportedly held a conference call with the members, who came to a collective decision to dissolve and started drafting a public statement.\n\n--1:14 p.m.: Trump tweets, announcing he was dissolving both the manufacturing council and economic advisory council: \"Rather than putting pressure on the businesspeople of the Manufacturing Council & Strategy & Policy Forum, I am ending both. Thank you all!\"\n\n--1:20 p.m.: United Technologies CEO Greg Hayes puts out a statement, explaining his exit from the manufacturing council.\n\n--1:30 p.m.: Alex Gorsky, CEO of Johnson & Johnson, releases a statement about why he resigned.\n\n--2 p.m.: General Electric's Jeff Immelt issues a statement on his decision to leave the council.\n\n--4:30 p.m.: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg writes a post condemning hate groups but doesn't mention Trump by name.\n\n--Late Wednesday night, Apple CEO Tim Cook sends a letter to employees, rejecting Trump's remarks on Charlottesville.\n\nThursday, August 17\n\n--1:15 p.m.: Cleveland Clinic, a hospital system, backs out of plans to host a fundraiser at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. It doesn't give a reason for the decision.\n\n--4 p.m.: American Cancer Society becomes the second organization to cancel plans for an event at Mar-a-Lago. The charity says using Trump property presented a \"challenge\" to its \"values.\"\n\n--7:30 p.m.: Another organization, American Friends of Magen David Adom, pulls a fundraising event from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--Throughout the day, three top magazines -- Time, The Economist and the New Yorker -- post snapshots of their latest magazine covers. Each lampooned Trump's response to Charlottesville.\n\n--Late Thursday, a scathing letter criticizing Trump written by 21st Century Fox CEO James Murdoch, is made public. He is the son of Trump confidante Rupert Murdoch.\n\n-- Late Thursday, a leader of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which President Trump's Florida resort Mar-a-Lagowants, says all charities should do a moral gut check before doing business at the club.\n\nFriday, August 18\n\n--12:30 p.m.: The American Red Cross cancels plans to hold its annual fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--1 p.m.: The Salvation Army says it won't host its holiday gala at Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--1:30 p.m.: Susan G. Komen, a breast cancer organization, pulls event from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--2 p.m.: The head of Leaders in Furthering Education, another philanthropic group, urges the foundation's board to move its fundraiser from Mar-a-Lago.\n\n--3:40 p.m.: Two authors of Letter to Steve Mnuchin, signed by more than 340 members of the '85 Yale Graduating class, appear on CNN to discuss their argument that classmate and Trump's Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin should resign.\n\n-- 4 p.m.: Billionaire Carl Icahn, a longtime friend of Trump, posts a letter announcing he would no longer serve as a special adviser to the president. He said he wanted to avoid becoming a partisan distraction.\n\n-- CNNMoney's Olivia Chang, Jill Disis, Julia Horowitz and Shen Lu contributed to this report.\n\nTM & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. {"id": "13", "title": "New York Post", "uri": "nypost.com"}, "url": "http://nypost.com/2017/08/18/another-charity-cancels-event-at-mar-a-lago/", "body": "A third large charity has ditched President Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort, canceling a fundraiser at the once-desirable venue that the head of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce now calls \"morally reprehensible.\"\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David, which raises cash for Israel's Red Cross, said it would not hold its 2018 gala at Trump's so-called \"Southern White House.\"\n\nThe event was the largest one help at the club last season, bringing in 600 guests, The Chicago Tribune reported.\n\nCharities -- including the huge international hospital network The Cleveland Clinic -- bailed on Trump's club after he blamed \"both sides\" for the violence in Charlottesville, Va., last Saturday, and for his defense on Tuesday of white nationalists, some of whom, he said, were \"very fine people.\"\n\nTrump's club is also facing a backlash from the local business community, with chamber Executive Director Laurel Baker predicting there would be more cancellations for the Palm Beach resort because of Trump's incendiary statements.\n\n\"The glitter, the shine has gone from the club, and I can't help but think there will be more fallout from it,\" she said, adding that Mar-a-Lago was a \"morally reprehensible\" place.\n\n\"If you have a conscience, you're really condoning bad behavior by continuing to be there,\" Baker said, according to the Palm Beach Post.\n\n\"Many say it's the dollars [raised at events] that count. But the integrity of any or organization rests on their sound decisions and stewardship,\" she added.\n\n\"Personally, I do not feel that supporting him, directly or indirectly, speaks well of any organization.\"\n\nMar-a-Lago is a dues-paying member of the chamber.\n\nThe other charity that pulled out was the American Cancer Society, which said the move was \"based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements.\"\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the ACS said in a statement.\n\n\"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic canceled its annual fundraising gala after medical officials pressed the system to dump Trump after the president's decision to repeal ObamaCare.\n\nPressure on the clinic only intensified this week after the white-hot controversy over Trump's behavior.", {"id": "9978684", "categories": [{"id": 121, "label": "dmoz/Society/People/Women", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People/Women", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 823, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service Clubs", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service_Clubs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1000, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711666442", "source": {"id": "77", "title": "San Jose Mercury News", "uri": "mercurynews.com"}, "url": "http://www.mercurynews.com/2017/08/18/charitable-groups-cancel-mar-a-lago-events/", "body": "By Drew Harwell and David Farenthold | Associated Press\n\nThe Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen on Friday joined a growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, deepening the financial impact to President Donald Trump's private business amid furor over his comments on Charlottesville.\n\nThe major exits now mean seven of the club's biggest event customers have abandoned it this week, likely costing the Trump business hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost revenue or more.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast-cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need - regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions - and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nThe charitable groups joined three other large event cancellations Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is no longer planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post Friday.\n\nThe move from the local group, which has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008, suggests that pressure on the club is growing even among groups with deep roots in Palm Beach.\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe cancellations hit at one of the private Florida club's top moneymakers: The club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past during Palm Beach's glitzy social seasons.\n\nBut they also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters were similarly at blame during a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T14:31:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": Such a choice \"symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to health care and cut billions of dollars in research funding,\" the letter argued, according to Bloomberg.\n\nThe American Cancer Society withdrew its intention to hold the \"Island of Palm Beach\" event at the same venue.\n\n\"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community,\" the organization stated, according to Politico. \"It has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations.\"\n\nTrump's remarks prompted business executives to distance themselves from his administration. The president decided to dissolve two advisory panels Aug. 16 after several business leaders said they would step down.\n\nCarlos Gutierrez, who served as commerce secretary under President George W. Bush, said Trump's brand has become too toxic.\n\n\"There's always the risk that CEOs will not have their brand associated with administration initiatives, which is extremely dangerous for the president's agenda,\" added Gutierrez, according to Bloomberg. \"The president will need the business community but the business community would rather stay out of the White House.\"\n\nStrategists and experts told Bloomberg the failure of Congress to pass important legislation and the perceived chaos in the White House is leading businesses to question their ties with the Republican Party.\n\n\"Standing with Trump at this moment, after his bizarre comments, is just too costly for corporations,\" said Graham Wilson of Boston University. \"This signal from corporate America could also have a broader impact on public opinion and the loyalty of core Republicans to Trump.\"\n\nWilson suggested that some Republicans who had been tolerating Trump could now decide to break with his {"id": "9969432", "categories": [{"id": 554, "label": "dmoz/Health/Conditions and Diseases/Cancer", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Conditions_and_Diseases/Cancer", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 823, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service Clubs", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service_Clubs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1000, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Motorcycles/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711639653", "source": {"id": "1697", "title": "Chicago Tribune", "uri": "chicagotribune.com"}, "url": "http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-salvation-army-red-cross-susan-g-komen-mar-a-lago-20170818-story.html", "body": "The Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen on Friday joined a growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, deepening the financial impact to President Donald Trump's private business amid furor over his comments on Charlottesville.\n\nThe major exits now mean seven of the club's biggest event customers have abandoned it this week, likely costing the Trump business hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost revenue or more.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast-cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need - regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions - and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nThe charitable groups joined three other large event cancellations Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is no longer planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post Friday.\n\nThe move from the local group, which has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008, suggests that pressure on the club is growing even among groups with deep roots in Palm Beach.\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe cancellations hit at one of the private Florida club's top moneymakers: The club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past during Palm Beach's glitzy social seasons.\n\nBut they also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters were similarly at blame during a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T20:17:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": {"id": "10016759", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 121, "label": "dmoz/Society/People/Women", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People/Women", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 505, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Grants", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 823, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service Clubs", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Service_Clubs", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1302, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Climbing/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1473, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Nudism/Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711783496", "source": {"id": "138", "title": "The Denver Post", "uri": "denverpost.com"}, "url": "http://www.denverpost.com/2017/08/18/salvation-army-red-cross-susan-g-komen-abandon-trumps-mar-a-lago-2/", "body": "The Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen on Friday joined a growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, deepening the financial impact to President Donald Trump's private business amid furor over his comments on Charlottesville.\n\nThe major exits now mean more than eight of the club's biggest event customers have abandoned it this week, likely costing the Trump business hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost revenue or more.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast-cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need - regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions - and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nThe cancellations hit at one of the private Florida club's top moneymakers: The club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past during Palm Beach's glitzy social seasons.\n\nBut they also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe charitable groups joined three other large event cancellations Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nSome of the club's most notable local boosters, with long fundraising histories and deep Palm Beach roots, were also in outright rebellion Friday against the club. Lois Pope, a Mar-a-Lago member and philanthropist who heads the Lois Pope Life Foundation and Leaders In Furthering Education, said she had told her foundation's board to move its well-known December gala from the club.\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and Anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by Neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive,\" Pope wrote in a statement. \"And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\"\n\nOne of the cancellations cut close to home for the Trumps. Big Dog Ranch Rescue said Friday it would no longer hold an upcoming event at the club and would instead move it to the group's facility nearby. Trump's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, was scheduled to co-chair the event.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is not planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post Friday. The local group has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008.\n\nThe Ryan Licht Sang Bipolar Foundation on Friday also announced it had canceled its annual medical briefing luncheon at the club and will move it to another venue.\n\n\"We stand with the community,\" the foundation's co-founder, Dusty Sang, told The Post Friday. \"I think people are standing up for what they believe.\"\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters equally shared the blame for a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T23:25:00Z", Neither specifically mentioned the president's controversial remarks in statements, but the American Cancer Society said it must consider its \"values\" and \"commitment to diversity.\" Cleveland Clinic CEO Toby Cosgrove was a member on the White House's strategic and policy forum, one of the two business advisory groups that disbanded on Wednesday.\n\n\"When we chose to hold our 2018 event and related dinner at Mar-a-Lago, we selected the venue based on a variety of factors, including costs and venue requirements,\" a statement from the American Cancer Society reads. \"Our values and commitment to diversity are critical as we work to address the impact of cancer in every community.\n\nIt has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations. With our volunteer leaders, we are exploring other opportunities and potential venues. The generous support of community volunteers and donors are critical to our life-saving mission. Only by coming together will we solve our society's most difficult challenges, including reducing the pain and suffering from cancer.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic offered little explanation for its venue change, but said it reached the decision not to hold a fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018 after \"careful consideration.\"\n\nThe president's businesses have benefitted in some ways since his inauguration. Fahrenthold / The Washington Post\n\nThe Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen on Friday joined a growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, deepening the financial impact to President Donald Trump's private business amid furor over his comments on Charlottesville.\n\nThe major exits now mean seven of the club's biggest event customers have abandoned it this week, likely costing the Trump business hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost revenue or more.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast-cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need - regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions - and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nThe charitable groups joined three other large event cancellations Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is no longer planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post Friday.\n\nThe move from the local group, which has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008, suggests that pressure on the club is growing even among groups with deep roots in Palm Beach.\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe cancellations hit at one of the private Florida club's top moneymakers: The club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past during Palm Beach's glitzy social seasons.\n\nBut they also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters were similarly at blame during a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T19:41:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": {"id": "9732289", "categories": [{"id": 1, "label": "dmoz/Health", "uri": "dmoz/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 2, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 3, "label": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical Specialties", "uri": "dmoz/Health/Medicine/Medical_Specialties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 239, "label": "dmoz/Business/Biotechnology and Pharmaceuticals/Pharmaceuticals", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Biotechnology_and_Pharmaceuticals/Pharmaceuticals", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 912, "label": "dmoz/Business/Biotechnology and Pharmaceuticals/Contract Research Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Biotechnology_and_Pharmaceuticals/Contract_Research_Organizations", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710992275", "source": {"id": "2166", "title": "cleveland.com", "uri": "cleveland.com"}, "url": "http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2017/08/cleveland_clinic_pulls_fund-ra.html", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Cleveland Clinic is cutting another tie to President Donald Trump, canceling plans to hold its 2018 Florida fundraising gala from the Trump-owned Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach.\n\n\"After careful consideration, Cleveland Clinic has decided that it will not hold a Florida fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago in 2018,\" the hospital system said in a statement. \"We thank the staff of Mar-a-Lago for their service over the years.\"\n\nThe Clinic and its CEO, Toby Cosgrove, had taken criticism for continuing to hold the annual event there.\n\nThe exit follows a decision by Cosgrove and top executives of some of the nation's leading corporations on Wednesday to disband a business advisory council that reported to the president. They said Trump's recent comments on last weekend's violence in Virginia by neo-Nazis and Ku Klux Klan supporters were inappropriate and didn't represent the values for which they and their organizations stood.\n\nCorporate leaders say Trump has gone too far now\n\nA 32-year-old Charlottesville woman was killed Saturday when a Maumee, Ohio man with reported Nazi sympathies allegedly plowed his car into a crowded street in the Virginia university town. This occurred during clashes involving white supremacists, shouting racist and antisemitic slurs and holding signs with symbols representing bigotry and hate. They were in Charlottesville to protest the planned removal of a statue of Confederate leader Robert E. Lee.\n\nAlthough Trump read a statement Monday denouncing bigotry, racism and antisemitism, he told reporters Tuesday there was \"bame on both sides\" because counter-protesters, some with clubs, were intent on creating conflict. He also said there were \"some very fine people on both sides\" who just wanted to present their respective views in the controversy over keeping or removing statues of Confederate War heroes.\n\nAnd he warned -- and repeated on Twitter today -- that the movement to remove Confederate War these statues could spread to a drive to take down statues of founding fathers and early presidents, including George Washington and Thomas Jefferson, because they were slave owners, too.\n\n...can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish! Also... -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nCorporate leaders, numerous members of Congress and many Americans say Trump is showing a gross and inappropriate sense of moral equivalency.\n\nThe Nazis, who killed 6 million Jews in World War II, and Ku Klux Klan, who lynched black Americans throughout the South and whose members still want to maintain racial segregation, embodied evil, and no thoughtful American should stand with them or equivocate about \"both sides,\" the Trump critics say.\n\nThe criticism has built throughout the week, creating public anxiety about the Trump's judgment barely seven months into his presidency. Some of his supporters, however, say he has been misunderstood or was merely inartful in presenting his understanding of the Charlottesville events. White separatist and nationalist leaders have gone further and praised Trump, with former KKK leader David Duke thanking Trump for his \"honesty and courage.\"\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic system, which has a hospital in Broward County, Florida, was under public pressure to move its February fund-raiser long before this week. The Mar-a-Lago controversy erupted soon after Trump took office in January and signed an executive order to temporarily ban people from Syria and other Muslim-majority countries from entering the United States.\n\nThis affected medical students and young doctors doing residencies at American hospitals, including the Cleveland Clinic. A petition drive and peaceful protests in Cleveland would not dissuade the Clinic because, officials there said, it had a binding contract with Trump's club for the 2017 event. That event wound up raising about $1 million for the Clinic's Florida hospital.\n\nThe Clinic then said it would consider moving its annual Florida gala to another location in 2018, but later said it decided to continue using the Trump Club because a committee that included donors preferred Mar-a-lago to any alternatives. The hospital stood out in this regard, since several other charitable and medical organizations that have hosted events there had decided to go elsewhere in 2018.\n\nTrump's strong support for dismantling the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare, appeared to factor into those decisions. Trump says the nation will be better off it Obamacare \"implodes,\" citing high premiums for Americans whose incomes are too high to qualify for subsidies.\n\nLeading medical organizations and the nonpartisan Congressional Bydget Office say the Republican replacement proposals would leave at least 22 million Americans without health coverage.\n\nWith that specific criticism, a group of medical students, heath professionals and liberal interest groups launched a fresh petition drive last week to try to persuade the Clinic to abandon Mar-a-Lago.\n\nThe Clinic said last week, however, that it planned to sign a contract with Mar-a-Lago for 2018.\n\nA new attempt to dissuade the Cleveland Clinic\n\nWith the newest Trump controversy swirling, it has changed its mind.", "dateTime": {"id": "9951929", "categories": [{"id": 11, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 17, "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Organizations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 705, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Race-Ethnic-Religious Relations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Race-Ethnic-Religious_Relations", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 787, "label": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar System", "uri": "dmoz/Science/Astronomy/Solar_System", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1222, "label": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit Resources", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Organizations/Nonprofit_Resources", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711592259", "source": {"id": "260", "title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/aug/18/charities-cancel-events-at-trumps-mar-a-lago-club", "body": "After the president's remarks blaming violence at a neo-Nazi rally on 'both sides,' the Red Cross and others cancel fundraiser at his property\n\nThe American Red Cross has said it will cancel its annual fundraiser at Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Florida.\n\nThe charity is the sixth non-profit to cancel a gala at the president's event space in two days, after Trump's controversial comments equating neo-Nazis and anti-hate protesters in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\n\"The American Red Cross has decided we cannot host our annual fundraising event at Mar-a-Lago, as it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters\", the Red Cross said Friday.\n\n\"We believe this action will allow us to continue to put the focus on our lifesaving mission and the people we serve. The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nIn addition to the Red Cross, five other charities have canceled in the last 24 hours, including the leading academic hospital the Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society and the Friends of Magen David Adom (the Israeli Red Cross). Other medical organizations canceled galas at Mar-a-Lago earlier in the year, including the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.\n\nThe Washington Post reported that the Salvation Army, the Autism Project of Palm Beach County and Susan G Komen have all also canceled fundraisers.\n\nThe organizations that have canceled are juggernauts in the American nonprofit world. For example, the Cleveland Clinic alone said it raised $1m each year at its Mar-a-Lago event, according to the Boston Globe.\n\nThe announcement comes after the Red Cross withstood pressure in January to cancel its annual gala at Mar-a-Lago. At the time, critics said the president's moratorium on refugees conflicted with the aid organization's mission.\n\nNonprofits are not the only ones abandoning Trump after his comments on Charlottesville.\n\nThree White House business panels have been disbanded this week after CEOs of some of the country's largest companies withdrew their support.\n\nOn Friday, 16 members of Trump's Committee on the Arts and Humanities sent the president a letter of resignation, citing his \"hateful rhetoric\". The letter featured an acrostic which spelt out \"resist\". The members were appointed by Barack Obama.\n\nAnd one of the three universities to give Trump an honorary doctorate is considering whether to revoke it.\n\nMitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, warned of an \"unraveling of our national fabric\" in a Facebook post attacking Trump over his defence of people involved in a neo-Nazi rally.\n\n\"Whether he intended to or not, what he communicated caused racists to rejoice, minorities to weep, and the vast heart of America to mourn,\" Romney, a longtime critic of Trump, wrote on Friday.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T18:04:00Z", Komen announced on Friday they would hold their events planned for Mar-a-Lago elsewhere.\n\nThe Red Cross said in a statement that it decided to pull the plug on its plans to hold its annual fundraising event at the club, because the president's property has \"become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters.\"\n\n\"We believe this action will allow us to continue to put the focus on our lifesaving mission and the people we serve,\" the group said.\n\n\"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need, regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation, or political opinions, and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nKurt Watkins, a spokesman for The Salvation Army, said in a statement that it decided to cancel plans to host its \"Holiday Snow Ball\" at Mar-a-Lago, because \"the conversation has shifted away from the purpose of this event.\"\n\nSusan G. Komen, a breast cancer nonprofit, said in an internal announcement Friday that it was withdrawing from the Palm Beach club and is in the process of finding a new venue, according to Andrea Radar, the group's senior communications director.\n\nThe Washington Post reported Friday that the Autism Project of Palm Beach County had also backed out of plans to hold an event at the club. The group did not immediately respond to The Hill's request for comment.\n\nThe new announcements bring the total number of groups that have canceled events at Mar-a-Lago to seven.\n\nThe Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society and the American Friends of Magen David Adom all announced that would no longer hold events at the club earlier this week.\n\nTrump has faced mounting criticism following an off-the-rails news conference on Tuesday when he appeared to defend white nationalist and neo-Nazi groups who had gathered in Charlottesville, Va., to protest the removal of a Confederate statue.\n\nHe also doubled down on his claim that \"both sides\" were responsible for the violence that erupted during the Saturday protests, criticizing what he called \"alt-left\" demonstrators for violently confronting white nationalist groups.\n\nThe president's comments spurred immediate criticism from both Democrats and Republicans, who have urged him in recent days to take a harder line against racism and hate groups.\n\nAlso amid the fallout, two of Trump's economic councils disbanded as prominent business leaders sought to distance themselves from a White House consumed increasingly by controversy. Komen on Friday joined a growing exodus of organizations canceling plans to hold fundraising events at the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, deepening the financial impact to President Trump's private business amid furor over his comments on Charlottesville.\n\nThe major exits now mean seven of the club's biggest event customers have abandoned it in a matter of hours, likely costing the Trump business hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost revenue or more.\n\nThe Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement Friday.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the nation's largest breast-cancer fundraising group, said Friday it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nAnd the Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is no longer planning on hosting an event at the club, president Richard Busto told The Post Friday. The group has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at the club every year since at least 2008.\n\n[Three fundraising giants cancel plans for galas at Mar-a-Lago]\n\nThe charitable groups joined three other large event cancellations Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nAnother group, the Unicorn Children's Foundation, said it is \"currently exploring other options\" for a previously planned luncheon at Mar-a-Lago and would make its final decision next month.\n\nThe cancellations hit at one of the private Florida club's top moneymakers: The club earned between $100,000 and $275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past during Palm Beach's glitzy social seasons.\n\nBut they also reveal a widening vulnerability for Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counter-protesters were similarly at blame during a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nThe Trump Organization did not respond to requests for comment.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T17:13:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": Komen for the Cure on Friday all pulled out, according to The Washington Post's Drew Harwell and David Farenthold.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\n\"The major exits now mean more than eight of the club's biggest event customers have abandoned it this week, likely costing the Trump business hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost revenue or more,\" The Post reports.\n\nOn Thursday, the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society also canceled scheduled fundraising events at Trump's Mar-a-Lago.\n\n\"The cancellations will hit one of the biggest moneymakers for what Trump calls the 'winter White House,' where similar-sized events have often earned the club between $100,000 and $275,000 a piece,\" Farenthold on Thursday reported.\n\nWith the tally at eight cancelations, Trump conceivably has lost between $800,000 and $2.2 million, based on the Post's numbers.\n\nUPDATED: list of charities holding galas at @realDonaldTrump's Mar-a-Lago next yr. Seven have gone from yes to no. pic.twitter.com/vj5ouSqYWr -- David Fahrenthold (@Fahrenthold)\n\nAugust 18, 2017\n\nThe Post notes for Trump this time it's getting personal.\n\n\"One of the cancellations cut close to home for the Trumps. Big Dog Ranch Rescue said Friday it would no longer hold an upcoming event at the club and would instead move it to the group's facility nearby. Trump's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, was scheduled to co-chair the event.\"\n\nIt's not only large national non-profits that are leaving.\n\n\"Lois Pope, a Mar-a-Lago member and philanthropist who heads the Lois Pope Life Foundation and Leaders In Furthering Education, said she had told her foundation's board to move its well-known December gala from the club.\"\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and Anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by Neo-Nazis and White Supremacists are repugnant and repulsive,\" Pope wrote in a statement. \"And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\"\n\nTo comment on this article and other NCRM content, visit our
