"label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Judaism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Judaism", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711201795", "source": {"id": "5836", "title": "mypalmbeachpost.com", "uri": "mypalmbeachpost.com"}, "url": "http://www.mypalmbeachpost.com/news/inside-philanthropists-decision-quit-trump-mar-lago/lUvvXewHqJT2guveVI9vuN/", "body": "\"Money is something that Trump understands, more than anything,\" Palm Beach's Richard Rampell said.\n\nPresident Donald Trump's statements that \"both sides\" were at fault in the deadly violence in Charlottesville, Va., were troubling to philanthropists who give money to organizations that hold events at Trump properties, including Mar-a-Lago.\n\nIn interviews with charity benefactors, the sentiment was that Trump finally had crossed a line.\n\n\" COMPLETE COVERAGE: Latest news, photos, videos on President Donald Trump\n\nDonors were appalled when Trump first said both sides were at fault in the violence, then two days later condemned neo-Nazis and white supremacists, only to defiantly backtrack on Tuesday by doubling down on his \"both sides\" comments.\n\n\"The tide has turned against Trump,\" one philanthropist said. \"His inability to respond to the neo-Nazis, the KKK and others is so egregious, I think people find this intolerable.\"\n\n\" LATEST: Three organizations say they're moving events from Mar-a-Lago\n\nAs a result, the philanthropist also expected Trump to see more Jewish supporters and Jewish philanthropists start to break from him. Many Jewish residents of Palm Beach County have family members who perished in the Holocaust.\n\n\"When you get into the area of anti-Semitism, global anti-Semitism, it transcends all the other issues, like health care and immigration,\" the philanthropist said. \"The issue is so raw now, I think you will see people bail.\"\n\nIndeed, a prominent organization that provides money for disaster relief in Israel became the third charity on Thursday to cancel a planned fundraising gala at Mar-a-Lago since Trump's comments on Charlottesville.\n\n\" Palm Beach chamber head tells charities 'have a conscience' about Mar-a-Lago events\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom issued a terse statement to the Palm Beach Post Thursday evening, announcing the cancellation of its gala, set for Sunday, Feb. 25, 2018.\n\nLast season's gala, held Feb. 26, featured more than 600 attendees who paid $650 per ticket for the event.\n\n\"After considerable deliberation, AFMDA -- an apolitical and humanitarian aid organization -- will not hold its 2018 Palm Beach Celebration of Life Gala at Mar-a-Lago.\" Magen David Adom (MDA) is Israel's ambulance, blood services and disaster-relief organization, serving as emergency medical first-responders.\n\n\" RELATED: Why the American Humane Association won't return to Mar-a-Lago\n\nNo further information was available about whether AFMDA would try to hold an event elsewhere in Palm Beach County during the season.\n\nRichard Rampell, a Palm Beach CPA, said the issue of philanthropy is very important to those of the Jewish faith.\n\nThe Hebrew word, \"tzedakah,\" often is used to describe charity. But the word means much more, Rampell said.\n\n\"It means righteousness and justice,\" he said. \"Giving is not viewed as a generous or magnanimous act, but as an obligation.\"\n\nNowhere is this belief more evident on Palm Beach than at the Palm Beach Country Club, created by the Jewish community after members were excluded from other clubs on the island.\n\nRampell said he is not a member of the Palm Beach Country Club, but he has friends and clients who are. Membership is not even considered unless an applicant can demonstrate years of generous philanthropy, Rampell said.\n\n\" RELATED: Dana Farber, three other charities won't return to Mar-a-Lago in 2018\n\nPalm Beach Country Club members are among the most generous contributors to cultural, medical and other organizations, Rampell said.\n\nAnd Palm Beach overall has become a center of philanthropy for many national organizations during the winter season.\n\nFor a number of organizations, a Palm Beach gala is the single-largest fundraiser they hold. But hosting these elegant affairs costs big money, especially at the two premier Palm Beach locations, The Breakers Hotel and Trump's Mar-a-Lago.\n\nTherefore, charities canceling at Mar-a-Lago are sending a loud message to Trump, Rampell said.\n\n\"Money is something that Trump understands, more than anything,\" Rampell said.\n\nRampell said the same dynamic is starting to play out at Mar-a-Lago as was seen recently with Trump's manufacturing council, where Merck's chief executive quit, followed by several other top executives.\n\nWhen one charity decides to cancel an event at a Trump property, others are emboldened, Rampell said.\n\n\"Everyone is afraid to make the first move. You need a leader with a lot of stature,\" Rampell said, noting that Cleveland Clinic has a lot of stature.\n\nWhen other organizations see a leader act, \"other people will follow,\" Rampell said.\n\nIndeed, hours after Cleveland Clinic announced it would not hold its charity event at Mar-a-Lago, the American Cancer Society also announced it would not have its gala there.\n\nRampell said he expects other charities will follow.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:37:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 1943, "textStart": 1930, "date": "2018-02-25", "amb": false}, {"textEnd": 1978, the decision to move our annual dinner dance,\" the group wrote.\n\nThe local nonprofit is \"dedicated to protecting and celebrating the unique architectural and cultural heritage of Palm Beach,\" the organization said in the statement.\n\nThe local charity follows other major nonprofits such as The American Friends of Magen David, the American Cancer Society and the Cleveland Clinic in pulling out from the location.\n\nThe groups' announcements all come as Trump faces massive backlash for saying \"both sides\" were to blame for violence at the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville.\n\nTrump has faced mounting criticism following a news conference on Tuesday, where he appeared to defend white nationalist and neo-Nazi groups that had gathered in Charlottesville to protest the removal of a Confederate statue.\n\nHe also doubled down on his claim that \"both sides\" were responsible for the violence that erupted during the Saturday protests -- resulting in the {"id": "10122725", "categories": [{"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712086238", "source": {"id": "1999", "title": "The Age", "uri": "theage.com.au"}, "url": "http://www.theage.com.au/world/donalds-trumps-maralago-club-loses-its-ninth-big-charity-event-this-week-20170819-gy02rb.html", "body": "Another charity announced that it was cancelling plans to hold a gala at US President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club - the ninth to cancel a big-ticket charity event at the club this week.\n\nThe Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach, a charity focused on the ritzy island's architectural landmarks, had planned to hold a dinner dance at Mar-a-Lago next March. The foundation was a new customer for Trump's club, and a potentially lucrative one: It spent $US244,000 ($308,000) on rent and food on a previous gala at another site, according to tax filings.\n\nMore World News Videos Previous slide Next slide Trump attacks Republican senators Trump attacks Republican senators\n\nPresident Donald Trump\u00e2\u0080\u0099s turnabout on the violence went on a stabbing rampage in a market square in the Finnish city of Turku on Friday.\n\nMore videos Trump attacks Republican senators\n\nPresident Donald Trump\u00e2\u0080\u0099s turnabout on the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia has rocked his administration, leading to rising speculation that some top officials may be looking for a way out.\n\nBut on Saturday, US time, the foundation said it would find another venue.\n\n\"Given the current environment surrounding Mar-a-Lago, we have made the decision to move our annual dinner dance,\" the foundation's executive director, Amanda Skier, said.\n\nRelated Articles Trump will not attend Kennedy Centre Honours over concerns of 'political distraction' 'No good Nazis': James Murdoch takes $1.3m stand against Trump\n\nThat decision meant that Mr Trump's club had lost nine of the 16 galas or dinner events that it had been scheduled to host during next winter's social \"season\" in Palm Beach. At least two other groups have also cancelled charity luncheons there this week.\n\nThose losses could reduce the club's revenue by hundreds of thousands of dollars by each event, and deny Mr Trump his dual role as president and host to the island's partying elite. If he returns to the club for weekends next winter, the president could often find its grand ballrooms quiet and empty.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThese cancellations all followed Mr Trump's remarks on the march of neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups in Charlottesville, Virginia, in which the president said the protesters, who gathered under the pretense of wanting to preserve a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee, included some \"fine people\".\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nOn Friday, the Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen joined the growing exodus of organisations cancelling plans to hold fundraising events at the club.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the US's largest breast cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need - regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions - and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nTrump's club earned between $US100,000 and $US275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past.\n\nBut the cancellations also reveal a widening vulnerability for Mr Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe Trump Organisation has not responded to requests for comment.\n\nThe charitable groups join three other large event cancellations from Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nSome of the club's most notable local boosters, with long fundraising histories and deep Palm Beach roots, were also in outright rebellion Friday against the club. Lois Pope, a Mar-a-Lago member and philanthropist who heads the Lois Pope Life Foundation and Leaders In Furthering Education, said she had told her foundation's board to move its well-known December gala from the club.\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by neo-Nazis and white supremacists are repugnant and repulsive,\" Pope wrote in a statement. \"And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\"\n\nOne of the cancellations cut close to home for the Trumps. Big Dog Ranch Rescue said Friday it would no longer hold an upcoming event at the club and would instead move it to the group's facility nearby. Trump's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, was scheduled to co-chair the event.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is not planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post on Friday. The local group has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008.\n\nThe Ryan Licht Sang Bipolar Foundation on Friday also announced it had cancelled its annual medical briefing luncheon at the club and will move it to another venue.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters equally shared the blame for a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nThe Washington Post", "dateTime": "2017-08-20T00:57:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": Mexican wrestlers go to church in annual homage\n\nMasked lucha libre wrestlers embark on their annual pilgrimage to the Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe while signing autographs along the way.\n\nMore videos Trump attacks Republican senators\n\nPresident Donald Trump\u00e2\u0080\u0099s turnabout on the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia has rocked his administration, leading to rising speculation that some top officials may be looking for a way out.\n\nBut on Saturday, US time, the foundation said it would find another venue.\n\n\"Given the current environment surrounding Mar-a-Lago, we have made the decision to move our annual dinner dance,\" the foundation's executive director, Amanda Skier, said.\n\nRelated Articles Trump will not attend Kennedy Centre Honours over concerns of 'political distraction' 'No good Nazis': James Murdoch takes $1.3m stand against Trump\n\nThat decision meant that Mr Trump's club had lost nine of the 16 galas or dinner events that it had been scheduled to host during next winter's social \"season\" in Palm Beach. At least two other groups have also cancelled charity luncheons there this week.\n\nThose losses could reduce the club's revenue by hundreds of thousands of dollars by each event, and deny Mr Trump his dual role as president and host to the island's partying elite. If he returns to the club for weekends next winter, the president could often find its grand ballrooms quiet and empty.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThese cancellations all followed Mr Trump's remarks on the march of neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups in Charlottesville, Virginia, in which the president said the protesters, who gathered under the pretense of wanting to preserve a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee, included some \"fine people\".\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nOn Friday, the Salvation Army, the American Red Cross and Susan G. Komen joined the growing exodus of organisations cancelling plans to hold fundraising events at the club.\n\nSusan G. Komen, the US's largest breast cancer fundraising group, said it would seek another venue after hosting its \"Perfect Pink Party\" gala at Mar-a-Lago every year since 2011.\n\nThe Salvation Army, which has held a gala at the club every year since 2014, said in a statement that it would not hold its event there \"because the conversation has shifted away\" from its mission of helping those in need.\n\nAnd the American Red Cross said it would cancel its annual fundraiser at the club because \"it has increasingly become a source of controversy and pain for many of our volunteers, employees and supporters,\" the charity said in a statement.\n\nIn a letter to staff Friday, chief executive Gail McGovern said, \"The Red Cross provides assistance without discrimination to all people in need - regardless of nationality, race, religious beliefs, sexual orientation or political opinions - and we must be clear and unequivocal in our defense of that principle.\"\n\nTrump's club earned between $US100,000 and $US275,000 each from similar-sized events in the past.\n\nBut the cancellations also reveal a widening vulnerability for Mr Trump, who, unlike past presidents, refused to divest from his business interests when he joined the White House.\n\nThe Trump Organisation has not responded to requests for comment.\n\nThe charitable groups join three other large event cancellations from Thursday: the Cleveland Clinic, the American Friends of Magen David Adom and the American Cancer Society, which cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in its decision to abandon the club.\n\nSome of the club's most notable local boosters, with long fundraising histories and deep Palm Beach roots, were also in outright rebellion Friday against the club. Lois Pope, a Mar-a-Lago member and philanthropist who heads the Lois Pope Life Foundation and Leaders In Furthering Education, said she had told her foundation's board to move its well-known December gala from the club.\n\n\"The hatred, vitriol and anti-Semitic and racist views being spewed by neo-Nazis and white supremacists are repugnant and repulsive,\" Pope wrote in a statement. \"And anyone who would demonstrate even a modicum of support for them by insisting that there are 'good people' among them is not deserving of my personal patronage or that of my foundations.\"\n\nOne of the cancellations cut close to home for the Trumps. Big Dog Ranch Rescue said Friday it would no longer hold an upcoming event at the club and would instead move it to the group's facility nearby. Trump's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, was scheduled to co-chair the event.\n\nThe Autism Project of Palm Beach County also said Friday that it is not planning on hosting an event at the club, President Richard Busto told The Post on Friday. The local group has held \"Renaissance Dinner\" galas at Mar-a-Lago every year since at least 2008.\n\nThe Ryan Licht Sang Bipolar Foundation on Friday also announced it had cancelled its annual medical briefing luncheon at the club and will move it to another venue.\n\nThe groups' cancellations follow rebukes from business executives this week, who heavily criticized Trump's comments that white supremacists and counterprotesters equally shared the blame for a deadly weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nThe Washington Post", "dateTime": "2017-08-20T00:32:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": {"id": "9940681", "categories": [{"id": 115, "label": "dmoz/Society/People", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 116, "label": "dmoz/Society/People/Generations and Age Groups", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People/Generations_and_Age_Groups", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 220, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 327, "label": "dmoz/Reference/Museums/History", "uri": "dmoz/Reference/Museums/History", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 395, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Softball/Slowpitch", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Softball/Slowpitch", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 737, "label": "dmoz/Business/Real Estate/Residential", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Real_Estate/Residential", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711560268", "source": {"id": "2566", "title": "Crain's Cleveland Business", "uri": "crainscleveland.com"}, "url": "http://www.crainscleveland.com/article/20170818/BLOGS03/170819804/cleveland-clinic-pullout-may-be-just-the-start-of-challenges-for-mar", "body": "The Cleveland Clinic isn't the only nonprofit giant abandoning President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Fla.\n\nThe Washington Post reports that the Clinic was one of three fundraising giants that on Thursday, Aug. 17, decided to pull events from the venue in the wake of controversy over the president's comments on racial unrest in Charlottesville, Va. The cancellations signal \"a direct blowback\" to the president's business empire as a result of the uproar, The Post says.\n\nFrom the story:\n\nThe American Cancer Society, a high-dollar client at the club since at least 2009, cited its \"values and commitment to diversity\" in a statement on its decision to move an upcoming fundraising gala. Another longtime Mar-a-Lago customer, the Cleveland Clinic, abruptly changed course on its winter event only days after saying it planned to continue doing business at Mar-a-Lago, a leading venue for charitable events in the posh resort town.\n\nThe American Friends of Magen David Adom, which raises money for Israel's equivalent of the Red Cross, also said it would not hold its 2018 gala at the club \"after considerable deliberation,\" though it did not give a reason. The charity had one of Mar-a-Lago's biggest events last season, with about 600 people in attendance.\n\nThe cancellations \"will undoubtedly squeeze revenue\" for the private club, the newspaper reports. It estimates similar-size events \"have often brought in fees of between $100,000 and $275,000 each.\"\n\nAnd things might get worse for Mar-a-Lago. The Post reports that the head of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, of which Mar-a-Lago is a member, called the business \"morally reprehensible\" and said she expected more charities to defect.\n\nA fun New York Times story looks at what it takes to market Frank Lloyd Wright houses that are for sale nationwide, including one in Willoughby Hills.\n\nAmong the unique challenges are \"the need to become a Wright expert, to devise a strategy for separating potential buyers from sightseers, and to develop a convincing argument for why someone should pay a premium to live in a house with small bedrooms and a snug kitchen, cinder-block walls, cement floors, narrow doorways, a carport instead of a garage and, quite likely, no air-conditioning,\" the paper notes.\n\nAnd for potential buyers, The Times says, \"it means becoming the steward of a legacy, which includes instant membership in an exclusive, sometimes intrusive, society of Wright enthusiasts.\n\nIn Willoughby Hills, the Penfield House, built in 1955, has just been listed for sale with Howard Hanna Real Estate for $1.3 million. It had been put on the market for $1.7 million about three years ago.\n\nThe Times talks with Paul Penfield, who \"remembers Wright's long silver hair and the coat he wore draped over his shoulders when he met with his parents in 1957 to discuss designing his second house for them.\"\n\n\"My wife, Donna, and I are getting ready to retire, and my children have busy careers of their own and they don't want to manage the property,\" Penfield, 72, tells the newspaper.\n\nThe Times says Penfield \"was drawn back to Penfield House in 1983 after his mother died and he inherited the property. He undertook a five-year restoration project that was completed in 2004, at which time the Penfields, who live in another midcentury modern house nearby, began renting out the three-bedroom house for $275 to $300 a night. The 1,730-square-foot house, listed on the National Register of Historic Places, is booked through early November.\"\n\nEven in senior slow-pitch softball leagues, apparently, there are people who will look to get an unfair advantage.\n\nThere's a bizarre Cleveland anecdote in this Wall Street Journal feature about the popularity of senior softball, which is played by an estimated 393,000 Americans in their 50s and above, according to the Sports & Fitness Industry Association. And their ranks are rising as people age; The Journal notes there were 13.9 million men age 70 or over in the United States in 2016, up 17% from 2011.\n\nIt's mostly fun and games, though as the newspaper points out, \"there's the matter of making sure everyone is a genuine senior.\"\n\nFrom the story:\n\nIn the Cleveland suburbs, the Huff-N-Puffers league last year discovered at the end of the season that its champion team had surreptitiously fielded two players a year or two below the league's 60-year-old threshold. All team members were stripped of their championship jackets, and the league now requires a photo ID to prove age.\n\nJohn Teron, league president, said nothing like that had happened in more than three decades of play: \"Why would you want to join the senior league if you're not senior?\"\n\nFord has a new store on Madison Avenue and 61st Street in Manhattan. As you would expect, it is very fancy and is filled with beautiful items. His wares \"have long charmed the rich and famous,\" The Times says, and the paper somehow settles on Jones as an example of that.\n\nHe and his pregnant wife, Valeisha, \"were being squired around by a black-clad attendant offering assistance,\" the paper says. \"Up the spiral staircase, a glossy corkscrew of black fiberglass, is the men's department, where the real action is. Mr. Ford is known for red-carpet women's wear (those sequined dresses are major sellers), but his is the unusual luxury brand at which men's wear outsells women's. (Mr. and Mrs. Jones had soon repaired upward to assess men's backpacks and leather goods.)\"\n\nThe story, written by Times style reporter Matthew Schneier, ends this way: \"I did not have the means or the wherewithal to lay down my Amex. But for a few minutes, I was a Ford man, peer of the rich and fabulous, literally keeping up with the Joneses. Dress for the job you want, the saying goes. May I introduce you to me, the newest Cleveland Cavalier?\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T17:01:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 230, "textStart": 223, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": medical professionals opposed to the president's efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act and overhaul the nation's healthcare system.\n\nThe ACS's decision to move its event came a day after two of Komen, a multimillion-dollar nonprofit that raises money for breast cancer research; the International Red Cross; The Salvation Army; the Autism Association of Palm Beach County; and Big Dog Ranch Rescue in Loxahatchee Groves, Florida, all said they were pulling events from Mar-a-Lago's upcoming winter fundraising schedule, according to local reports.\n\nStory Continued Below\n\nThey joined the Cleveland Clinic, the American Cancer Society and the American Friends of Magen David Adom, all of which announced Thursday their decision to move their events off-site, bringing the total of charities to pull events from Trump's estate to eight.\n\nThe cancellations serve as the latest blow to the president during a week in which he's seen several of his advisory policy councils crumble over his handling of the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville. At one point, U.S. Rep. Lois Frankel, D-West Palm Beach, held a press conference within eyesight of Mar-a-Lago to draw attention to the issue.\n\nTrump made seven visits to Mar-a-Lago after taking office, which included summits with leaders of China and Japan. His last visit was during Easter weekend. He's expected to resume his trips to Mar-a-Lago when Palm Beach's social season picks up in the fall.\n\nDuring the summer, Trump has used his golf club in Bedminster, N.J., as a getaway {"id": "9970840", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 276, "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711643669", "source": {"id": "2690", "title": "Vanity Fair", "uri": "vanityfair.com"}, "url": "https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/08/the-bull-case-for-the-trump-presidency-collapses", "body": "The businessman in chief is losing the business community. Wall Street, and polite society, is spooked.\n\nFor many critics of Donald Trump, there were two best-case scenarios for his presidency. The first was that he might induce the unlikely political realignment that his populist campaign seemed to promise: a European-style fusion of nationalism with staunch support for the welfare state. In this scenario, Trump would build the wall and renegotiate tougher trade deals, but he would also protect Medicaid and work with Democrats to pour money into infrastructure projects around the country. At its core was the premise that Trump is not an ideologue and might be uniquely positioned to positively disrupt an ossified political establishment.\n\nThis, it quickly became obvious, would not happen. Instead, Trump quickly adopted a traditional Republican platform focused on tax cuts and deregulation. Which leads to the second best-case scenario: that Trump, a political neophyte motivated by glad-handing and deal-making, might be uniquely positioned to help implement a center-right, pro-business agenda. And indeed, his presidency seemed to start off this way. The stock market soared as Trump made peace with Paul Ryan, set about unshackling Wall Street, and assembled several business advisory councils, convening the nation's top C.E.O.s for photo-ops and brainstorming best practices for cutting America's red tape. The presence of so many millionaires and billionaires in his Cabinet may have seemed gaudy, even unseemly, but at least it suggested that Trump wouldn't succumb to his more apocalyptic impulses. Markets largely ignored the president's rumblings about trade wars with China or Mexico (or Canada or Germany), secured by the presence of Trump handlers like former Goldman Sachs president Gary Cohn.\n\nIn the last week, however, the wheels have come off the Trump train in spectacular fashion. The same executives who saw their proximity to the president as a net benefit to their shareholders abruptly changed their calculus when Trump drew a moral equivalency between the neo-Nazi white nationalists marching in Charlottesville, Virginia, last weekend and the protesters who stood up to them. In a press conference at Trump Tower on Tuesday, the president returned to his first reaction to the violence, telling reporters \"I think there is blame on both sides.\" Cohn, among the other White House advisers who were assembled alongside him, having expected to discuss an infrastructure plan, looked distraught. Chief of staff John Kelly, who had recently joined the West Wing in hopes of bringing some military discipline to an unruly group, stared glumly at the floor.\n\nA groundswell of criticism and shock followed from lawmakers on both sides of the aisle, including former presidents, world leaders, and even members of Trump's own staff. By Wednesday, a dozen or so of the business leaders who had bolstered Trump's credibility in his first weeks in office, and were to serve as the lynchpin of his tax-reform campaign, decided to disband their advisory councils in protest. On Thursday, the White House said that it would scrap a third corporate advisory group -- the yet-to-be-fully-formed Council on Infrastructure -- which was only officially established last month. An incorrect tweet claiming that Cohn would be resigning caused the stock market rally to falter, with the benchmark index dropping half a point and Treasury yields falling 0.7 percent before recovering when the rumor was quickly debunked.\n\nThe brief stumble exposed how fragile the business community's faith in Trump has become. Since before the election, the bull case for the Trump presidency was that the real-estate mogul would surround himself with the same stabilizing, charity-circuit set that he mingled with back in New York. In the past week, however, Trump has become increasingly isolated, relying on an ever-smaller circle of loyalists as polite society has turned its back on him. On Tuesday, according to The Washington Post, three fund-raising pillars decided to pull out of events at his Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach, Florida. The American Cancer society, which has held its annual event there for the past eight years, said its \"values and commitment to diversity\" led to its decision to hold the upcoming gala elsewhere. The American Friends of Magen David Adom, which is one of the club's biggest events with roughly 600 attendees, also said it would not to use Mar-a-Lago as the venue for its 2018 gala after \"considerable deliberation.\" The Cleveland Clinic, which had, as recently as this month, said it would host its ninth gala there, reversed course on Wednesday, after 1,600 health professionals said that booking the event there \"symbolically and financially supports a politician actively working to decrease access to health care,\" the Post reported. (The clinic's chief executive also happened to sit on Trump's Strategic and Policy Forum, one of the groups that disbanded this week.)\n\nEven before Trump's widely derided Charlottesville statements, seven other groups that had, in the past, hosted events at Mar-a-Lago had announced that they would be taking their business elsewhere. This amounts to the slowest stretch for charity events at the club in a decade, according to the Post. That will cost the Trump Organization a pretty penny, since each of the galas brings in between $100,000 to $275,000. The president opted to not divest from his global business empire when he took office, relinquishing day-to-day control to his two sons. The whole family retains a financial stake.\n\nBack in the Washington swamp, however, one Trump property isn't feeling a pinch. Trump's International Hotel in Washington, just five blocks down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House, has raised room rates and drink prices in order to keep pace with the overflowing demand for all-things Make America Great Again. On any given night, members of Trump's Cabinet and inner circle will gather in the lobby, and revelers hoping to get a taste of the action have ponied up $25 for cocktails and nearly $700 per night for rooms to drink it all in. And while foundations may be shying away from Mar-a-Lago, conservative organizations, and even a Supreme Court justice aren't pulling back from their D.C. haunt. Only two weeks before the court takes up Trump's travel ban case, Trump's appointee to the bench, Neil Gorsuch, is scheduled to deliver the keynote address at the Fund for American Studies 50th
